Ottawa, February 19, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I am in receipt of a letter dated the 9th instant, signed by J. A. Findlay, Prince Rupert, B.C., who is apparently acting for Indian Agent Gillett. In this letter he states that Miss Emma Schmidt, former teacher of the Sunnyside Indian Day School, is anxious to know how much she will be allowed for sick leave.

Miss Schmidt taught at the Sunnyside Day School from November 26, 1945, to January 18, 1946. In your letter of January 31 you stated that she gave up duties at Sunnyside owing to illness on January 18. We allowed her salary for the month of January. In other words, she was paid for 13 days' sick leave. In view of the fact that she was employed as a teacher for less than two months, I cannot see how we can allow her any additional sick leave. I would appreciate it if you would write to Indian Agent Gillett.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Mr. Gillett, before he went on holidays, sent reports to the Commissioner's office with reference to Miss Emma Schmidt having to leave her school teaching duties on account of illness. She has since sent us a letter stating that a doctor in Vancouver has ordered her to bed for six months suffering from a severe attack of pleurisy. She is anxious to know just how much she will be allowed for sick leave. She taught at Sunnyside Day School from November 28th, 1945 to January 18th, 1946. We might mention that she was Field Matron at Greenville last year from January to June.

JAF/pb

for J. Gillett.
Indian agent.

In a letter dated Sept. 10th, Indian Agent Anfield states that Miss Ruth Atkinson left Prince Rupert on Sept. 9th but before leaving she stated that she had not received her August cheque.

We do not know to what cheque she refers. As far as we know the school closed on June 30th and she was paid up to that time.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Miss Ruth Atkinson has given to me her verbal resignation as teacher at the Sunnyside Indian Day School effective August 31st, 1946.

Miss Atkinson, who left Prince Rupert last night, informed me that she had not received her August cheque. It will be appreciated if this cheque can be located and sent to her airmail, c/o Indian Commissioner's Office, P. O. Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

F. Earl Anfield.
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.
Re: Sunnyside Indian Day School No. 874.

Please note that the Department has accepted the resignation of the teacher Miss Ruth Atkinson effective July 1, 1946 and no further payment of salary should be made to her. I will advise you later who will be in charge of this school for the academic year 1946-47.

for Deputy Head.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of August 26th in connection with the proposed appointment of Mrs. Ethel Kennedy as teacher at the Sunnyside Indian Day School.

It is understood that Miss Ruth Atkinson, the present teacher, intends to relinquish her duties and resume her studies at the University and although her resignation has not been received it is presumed this will be forthcoming and I would recommend the appointment of Mrs. Kennedy to replace her at a salary of $105 a teaching month plus bonus.

Application, questionnaire and other forms will be forwarded on receipt of the Department's approval of this appointment.

For D. H. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
August 26th, 1946.

D. M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 70, Vancouver.

With the approval of the Bishop of Caledonia, Right Reverend J. B. Gibson, the name of Mrs. Ethel Kennedy is placed in nomination for the teachership at the Sunnyside Cannery as from the opening of the 1946-47 school term.

Mrs. Kennedy, age 39, lives at 2009 West 3rd Avenue, Vancouver; she holds a First Class Nova Scotia Professional Teachers Licence; she also holds an Industrial First Aid Certificate. She is a widow with one boy, age 11, and she has not taught for the past eight years. Mrs. Kennedy was interviewed by the writer on the 24th instant and it is recommended that she be appointed to the Sunnyside School at a salary of $105 a teaching month plus cost of living bonus and living quarters.

The B.C. Packers have agreed to build a new teacherage at the Sunnyside Plant this fall and in view of the present condition of the shack occupied by Miss Ruth Atkinson who has taught there for the past few months, I will arrange with the Manager to supply a cannery cottage for Mrs. Kennedy and her son. Permission is also requested for the boy to attend this school whilst his mother is teaching there.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent

June 21, 1946.

AIRMAIL

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, the Department approves the continued operation of the Sunnyside Indian Day School during the months of July, August and September. Salary will be allowed Miss Atkinson at the same rate as formerly paid to her.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your File 168-39-1

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of June 4th in connection with the proposed operation of the Sunnyside Indian Day School during the months of July, August and September. This school was closed during the period January 18th to April 12th and aside from the fact that the operation of the school during the summer months will give the children an opportunity to complete their school work for the year, it would be of considerable advantage to the Indian parents working at the Cannery if the children were occupied. I concur with the Agent's views and would recommend that the school remain open and that Miss Atkinson be employed during the months July to September inclusive.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Prince Rupert, B. C.
June 4th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver.

Miss Ruth Atkinson has made application to this office for permission to continue as teacher at Sunnyside Cannery during the months of July, August and September during which period she would like to conduct a summer school for the Indian children congregated at that centre.

Whilst Miss Atkinson is not a certificated teacher she is an enthusiastic person and I believe that she would do an excellent piece of educational and social service work at Sunnyside and adjacent canneries during the summer. She is prepared to have a morning and afternoon session with different groups and in view of the fact that well over 100 children will be located at this cannery alone anything that can be done to continue their education would be well worthwhile.

In connection with this application it should be stated that Dr. Galbraith hoped to employ both Miss Meier and Miss Fraser as itinerate first aid workers on the Skeena River this summer with headquarters at the North Pacific Hospital. Miss Meier's health is such that she may not be able to accept this post and if Miss Atkinson's continuance as teacher is approved she and Miss Fraser could stay together at Sunnyside.

This matter has been carefully discussed with Miss Atkinson and it is recommended that her application for continued service for the months of July to September be approved. Your early advice will be appreciated so that Miss Atkinson may make the necessary arrangements to continue in residence at Sunnyside.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

cc. Dr. Galbraith.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs for B. C.,
Box 70,
Federal Building,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Major MacKay:

This afternoon I visited the Sunnyside Indian Day School with Mr. Indian Agent Anfield. The teacher at this school cannot be left in charge of the pupils there any longer. If she has not already had a mental breakdown she is on the verge of doing so. She made very wild statements about the fear she had of the Indians and referred to the tragedy that occurred at Port Essington several years ago and stated that she expected the same to happen to her. Apparently she will associate with neither the Indians or the white people at this point because, to quote her, "they are all against me". At several points during the conversation she broke down and cried. She asked how soon she could leave and when I told her that the Department usually expected at least a month's notice she wept.

In the latter part of January I received a letter from Mrs. Kennedy that indicated that she was not happy at Sunnyside. In the light of what I have found at this school it shows signs of the beginning of this teacher's breakdown. This letter is in my files in the Vancouver office under her name.

All of this indicated that Mrs. Kennedy should be moved without delay and I have made arrangements with her and Mr. Anfield to have the Naskeena pick her up at Sunnyside on Monday, February 9th, and bring her to Prince Rupert. I had some difficulty in persuading Mrs. Kennedy that it would be safe for her to travel in this way as she said she was afraid she might be "kidnapped".

I recommend that Mrs. Kennedy's resignation be accepted as from the end of this month. She has promised to forward it to Mr. Indian Agent Anfield.

I hope that the Department will approve of my action in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

R. F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools

Has any decision been arrived at yet regarding the old Girls' Home? There has been a good deal of discussion regarding this building, and personally I am of the opinion that if the Department intend establishing a tubercular sanitarium for the Indians, that this would make a good central station for it, being used as an administrative building, while the patients themselves could be put in small huts outside. As you are aware, there have been many recommendations made on this matter, and some of the most eminent specialists on tuberculosis have made extensive researches regarding this disease. If this place was set aside for incipient cases, more particularly for children, and a competent staff appointed to look after it, the children could be educated, as there are classrooms in this building itself, and I think there would be very little danger on account of its close proximity to the new building.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant in which you enclose for my information a copy of a letter addressed to Mr. Indian Agent Halliday, with regard to the use to which the old Girls' School at Alert Bay might be put to and asking for my recommendation if I have any comments to make thereon.

In reply I beg to say for the time being it would be advisable to withhold any determination as to what use the old Girls' Home should be put to, but I certainly agree with you that it should not be used as a sanitarium. The management of the school has hardly before properly established in the new buildings to know just what they really want. However, when Dr. Scott and myself were at Alert Bay in the summer of 1928, the future use of this school was discussed to a very slight extent with Principal Anfield and it was thought that a part of the same might be utilized for the advanced pupils in technical work. In the meantime there is no reason why the building cannot be used for storing considerable of the materials and commodities used at the school, but I am inclined to the opinion that it is too removed from the kitchen to be used as a cold storage plant.

With further reference to past correspondence, more particularly to your letter of February 7, I would advise you that I have gone thoroughly into the matter of the old Girls' Home at Alert Bay with the Principal of the Residential School.

In the building of this new institution it would seem that there is not sufficient classroom space if the building is filled to capacity. It has been the custom in most of the Residential Schools only to have the children in school for half time; in other words, half of them go in the morning and the other half in the afternoon. Personally, I have always felt that this is more or less an injustice to the Indians, as white children are at school for from five to six hours a day, and they seem to stand it alright and to get along alright, whereas in most of the Residential Schools from two to three hours is the maximum. In the classrooms provided in the new building, they can put one hundred pupils at a time, whereas the capacity of the school is from two hundred to two hundred and forty. It has always been the endeavor of the officials of the Residential School here to keep up the academic end and in order to do this to full capacity, more classrooms will have to be provided.

In looking over the plans of the old building, it would seem that it would not be a matter of very great expense to provide four good classrooms, or if it was felt that some of the other rooms should be kept intact, three good classrooms and four bedrooms on the top floor. If you will look at the plan which was drawn by Mr. Ogilvie, on Page 3 you will see on the ground floor that there is a hallway going through the building from the front door to the back stairs, and also another corridor going through from end to end of the building. Partitions on each side of this latter corridor carry the upper floor, and I would suggest that "I" beams of sufficient strength be used and
these partitions removed. This would convert into one classroom what is now marked the dining room, part of the corridor, the staff sitting-room, and the Principal's office, and would make a classroom with inside dimensions of 23' x 46'. The other classroom downstairs could be made by tearing out the staircase in the corridor, and would make a classroom 46' x 24'6", giving two splendid classrooms downstairs. The verandah on the north-west end should be torn away entirely in order to give plenty of light.

In the upstairs, the room which is marked "dormitory" could be utilized without any changes other than taking away the sleeping verandah in order to give it more light. The other rooms upstairs might be left as they are, or might be used as a fourth classroom by including the private bathroom, infirmary, two chambers and the assistant matron's chamber. The lavatory which is at present would have to be renovated, and new toilet basins put in, as the others have not worked satisfactorily for a number of years, and a new lavatory could be provided in what is now the kitchen so that the plumbing would all be in line; one of these lavatories to be used by the boys, the other for the girls. The floors on the downstairs part of the building would all have to be renewed, as they are badly worn, and possibly new radiators might need to be provided for the heating plant, as for the last two years it was very unsatisfactory, but possibly by overhauling them and making a few changes they could be made to serve. The basement, which has concrete walls all round, and which, since the new drainage system was put in, remains dry, could be used for storing and as a root-house. The potatoes belonging to the institution have been stored there this year, and came through the exceptionally severe winter without any loss.

If, by any chance, you have not a copy of the plan referred to, I would be glad to let you have the one in my possession. The whole expense should not be very great, and it would make a good use of the building which is now lying idle. I would recommend, however, that if the work is done, that a good competent foreman be obtained and the work done by day labor; I think the expense would be much less than by letting a contract; all of which is respectfully submitted for your consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honor to forward for your consideration a scheme for the benefit of the Indians under my charge in this Agency.

As I have before mentioned the area of good land in the Reserves is much too small to permit them to engage in agricultural pursuits, with the exception of the We-wai-ai Kai tribe at Cape Mudge. Consequently during the summer months they go south to earn money in whatever way they can, to the great detriment of both men and women, especially the latter so much so, that in a few years, if things go on as at present, there will be few women left among them.

Now these Indians show a good capacity for mechanical work and any scheme that would induce them to remain at home would be a step in the right direction. I would suggest first, that the Department reserve all the land at Alert Bay which lies between the Church Missionary Society's claims and the

J. W. Powell Esq.,
Ind. Sup't.
point already reserved by the Provincial Government. This piece of land is admirably adapted for the purpose, large enough for the settlement of all Indians likely to come there. Here they would be willing to leave their present mode of life, could live secure from molestations from the others would gradually get accustomed to a civilized way of living, and would be more under control.

As soon as the land is secured as an Indian Reserve I would propose that a large building be erected, in which the different trades of Carpenter, Blacksmith, Boatbuilder and Shoemaker should be taught. The two trades of Carpenter and Blacksmith would not need resident instructors, as they could be obtained in the place and could be paid only when their services were required. The Shoemaker and boatbuilder would have to be frequently settled here for a time. The building would require to be about 60 ft x 40 ft, 26 ft high, an estimate of the cost of which I provide with tools I enclose. Next I would suggest the proposal of the Department acquiring the Saw Mill now erected and adjoining the land I propose to be Reserved. This would in the end save the Department expense, as the mill properly managed would soon pay for itself and be a source of employment to those settling...
the new village. The Department already an interest in the mill, and have obtained from the Church Missionary Society's representative that in the event of the Department being reimbursed for the actual outlay, the amount of which I also state in my estimate of the sum needed for the purpose. Next I would suggest the advisability of rendering some assistance to those wishing to build decent houses; these would form a nucleus around which others from all the tribes would quickly gather there, and not till then can anything in the shape of instruction be successful amongst them. Their mode of life at present is too nomadic to hope to do anything.

A home for girls is also another thing that would be eventually required and which would answer a twofold purpose both for instruction in household duties and also general instruction.

A small hospital and resident man are greatly needed. The distance from Victoria, nearly 240 miles, with no very regular communication, precludes the obtaining any medical assistance. There have been two urgent cases only during the last ten days and great numbers are in need of medical treatment.
P. O' Reilly,
H. R. Co.,

Alert Bay is 260 miles from Metlakatla; it is the center of nine villages, the farthest only thirty-five miles away, containing about 1500 Indians; and it is admitted by all to be the best site in this district for an Indian school.

At this place, and at no other, there is a Post Office and therefore the steamships call here to have also the Indian Agent's house, mission house and church.

I would therefore most respectfully yet earnestly beg you to do all in your power to obtain a grant of money for the purpose of building and maintaining a girls' school at Alert Bay similar what so successfully carried on at Metlakatla for boys.

In five years we had Indian girls in our care several of whom are now mothers and an ornament to our Mission. But the parents found my action was legally marry their daughters and because their gain he could no longer make them to send their daughters to come.
But here are orphan girls whom I venture to suggest should become wards of the Department and placed in the girl boarding school, and doubtless others would follow. Nothing that the Department could do would confer so great a blessing on these people as the successful working of such an institution. It would do more than anything else to break up the system of pot-latching, and this must be destroyed before any real progress can be made amongst this people.

Probably you are aware of the fact that it is impossible for a young man to legally marry. The pair live together according to Indian law, after the man has given a "pot-latch" to the girl's parents or relatives claiming to recall their daughter whenever he chooses until the husband gives them another "pot-latch." Not unfrequently this "pot-latch" is forthcoming from another man, or sent to him to enable her people to gain more.
Referring to your valued letter of August... although the Department sanctioned and encouraged its Agent in Pidcock in probably preventing some Indian women leaving our boat alone for Victoria, yet so severe a reprimand has been given to our constable by his superior officer that he refuses to act again. Hence nothing has been done.

Can no arrangement be made with our Provincial Government or with the Steamship Company by the... traffic can be checked?

From a conversation held with our... Mr. John Robson & found in perfect sympathy with our views.

It is three years since I addressed you with reference to the necessity of providing a home for Indian girls at this place.

You were then kind enough to make certain proposals which came to my approval in England, and who have been unable to accept.

I am now returning to Alert Bay and have journeyed without a Miss Dudley who had volunteered to act as matron of this proposed home for girls. This lady is forty years of age and I consider her financially capable of fulfilling this position.

I cannot too strongly press upon the Indian Department of the urgency there is for such an institution home for girls at Alert Bay.
And as I have positively no funds in prospect I beg you to make an allowance for each girl's maintenance and clothing, if not less than $50 per annum.

I do not propose accepting more than ten pupils for the first year, but hope in the near future to have 25 or 30 under training. From experience it has been learned that day schools are not a success with the Indians, as the attendance is most irregular, which is a great drawback to the advancement of the children in the acquirement of knowledge. Industrial, or Boarding schools, so far, seem to work very well, as the children are collected and the parents know that they are well cared for and not at all uneasy about their welfare abroad upon their fishing or trading expeditions.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge your letter No. 70 of the 14th. July together with a copy of letter from the Deputy Supt. General in regard to the erection of Workshops &c at Alert Bay Cormorant Island, and requesting me to report on the same.

I believe no plan of the proposed building has yet been accepted by the Department and therefore before this is definitely settled no idea can be given of the price of construction. I believe the best way, in a place so far from Victoria as Alert Bay is, is to erect the buildings by day work, appointing one of carpenters, if a competent man, as foreman.

In my letter of Dec. 4th. 1890, I gave my reasons for suggesting an alteration in the scheme and also in the character of the buildings, and went fully into the reason why a change in the scheme would be of so much more advantage to the Indians of this locality. I will again

A. W. Vowell Esq.,
Visiting Indian Superintendent.
again briefly state why the plan as originally proposed would not be of much benefit.

In the first place before any trade can be successfully learnt, a certain amount of knowledge must first be obtained by the pupil, especially in carpentry and blacksmith work, and until such knowledge has been imparted, very little progress will be made, and it is not to be supposed that trade instructors will teach anything except in their own particular line of business.

2nd. As the young men who would be likely to attend would be of an age when it is difficult to control them, their attendance would be very irregular, and at times, as during this last winter when all were away for four months at one time, there would be absolutely no occupation for the instructors.

3rd. The school as proposed would only be used by the one tribe, the Nimkeesh, as no one who knows the character of these Indians would suppose that any of the parents would leave their own village to reside at Alert Bay for the benefit of their children.

As the Deputy Supt. General says in his letter of 7 Dec'r 1889 "as the scheme is purely a tentative one, and may not at all unlikely prove a failure" it seems to me, that after mature
mature consideration, the present scheme is not likely to be attended with success, it would be much better to defer the building of Workshops and dwelling houses for Instructors, until such time as some scheme that would be of real benefit to these Indians could be settled upon.

I know of nothing more likely to be of real benefit to the Indians of this Agency than an Industrial School after the plan of other Industrial Schools erected in the Province, where the youth of both sexes might be taken permanently away from the influence of their present mode of life, and I feel sure that as many pupils could be obtained as the School could accommodate.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose my report on the Alert Bay Industrial School for the month of October, which it will be noticed is not altogether a favorable one.

I have always regarded this and similar institutions as the only means of lifting the Indians of this Agency to the higher level which should prevail. As a consequence I have spared no effort at any and all times to do everything in my power to make it a success. Mr. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, has been inspecting this office and affairs pertaining to this agency and accompanied me to the Industrial School, and I regret to state there was nothing to justify the praise which I had bestowed on the institution.

One very regrettable fact was the absence of both the Principal and assistant teachers of the institution, who were away entirely without consent from the Department.

The Principal casually in conversation on the evening of 15th instant mentioned that he was going to Victoria to attend the meeting of the clerical synod, and that George Luther his assistant had already gone. He was asked if the school was to be allowed to run itself but replied that Mrs. Gerker would be in charge. I informed him that I could not consider that this arrangement would be at all satisfactory to the Department, and advised that either he or his assistant should remain at home, and that as the Department built...
and equipped the school, and provided the necessary funds for its maintenance, that, to put the matter very mildly, it was only a matter of courtesy that before vacating his post for a week he should first obtain permission from the Department, and even then should provide a proper substitute.

It may be remembered that in June 1936 the Principal of this institution went to England on furlough for over a year. On that occasion though he had been making preparations for months with regard to his departure the Department was not consulted on the matter. This occasioned considerable correspondence with the Department and this method of procedure was condemned by the Department, and on his return to duty this office notified the Principal that his conduct had merited the disapproval of the Department.

I do not wish to dictate to the Department what course should or should not be pursued but I would respectfully recommend that a reprimand should be sent to the Principal from your office, a copy of which should be sent to this office, so that in future these unpleasantnesses may be avoided.

I wish to state that there is absolutely no personal animus in the case, but feel that it is my duty to call your attention to the matter.

Your obedient servant,

My dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of November 25. Mr. Corker and his Assistant attended the meeting of the Synod, and the School at Alert Bay was left under the charge of Mrs. Corker assisted by her son, who has lately returned from a good public school in England. Mrs. Corker holds the highest certificates for teaching, and has had large experience, and is an excellent disciplinarian.

With regard to Mr. Corker himself I can assure you that no better Master could be found. He is a man of very strong character, and resents any interference except from those who have authority. We all deplore the resignation of Mr. Vowell as Superintendent. His wise and firm rule was thoroughly appreciated. No greater mistake could be made than to make a man like Mr. Corker feel that he was to be subordinate to, and take his orders from, an Indian Agent. In this case if Mr. Halliday, knowing that Mr. Corker was away, had offered to assist Mrs. Corker in any way in his power, he would have, in my opinion, been doing his duty; but at such a time to "inspect" and label the School, would I am sure have drawn from Mr. Vowell or any other official Head of a Department a rebuke.

Several parts of the School require money to be spent upon it, but apart from this, you may be assured that the discipline and the influence for good of Mr. Corker are all that could be desired.

My dear Sir,

As medical officer of the Alert Bay Industrial School for Indian Boys I have been asked two letters from your Department actually criticizing the management of the above mentioned school.

During the last twenty-three months I have visited the school dozens of times and can testify on the oath that I have never yet found the school in any thing but a creditable condition of cleanliness and tidiness. I consider the school in keps in for condition even for the same number of white boys and very suitable indeed when we consider the orderliness and cleanliness are quite foreign to the boys.

I consider the school the most efficiently managed place of Indian work and of the most creditable Department of Indian Affairs. If anything that I ever wrote on the subject.

My teacher George Luther (an old pupil) is a young man very suitable for ordination, and the Synod naturally wished him to be present.

I consider I made adequate provision for the proper carrying on of the school during my absence.

Mrs. Coker, who is matron of the school, is a capable school mistress and a good disciplinarian. I did not leave until nearly midnight on Sunday Oct. 16th. The next day the officials called. In this short interval the school could not possibly have got dirty. Miss Warren, assistant matron, assured me the boys were in perfect order during the week, I was away. Blue Book page 246, (1909). "The school is well situated and ably managed."

Blue Book 1910. 336. "The (Mrs. Coker) has a well equipped staff," etc. I beg to state here there has been no change in my staff since this was written.

remarks should be made here, and such totally different reports sent to the Department is more than I can understand.

Sir,

The Lord Bishop of Columbia wrote to Mr. Corken on Dec 5th complaining of the "lack of discipline" and "the unclean appearance of this school" on the occasion of the visit of two officers of the Department. As Mr. Corken was absent on that date these two remarks reflect upon me, hence my reason for writing to you.

Since the year 1893 when Mr. Corken was appointed to take charge of this school I have been Matron and have in all these years aimed at perfect cleanliness in every department; this is the first time that anyone has ever said such a thing. It is so false that it seems ridiculous to write refuting it, it is especially so as I remarked to Miss Warner (Assistant Matron) on the morning of the aforementioned visit, we will have extra scrubbing done today, and literally the school was a great deal cleaner than usual. It is an extremely difficult subject to eulogize oneself but I am only writing thus for the Department's enlightenment. I taught for 8 years in a London School where the highest merit grant was always obtained. I am a Certificated Teacher and frequently help Mr. Corken in the classroom. The school was in perfect order when Mr. Hitchbourne and Mr. Halliday arrived, the boys rose and saluted them. Mr. Halliday introduced Mr. Hitchbourne whom I had never seen nor even heard of. He asked for Mr. Corken. I told him simply Mr. Corken was away but would be very sorry to miss him. They were both rather rude, they said I was only Mr. Corken which of course I admitted. I asked them if they would like to hear the boys read or see the work they discovered, etc. As it was just cleaning up...
Came and took charge of the boys, setting them to work. I proceeded to show the Gentleman round the school accompanied by Miss Warren. The Dormitories, Dining Room, Kitchen, Bath rooms, Store rooms & Laundry were in perfect order. I was pleased to show them. I took them to the vegetable garden, workshop, well house etc.

I should like to add that some things in the School are very shabby, we have been in the building 17 years this month & things have a way of wearing out. We would like to ask the Department for many things & we feel if my Ottawa could visit us they would supply every one realizing they were all very legitimate wants.

Apologizing for taking up so much time & with the power of proving absolutely true every word I have written.

I am

Yours Sincerely,

The Matron,
Emma Corke.

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Dec. 6th, 116947, and in reply beg to state that these reports are false. In reading your letter carefully over I consider the summing up very strong, in consideration of the charges.

In reply to your letter of the 15th. of December with reference to the management of the Alert Bay Industrial School, I have to inform you that the Department is deeply concerned in the welfare of this institution and of the Indians who are dependent upon it for the education of their children. Sir:

With further reference to my report of October 22 on the affairs of the Alert Bay Industrial School I beg to state that there must be some misunderstanding somewhere. In my report I make a specific complaint for a specific offense, while I infer from your letter that the matter has been treated as a general complaint. I thank you for the last clause in your letter which reads "You have always been considered as a friend to the cause of Indian education and the warm support you gave the project of erecting the Girl's School at Alert Bay was a factor which led to a favorable decision on that project X X X X."

This very fact was my reason for making the complaint and I would ask that you read this report again carefully and in it you will find my views on Industrial schools on the whole, which are, that in my opinion the Industrial school system is the only system so far as this agency is concerned.

Shortly after my taking office as Indian Agent for this agency I was in the Indian Office in Victoria and took up the matter of Industrial schools amongst other things; and asked what relationship should exist between the Indian Agent and the School authorities. The instructions given me verbally were that the Indian Agent represented the Department and if he saw anything wrong in the management or method of conducting affairs at any time his duty was first to take up the matter personally with the Principal and discuss the matter medically and if it was

J.D. McLean Esq.
Secretary Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.
not remedied my duty was then to report the matter to the Department. I may say that this is the method that has been consistently followed and it is the first time that it has been necessary to lay a complaint to the Department the previous matters having been settled amicably.

I informed the Principal of the School of the intended coming of Mr Inspector Ditchburn, and as a matter of fact Mr Ditchburn was at Alert Bay about one hour before Mr Gerber left. In my conversation with Mr Ditchburn previous to inspection I had spoken very favorably of the Industrial school, but conditions at the time of our visit did not in any sense warrant the opinion given to Mr Ditchburn on the morning of the day on which we called at the school. I may say in all fairness to the school management that I hardly ever saw the school untidy or dirty on any previous occasion, but on the occasion of our visit not only were the boys in school very untidy but the whole school from top to bottom looked as though no care had been taken and I therefore held to the same opinion that the Principal was doing his duty when he would leave home without getting some competent person to take care of things during his absence. Formerly no boy would be allowed to take his seat in the schoolroom without having his jacket on. On that day a large percentage were in their shirt sleeves, and many of them had lost the buttons from their neckbands and wristbands which were flopping in a very untidy manner. Two boys wore knickerbocker trousers, underneath which they wore long drawers of white cotton flannel which should be tied with tapes round the ankles. The tapes were off and as the boys mentioned had neither boots nor stockings on you can imagine what they would look like when they walked across the floor.
In all fairness I would ask how either the Bishop of Columbia or Dr Baker could be in any position to express any opinion as to the condition of the Alert Bay Industrial school on that particular occasion, nor can I see anything in the report to make anyone suppose that such a condition was customary. In my report I only requested that the Principal be reprimanded to avoid in future any such centretamps, as they are very detrimental to the school.

With regard to the statement of Mrs Gerker that both I, and Mr Ditchburn, were rude in our manner to her I beg to give a most emphatic and absolute denial.

In conclusion I would request as I did in my former report that the principal be instructed that in future he must not leave the school without leaving some competent person approved by the Department in his place, and this request is made in the interests of the education of the boys and not from a sense of "defending our different positions and spheres of duty" as mentioned in your letter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

My dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th Instant, and to assure you that I fully recognize the fact of the concern of the Department for the welfare of the Indians. I hope that I have not in my former letters seemed to cast any doubt upon the matter. I do not consider it necessary to say that I am equally interested.

There appears to me to be a blot upon the present system in the appointment of Agents as a political reward. It must be in the cognizance of the Department that owing to this, it often happens that the best men are not selected. In this Province it did not make so much difference so long as a Superintendent like Mr. Vowell was over them, but now that so much power is put into the hands of the Agents, it is a most serious affair. In the case of Alert Bay, there is no doubt that there is friction between Mr. Halliday and Mr. Corker. How it arose I am not absolutely certain, but the whole condition of things ought to be thoroughly probed. The outrageous length of the "Potlatch", and the fact that the Indians obtained liquor without being dealt with is generally known. Moreover there is dissatisfaction amongst the White people at the appointment of a Custom House Officer in the person of Mr. Halliday at a stipend of $300 a year.

I can only repeat that no School could have a better Master than Mr. Corker, who has faithfully worked on, and who is worthy of the whole-hearted support of the Department.

Yours faithfully,

W.W. Columbia

There appears to me to be a blot upon the present system in the appointment of Agents as a political reward. It must be in the cognizance of the Department that owing to this, it often happens that the best men are not selected. In this Province it did not make so much difference so long as a Superintendent like Mr. Vowell was over them, but now that so much power is put into the hands of the Agents, it is a most serious affair. In the case of Alert Bay, there is no doubt that there is friction between Mr. Halliday and Mr. Corker. How it arose I am not absolutely certain, but the whole condition of things ought to be thoroughly probed. The outrageous length of the "Potlatch", and the fact that the Indians obtained liquor without being dealt with is generally known. Moreover there is dissatisfaction amongst the White people at the appointment of a Custom House Officer in the person of Mr. Halliday at a stipend of $300 a year.

I can only repeat that no School could have a better Master than Mr. Corker, who has faithfully worked on, and who is worthy of the whole-hearted support of the Department.

My dear Sir:

Your reply to my letter makes it clear that this Diocese is responsible for the management of the new Home for Girls at Alert Bay. Will you please forward to me the necessary form of agreement, which will convey the Home to our charge. We are now ready to undertake the responsibility, subject to one condition expressed below.

I have just returned from visiting the new Home; the building is excellent in every way and seems to be well and thoroughly furnished with necessaries of all sorts, and of the best material. Mr. Halliday has evidently made these things his special care, and deserves our thanks for his pains.

The site is, in my judgment, not so wisely selected; the close proximity to the Boys' School is likely to increase the difficulty of maintaining due discipline in both institutions. The Department will, I hope, recognize there will be this difficulty and will be also confident that those who take charge of the Home will do their best to overcome it.

The girls dormitory is too small to accommodate 30. This is quite obvious now that the thirty beds are put up in it. There is however no real difficulty here, for other rooms...
can be used for some of the other girls to sleep in.

A wise provision for the education of the girls is, in my opinion, vital to the success of the whole undertaking. The plan hitherto suggested has been that the girls should be taught at the village school. In reply to Your Lordship's request for information regarding the Alert Bay Girls' Home I beg to say that in January, 1890, the Rev. Mr. Hall, Principal of the Alert Bay Industrial School, wrote the Department asking for the establishment of a residential school for girls. Mr. Hall had for some years prior to this application maintained and educated a few Indian girls in his own house without Government aid. The Department, recognizing the desirability of industrial training and education being afforded to Indian girls, agreed to allow Mr. Hall a per capita grant of $70.00 for the education and maintenance of a certain number of girls, not to exceed 30. Mr. Hall carried on the school up to 1905, when it was closed for want of pupils. Mr. Hall, after being forced to discontinue the school, urged the Department to re-open the school, the need of which as a protection to the girls was plainly put before the Department as Your Lordship will see from the enclosed copy of a letter from our Agent at Alert Bay dated January 5th, 1910. Sir:

The only complaint I had to investigate at Alert Bay was in connection with the management of the Girls' Home. A number of the girls who had been allowed out on their holidays, had not returned and a special constable had been appointed to bring them back. Some of the parents contended that the children had not been looked after properly and were allowed to go home with their heads in an unclean condition; also that the girls were made to work digging the garden and doing other general work around the school which they did not think girls should be called upon to do. I regret to say that upon investigation these complaints were well founded. As regards the children's heads not being kept in a clean condition, it was admitted by the school authorities that some time last year some of the girls went to their homes and their heads were found to be infected with vermin. I took this matter up with the matron, Miss Neville, and she admitted that, at the time about which the Indians complained, owing to the staff being extremely busy, the children's heads had not been properly inspected for a week. With reference to the complaint of the Indians that the girls had to do work which they should not be called upon to do, this and the other complaint is the direct result of a recommendation I made to the management of this school at the time it was opened not being carried out. At that time I gave my opinion that it would be found necessary to have a man employed to do the general labor work and carry out the many odd jobs in connection with this institution that no woman could do successfully. However, I was informed that such help was not required and that the staff and the girls could do everything that was necessary.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
The result has been that the girls have been made to do all the work in connection with the establishment and the premises. This was all right until the novelty wore off and then the Indians had a chance to complain, and to my mind with some just cause.

In so far as the childrens' heads not being kept clean I am satisfied that after my talk with the matron that this will not happen again, but I would recommend that the authorities, who have supervision of this school, should be informed that it is necessary to have a man appointed who will attend to the general work of the school, for it cannot be expected that Mr. Eli Hunt, who is the manual training instructor of the Boys' Industrial School, should act as general utility at the Girls' Home, for his time is, or should be, fully taken up giving instructions to the boys. However as the Girls' Home is under the supervision of the Anglican Diocese of British Columbia and the Boys' Industrial School is supervised by the Church Missionary Society, two separate and distinct bodies, a scheme of such a nature would not work out satisfactorily. If a man is appointed to do the general work around the Girls' Home it would then give the staff full opportunity to carry out their duties more efficiently and would permit of no excuse for laxity in their oversight of the childrens' persons.

At the Girls' Home, of which Miss A.R. Neville is matron, there were only 21 girls present, 11 not having returned since their holidays. I have since received word that the special constable had succeeded in bringing all the children back to the school! Miss N.E. Nixon gives the girls a good education in the classroom and the children have been making all the progress that can be expected of them. Dear Mr. Scott,

I should have reported to you before this that we have been making a change in the Principalship of our Indian Schools at Alert Bay. The Rev. A.W. Corker after long, faithful and devoted service has asked to be relieved, and in his place we have appointed Vivian S. Lord, Esq., as Principal.

The Dept. will be interested to learn that in Mr. Lord we believe we have an exceptionally suitable person for this position. The son of an English clergyman, Mr. Lord received a public school education and took part of his course at Oxford; he then was apprenticed to an engineering firm where he also took a course in carpentering. For some years he studied farming in South America, and then in Canada, and after several years overseas, he has been engaged at a lumber camp near Alert Bay.

After all this experience he has offered to tackle this work as a missionary undertaking, and if he finds he can do it to our satisfaction he is ready to give himself to it as a life work.

My own interview with him confirms all that I have been told by those who have known him, that Mr. Lord is a man of exceptional ability and of strong character; and that since he is taking up the work in a sincerely religious spirit, he should be a tower of strength to the boys and girls of the schools.

Will you then kindly deal with Mr. Lord in all matters pertaining to the School at Alert Bay, sending the quarterly cheques to him.

With kindest regards, I remain, yours faithfully,

Sir:-

I regret to inform you that I have received a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Halliday stating that on Sunday, the 13th instant, an attempt was made to burn down the Indian Girls Home at Alert Bay by two of the pupils, and on this matter I have to draw your attention to the remarks contained in Mr. Halliday's letter wherein he says that after a conference between himself and Principal Corker he suggested that if the two girls were given a good thrashing it would not occur again.

I am inclined to think that too much leniency has been extended to the pupils on this matter, as this is the fifth Indian school that has been on fire in a period of nine months.

In the five weeks from May 5th to June 15th, 1917, the Ahousaht, Alberni and Sechelt schools were burned down, the Clayoquot Indian school was also set on fire but was put out before much damage was done. Upon investigation it was shown that at Ahousaht and Clayoquot the fires were deliberately set by some of the pupils, at Alberni and Sechelt the origin of the fires was doubtful. The fire at Alert Bay makes the fifth, and I am therefore of the opinion that these girls should have been arrested and dealt with under Section 511 of the Criminal Code, which deals with the crime of arson, as I believe that if these girls had been sent to the Provincial Girls Home in Vancouver for a long term and notices put up in all the schools explaining what had happened.

I have also to report that institution had a narrow escape from being burned last Sunday night. A girl by name of Kathleen Collison, who comes from the north, from a spirit of pique over some fancied grievance procured some old rags, soaked them with coal oil, and crawled under the building in the part that has not been excavated and set fire to the waste, amongst the joints of the building. It was just at the time they were preparing to go to church, but fortunately another girl happened to notice the blaze and Miss Ferryman went in with a bucket of water and the fire was extinguished immediately before any harm was done. Mr. Corker held an investigation into it and finally the girl confessed and stated that another girl had been with her at the time. The reason given for the offence was that if the home was burned they would have a good holiday before a new one could be built. Mr. Corker reported the affair to me and asked me what I thought best to do as the staff at the girls' home thought she should be sent to jail. After hearing all about this matter I told Mr. Corker that if, under the circumstances, he gave the two of them a good thrashing that it would not occur again, and that if the girls were sent home the same thing would be likely to occur again, as in my experience while teaching at the Boys Home was that oftentimes mischief was done by the boys in the hope that they would be discharged from the school and sent home and not from any criminal or malicious intent. Confirming my Lettergram of last night I desire to take up more fully the question of an increase in the allowance at present made by your Department to the "Girls' Home" at Alert Bay, which has already been brought to your notice by Principal Corker.

In the first place I desire to put before you the following summary of the account with the "Home" as it stands in the books of this Diocese from May 1913 to December 1916:

| Month | Govt. Grant | Expenditure |
|-------|-------------|-------------|
| May   | $2073.50    | $3035.61    |
| Jan   | $1619.25    | $184.81     |
| Feb   | $2358.25    | $3732.13    |

| Total | $8539.75    | $13,220.82  |

This a/c shows that in the three years and nine months we have had to raise almost $5,000.00 over and above the Government Aid in order to carry on efficiently our work for the Indian Girls.

As our Principal states the tremendous increase in the price of all food-stuffs, clothing, and boots makes it abundantly clear that the cost of Board and clothing the pupils is growing rapidly.

We are as anxious as the Department can be that the Character Training of these Indian Children, which can only be accomplished under such influences as prevail in this kind of school, should be continued, and to this end we are prepared to urge our people to contribute to their support. At the same time the strenuous demands of the Patriotic Fund, Red Cross, and other War Calls are making it more and more difficult to maintain this kind of work which is dependent on the voluntary contributions of the Church-people. Furthermore, these difficulties, tho' common to all, are greatly aggravated by the specially unsatisfactory financial condition prevailing at present in these Western Provinces.

Sir,

I have acknowledged receipt of your letter of March 8th referring to a report from Mr. Inspector Cairns regarding the milk cows kept at the Alert Bay Industrial and Girls' Boarding schools and also to the fact that milk was being sold from the school when there was not a sufficient supply for the use of the pupils.

I took this matter up personally with Mr. Lord, the Principal of the school, and gave him a copy of your letter. I am in receipt of a reply from him stating that he has forwarded a copy of your letter to Dr. Nesbitt, Secretary of the Commission managing the Indian schools.

He also states that he has issued instructions that all sales of milk, cream or butter are to cease as soon as possible. He states also that since the beginning of the year the only sales made, with the exception of the butter from the Girls' Home have been to deluge people in case of sickness and young babies etc., etc., during circumstances prevalent on this island are almost unable to obtain the said commodity, and he states further that 100 pounds of butter was bought for the Girls' Home during the quarter ending March 31st, showing that the girls did not lack butter for which he adds is the main part of the milk.

In connection with these schools I have always urged on the principal the necessity for having more land put under cultivation so that stock could be kept and as I have pointed out that in addition to supplying the schools a very profitable dairy business could be conducted and the whole of the land might be supplied to the benefit of the settlers and to the profit of the schools. The late principal, the Rev. L. W. Corker, while agreeing with me in principle did not seem to be able to get the land under cultivation. Mr. Lord has for some time been a practical farmer and he is gradually extending their clearing. When Dr. Nesbitt, the Superintendent for the missionary Society of the Church of England, visited Alert Bay I took the matter up with him and urged on him the necessity of having land cleared for the benefit of the school, and he promised to give it his careful consideration but as his trip was a hurried one he told me that he would have to leave the details for further consideration before bringing it to the attention of the finance committee.

ALERT BAY.

BOYS' SCHOOL.

At the time of my visit to Alert Bay this summer, I found an insufficient staff on the boys' side and no harmony among the officers. The Principal has poor control over both boys and staff and, generally speaking, the institution is only fairly successful.

At this institution the boys' and girls' plants are entirely separate in finance and management, with the exception of the Principal himself. Even the gardens are under different control.

The boys' building needs new flooring on the main floor, and the foundation will have to be renewed very shortly. The range in the kitchen is in bad condition. The lavatories are all outdoor, and a new one for staff is badly needed. The water supply is adequate. Stoves only are used for heating. Laundry equipment is all "hand" in type. Water should be piped to it. Lighting is entirely by lamps.

The boys' classroom, which is a separate building, is in bad shape. It is crowded and the desks are poor, and at the other end of the building there is a noisy carpenter shop.

The boys' dormitories (2) are fairly good, but beds are badly needed. There are no wash room or lavatory facilities on the upper floors.

A complete new school for boys is really needed, and Dr. Westgate suggests building onto the girls school. The present water system would be adequate for a large building. Detached classrooms are satisfactory on the West Coast and if they had 3 rooms in one building and commenced co-education I believe better results would be obtained.

The Agent can place 120 pupils here. There are 50 on the waiting list now. The Kwawkewlth Agency is entirely Protestant.

GIRLS' SCHOOL.

The outside needs painting and I understand the contract has been let. The girls' staff is very efficient. The girls' dormitory has plenty air space, but hardly enough floor space for 56 girls. Lavatory and wash room facilities are on the same floor as the dormitory. Infirmary O.K. Third floor but a storeroom. Building is steam heated. Main floor needs renovating. The building on the whole is well provided, but is too small for 56 girls.
Basement is concrete. Adequate water supply (Artesian well with gas engine pump to cistern for both school). Lighting by lamps. In the near future a wing to permit of more dormitory accommodation is badly needed.

Thirty acres are cultivated, mostly potatoes but some vegetables are raised. Hay for the four cows has to be purchased.

Arrangements should be made to strengthen the hands of the Agent and Principal so that pupils could be held until they are eighteen (See Agent's report of March, 1921, concerning this).

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the holiday period at Indian residential schools. I have noted the reasons advanced by you why it might be desirable to arrange for a 6 weeks' period.

In reply I beg to state that the Department cannot change its regulations in this connection, at the present time. Some schools in certain parts of Canada are so situated that it is impracticable to allow the children to go home in the summer time. At these schools, arrangements are made for summer camps and other outings, always under the supervision of members of the staff. Further, I am of the opinion that there will always be delinquent pupils who fail to return promptly at the expiration of a holiday period, and a lengthening of the vacation would result in a general disorganizing of institutional routine, for a period every summer of at least two months. Most of our institutions are crowded to the limit of their capacity, and no opportunity must be lost to educate and prepare for Christian citizenship the youth of the present generation.

If it is found, at any school, that the general health and stamina of the children are not what they should be, special arrangements can be made upon application to the Department for outdoor activities, as a substitution for classroom work for those weeks in the summer that are not in the vacation period. The Department believes that the children enrolled at Indian residential schools should be, for 11 months of the year, under the discipline, care and civilizing influence of the staff of workers.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

This acknowledges the receipt of your letter of February the 16th in which you state that Dr. Westgate, Acting General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, requests that the holiday period for the Alert Bay Residential Schools be extended from four weeks to six weeks each year.

It will be just as well to recognize that if the request is granted in this case it will, of necessity, lead to a change of policy in this matter by the Indian Department. For I feel certain that similar requests will come from many of our Residential Schools.

It would be well, too, to remember that according to Indian Day School Regulations, the pupils of Day Schools have two months' holidays. I think that the arguments in favour of two months' holidays for our day school are equally cogent when applied to Residential Schools.

There is a tendency in educational circles to increase the holiday time. July and August are holidays in all the public schools of British Columbia. From a health point of view it is generally recognized that pupils are better out of the class-room during the period of extremely hot weather.
The objective of all our schools is to develop the moral, mental, and physical powers of the child. Therefore I am prepared to sanction any change that will help the schools to attain that objective.

There is also another phase of the question. At the present time many pupils do not return promptly and the result is that the quarter ending September 30th generally shows a marked decrease in the financial results. This leads to difficulty in financing the schools.

On the whole, I am in favour of the holiday period being extended to six weeks with full grant. Practically, it takes two weeks to get the pupils back to school and organized for work. If the policy of six weeks' holidays were adopted then punctuality on the part of the pupils should be insisted upon.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

It is with very great regret that I have to make the following report.

About 7.30 pm, Sept. 15th, I was informed that the Girls' Home was on fire. I hurried over at once and found that a pile of coats in the attic had been ablaze, but had already been extinguished by Miss Dibben, Matron i/c, with an Extinguisher. This lady's presence of mind and promptitude was very praiseworthy.

Mr. Indian Agent Halliday arrived a few minutes after me and it was clear to us both that the fire was not of accidental origin. Upon investigation it was found that the fire had been deliberately lit by Kitty Wannock, accompanied by Marion Webb. We also discovered that a small fire on Sept. 7th, had been lit by Molly Wilson. (This was a small fire in some underclothes, which did no damage. I reported this to Rev. Dr. Westgate, but did not think it of sufficient importance to report to the Dept., as no damage was done, and the fire appeared to be accidental).

I punished the above three girls in the presence of Mr. Halliday and the assembled school. Also, on the recommendation of Mr. Halliday, Kitty Wannock was expelled that evening. All three girls were members of a small group which had given us a great deal of trouble last term, and their only excuse was that they wanted to get out of school.

I would strongly recommend that all the girls be sent to a Reformatory, or a more distant school. Molly Wilson and Marion Webb have a bad influence in the School, but I should not like to see them sent to their own villages, - they need to be saved from themselves. Also if Kitty Wannock is permitted to remain at home it will only encourage other girls who wish to get out to commit similar acts. On the other hand if all three girls are sent away the moral effect will be very great.

I am glad to be able to report that no damage whatever was done to the building itself. The only damage was to clothing and bedding, of which the following was destroyed:

I beg to advise you that on Monday evening the 14th inst. a fire occurred at the Alert Bay Girls' Home.

It so happened that I was at the Industrial School which adjoins the Girls' Home overlooking the sewerage proposition and was informed that a fire had occurred at the Girls' Home and I immediately went over and found that the fire had been extinguished.

A week previous another fire had occurred in the same Institution which the ladies of the Institution thought was purely accidental and they were inclined to treat this one as accidental but after thorough examination of the situation I concluded that both fires had been of incendiary origin and I so informed the Principal. The girls were all called into the school room and questioned very closely and finally admissions were made by Kitty Wharnock that she had deliberately started the present fire and Molly Wilson admitted having deliberately started the other one. Associated with Kitty Wharnock was a girl known as Marian Webb who while she did not take any actual part was present when Kitty Wharnock started the fire up in the attic on a pile of clothing which was covered over by sheets.

Miss Dibben, the Matron of the Institution, very fortunately kept her head and used the chemical fire extinguisher directly the fire was discovered and thus avoided any serious loss but a few minutes longer would have resulted in the fire getting into the roof and possibly the whole building being destroyed.

The three girls in question were
publicly whipped before the staff, the Indian Agent and the rest of the girls and I immediately expelled Kitty Whonnock and took her home to her people. The other girl's misconduct was really not discovered until the next day and as her parents live at Kingcome Inlet she has not yet been expelled from the school but is being kept separate from the rest of the girls and is practically a prisoner.

In talking the matter over with the Principal I suggested that possibly the Department would consider the prosecution of these girls in the Criminal Court and have them sent to the reform school for girls which is near the City of Vancouver partly for their own sake that their education maybe continued and partly for the discipline of the school but before taking this step I would like your decision on the matter.

On being questioned the only excuse that the girls could give was that they felt lonely which being interpreted meant that they wanted to go out and carry on with the boys but were not given the opportunity to do so.

Sir,— 156-0-1

Your letter of May 20th was duly received but owing to the fact that I was called away for a few days and on my return the Principal was away for a few days I was unable to act upon it until this week. On the 8th inst. I went to the Industrial School and had a long interview with the Principal regarding the food supplies for the school. Mr. Spackman allowed me the free use of his requisitions and while on the whole there is ample food supplied for the boys it was pointed out to Mr. Spackman that many changes could be made that would benefit the boys and which in my opinion should be made commencing with the next quarter.

I find, first, that no butter is allowed for the boys but as a substitute they use peanut butter the average being 100 lbs. a quarter for from 40 to 41 boys. I consider peanut butter a very poor substitute for butter and that this quantity is insufficient. I find also that there is a scarcity in other rich foods and I suggested to Mr. Spackman that he increase the amount of beans used as food to at least three times the quantity which is being used at present.

With regard to meat the school has been handicapped until recently owing to the fact that in order to buy meat at all economically the week's supply has been bought at one time and there is no proper refrigerator to keep it in and even if there was bringing it up on the boat in small quantities seved up in sacks the meat is tainted before they get it. Mr. Spackman assured me, however, that now there are two cold storage plants handling meat at Alert Bay he has suggested to his Church Committee at Winnipeg that he be allowed to buy the meat locally which would allow more choice as to what they purchase and also allow a little better quality of meat. The quantity for the boys school has been insufficient. Had all the meat been in good order which arrived it would have been much more nearly a sufficient quantity than it has been under the present conditions.

The boys at the school look healthy and
look to be well fed, but during the last year there has been an unusual amount of illness and I talked this matter over with the principal to see if he did not think that it was on account of the not having enough fats. It was pointed out to him that in their native habitat Indians live on more or less oily foods, they use large quantities of fish and use very largely fish oils and also eat a great many of the hair seals which are very fat indeed. I found at the school that there was a very small quantity of fish on the diet list. It must be admitted however that at times it is difficult to get fresh fish, but it would appear from the quantity that would be used there that an arrangement might be made to get a good weekly allowance.

I found also that the allowance of sugar was only 4 lb. a day for the boys in the school and I think that this should at least be doubled. I suggested to the principal that if he would use more beans and would buy mess pork in barrels and cook it with the beans that it would help out materially with the fats and would not increase the cost of their living as they would make up for it in other ways.

I also took up the matter of the diet with the principal so far as the Girls' Home is concerned and I found that a much more liberal allowance had been made for the girls than for the boys. There, as in the boys school, no butter was allowed for the girls but the amount of peanut butter per capita was larger but still insufficient to keep the girls in good growing condition. Also at this institution there was found a scarcity of vegetables as they were limited to what they grow in their garden with the exception of potatoes.

To my mind, the great difficulty exists in the fact that these schools and their diet are controlled very largely by a committee at Winnipeg who have to deal with a large number of schools and apparently know nothing whatever about climatic conditions and what is best for this particular place, and the principal informs me that he has taken up this matter of the scarcity of fats with them but they have done nothing to remedy it. A copy of this report is being given to the Principal for his guidance and it is to be hoped that steps will be taken to make the school in every way as efficient as it might be.

The agent has been for two years past pressing the need of a new school building which is as much needed or perhaps more so than a change in the diet at the schools.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of June 28th (No. 156-0-1) relative to the question of a "better balanced diet" for the pupils at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, and to inform you in reply that this important matter has been receiving the very careful attention of our Society throughout the past year. It has formed the subject of some correspondence with the Principal, and was also given careful consideration by me at the time of my last visit to this institution. It will, of course, promptly receive the further consideration which you suggest, but there are certain factors which enter into this particular case which may not have been communicated to you, and to which I think it well to direct your attention.

1. In the first place I should like to state that the only items of food about which there has been any question of an inadequate quantity being furnished are butter and sugar. On referring to my report to our Commission, on my visit to this School in August of last year, I find special reference made to these two items. I also find that provision was made for an increase in the quantity of sugar which was to be allowed, and the provision thus made has been carefully adhered to.

The question of an increase in the supply of butter has also been considered, but owing to the lack of sufficient funds our Society has not been able to sanction the full amount which the School management have requested. They have always furnished, however, the amount fixed by schedule for all of the schools under their control, and this, it was felt, along with the quantities of syrup, peanut butter, etc., provided, was sufficient to meet the school's need.
2. In the second place, I beg to state that as practically no complaints have been made by any of the other Schools under our Society's control about a shortage of either butter or sugar, our Commission have been puzzled to know why any such should have reached your Department with regard to the Alert Bay School. The only conclusion they have, so far, been able to reach in this matter is that your local representatives namely, Mr. Indian Agent Halliday and Mr. Inspector Cairns have not furnished the Principal of the Alert Bay School with all the support and confidence which they could reasonably be expected to give. In support of this conclusion I may state that Mr. Inspector Cairns before he left the School at the time of his last visit informed the Principal that his report on the food would show that it was "Good in quality, Sufficient in quantity, Recommend more fats". On the 8th of June Mr. Indian Agent Halliday, accompanied by his Stenographer, presented himself at the School and stated that he had received orders from your Department to investigate food matters. When leaving the School after making his investigation he took away with him all the food requisitions for the three quarters of this year.

The Principal having placed the above facts side by side has come to the conclusion that the Inspector must have altered the tenor of his report before despatching the same to your Department, and is at a loss to know why he should have done so. He is of the opinion that this must have been done at the request of the Indian Agent but as no certain proof that such is the case. If the Inspector changed his report at the suggestion of Mr. Indian Agent Halliday who never uttered a complaint to the Principal personally, nor ever visited the School to examine the food for himself, then the conclusion which our Commission have reached that the Principal has not been receiving the support and confidence of your local representatives, appears to me to be well founded, and I hope that you may take the necessary steps to alter this condition of affairs.

I should further like to point out that in Mr. Indian Agent Halliday's report to you - dated June 11th - on his investigation of the food supply at the Alert Bay School, he has made certain statements which do not harmonize with the facts.

1. He states, for instance, with regard to the diet, that he found a much more liberal allowance had been made for the girls at the Girls' Home, than for the boys.

2. He also states that the Principal informed him that he had taken up with the Commission the matter of the scarcity of foods but that the Commission had done nothing to remedy it.

With regard to the first of these I can assure you that it is not true. With regard to the second the Principal declares that it is an "absolute exaggeration".
I regret Sir, that I have felt it necessary to write at such length, but the importance of the question raised seemed to me to demand the information which this letter will lay before you. When you have read the same I shall be obliged if you will (1) instruct your local representatives to furnish the Principal of this School with all the assistance they could reasonably be expected to render, (2) to refrain from incorporating in their reports statements - which are not accurate, and (3) request Mr. Indian Agent Halliday to return to the Principal the requisitions which he took away. He is at liberty to examine the requisitions and even to make copies of them, but I consider that he exceeded his powers when he removed the same from the custodianship of the Principal.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Comley, Missionary-in-charge of Alert Bay has been given the position of Acting Principal for the month of December. On January 1st of next year Mr. F. Earl Anfield, who is at present on the staff of St. George's School, Lytton, B.C., will relieve Mr. Comley from any further responsibility in connection with the Schools by taking charge in the capacity of Acting Principal. He will hold this position until an Ordained man has been found to take over the Principalship.

With regard to Mr. Anfield's qualifications, I beg to submit the following information contained in a letter he had addressed to me on Nov. 1st:-

"I am 29 years of age, born and educated in England, where I attended the William Ellis College; teacher-trained in London, Eng., and Ontario, and have close on seven years experience in teaching, three of which were as Principal of the Provincial Reformatory, one as Principal of the Fort George Public School, and the remainder here at Lytton. Have been Senior Leader at the Y.M.C.A. Boys' Camp for Vancouver, for the past six years, where I gained an intimate knowledge of boyology outside the schoolroom. Am also experienced in physical culture, and have a working knowledge of medicine and nursing having nursed the boys here through severe epidemics of..."
smallpox, scarlet fever, measles, and other ailments.

As far as Indian education here is concerned, I have built the school up to Entrance standard, and passed the first children ever to enter High School from Lytton. But I am not too keen on much advanced education for them, and I devote much time to the teaching of practical agriculture and hygiene, which subjects I consider to be fundamentally important for Indians; the first to enable them to compete with the whites and thus make a living; and the second to enable them to live as we have decided they must live.

Health is all important and I have tried by every means to teach the children here its real value. We have an organized Health Club, with weight charts, etc., and that we have been partly successful is shown by an increase in weight of 1500 lb. among 100 children in the past school year, with another increase of from nothing to 100 qt. of whole milk drunk per day, and the Indian as a class does not like milk as a beverage.
