"The Alert Bay Thunderbird"....A Review of Events at the Alert Bay Indian Residential Schools and the Surrounding Mission

A RETROSPECT AND A PEEP INTO THE FUTURE - 1894 - 1925.

It was in 1867 that the first organized attempt to bring the Gospel of the Good Shepherd to the Indian people of this part of the Coast was undertaken by the Church of England. In that year the Rev. A.J. Hall, C.M.S. Missionary, arrived at Fort Rupert and started the first mission. A year later he moved his headquarters to Alert Bay on Cormorant Island, off the north-east coast of Vancouver Island, where in the face of tremendous odds, the Good Word found fertile soil in the hearts of many.

Six years later the first Boys' School was opened by Mr. A.W. Corker, who was also on the C.M.S. Staff. The School commenced with seven boys, but within a few days all but one had run away. In spite of this discouragement and in the face of terrific opposition on the part of the Indians as a whole, the School steadily grew and prospered. The school reserve consisted of heavily timbered land, and technical education was at first of necessity confined to land clearing and carpentry. Mr. and Mrs. Corker were the only members of the staff for some time, and for many years Mr. Corker also did all the medical work of the district. It was in 1867 that the first Trades Instructor was appointed in the person of Mr. W.M. Halliday, now our respected Indian Agent for the district.

In 1905 it was found necessary to enlarge the School. The roof was therefore raised and a new dormitory added. The capacity is now for 40 boys, though 43 are in residence at present.

The Girls' Home was opened as a Diocesan School in July, 1912, with the Misses Nixon and Neville in charge. This was an independent school with a capacity for 35 girls.

In 1913, Mr. Corker, who had been ordained in the meantime, took charge of the Mission at Alert Bay. For nearly seven years he controlled both schools and parish. In 1920, however, he resigned his position as Principal and confined himself entirely to the Parish of Christchurch. Mr. V.S. Lord was appointed Principal, and Mr. J. H. was followed by Rev. F.S. Spackman, who arrived from the Diocese of Saskatchewan to take charge. He remained until June 1927, when the present incumbent arrived. In 1922 the Schools were combined under the management and control of the M.S.O.C.

During these long years the names of 368 boys and 156 girls have appeared on the school registers of admission. What a tribute to those workers of early days who laid a foundation sure and strong on which could be raised such a work for God. Up and down this coast, from Cape Mudge in the South to the Naas River in the North are scattered the graduates of these schools. They settled down in their villages, in many cases, built good homes for themselves, and in many cases, we have these ex-pupils' children in residence in the Schools today.
And what of the results - Considering the difficulties to be faced; the sweeping change of environment that school life must mean for the Indian child; the language handicap; the tremendous urge of native customs - we can indeed humbly thank God for a great work well done, and we can thank Him too for the lives of consecrated and devoted workers who pioneered the way. We reap where they have sown, and they sowed thickly of the Love of God to men.

The work goes on in the Strength and with the Help of the Master. Though not faced with the dangers of the early days, yet there are difficulties yet; and we need all the help from above; all the prayers of the faithful; and sympathy and understanding, to carry on Christ's work in the way that He would have it go.

Our buildings, worn with time and wracked with storm are fast approaching their latter days; and it is our prayer and hope that this year will see the erection of a building with large capacity, that will stand as a living witness to the zeal of the Church, a monument to the pioneers of days gone by, and a tribute of co-operation and interest on the part of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Both spiritually, educationally and morally these schools have abundantly justified their existence, and with the blessing and guidance of God, much can be hoped for in the future.

Let us take this opportunity of thanking those who made the printing of this magazine possible. The Diocesan Board of the Columbia W.A., in donating a mimeograph to the Schools have performed a work, the value of which will increase as time goes on. Keeping in touch with ex-pupils; contacts with the Sunday Schools and Churches that are actively interested in our work; reports on progress to parents of children in the schools; scripture study project work; hymn sheets, and many other uses too numerous to mention, are all made possible by this splendid gift of fellow workers in a common cause - the advancement of Christ's Kingdom on earth.

We do not know just how often it will be possible to publish this little magazine. It is hoped to get it out quarterly at any rate, and later, if results justify, to make it monthly. In order to defray the cost of paper, postage and ink, we are making a charge of ten cents, and we would ask who like our effort to send us this amount when next they write. Suggestions and comment whereby we can improve will be welcomed. Please address all letters to the Principal, Residential Schools, Alert Bay, B.C.

With this school magazine we are incorporating a section dealing with other Mission activities in Alert Bay and district; including the work of the Columbia Coast Mission with its hospitals and mission ships; and the outlying stations of Village Island and Kingcome. Material for our next issue will be gladly received. We wish to urge on those engaged in Missionary effort to help us with this work. Our magazine will cover a wide field, and the Churches are keen and anxious to hear of the work.
A Page of Interest for all Our Ex-Pupils

My dear Friends:—

To all our ex-pupils, whether you left last year, ten, twenty or more years ago, do we extend greetings and best wishes with the hope that in this magazine of ours you will find much to help and encourage you in the battle of life; that in its pages you may find news of fellow pupils of your day in school; and that you may be linked up with us in our work for the present generation now in the Schools.

Too often alas, is it said, that after the Schools have trained and educated our Indian children, they leave and have no further link with the place that has been home to them, often for many years; the place in which they have been taught to know and love Jesus Christ to lead a Christian and a godly life; and then return to their homes and villages to lead out and live out those lives in Service to the Master and their fellow men.

Dear Friends, do not think that school days are over. Do not think that you are no longer linked with us—for you are still pupils—older perhaps, but yet in training. Here the ground work was laid; the foundation put in—though remember that the strength and stability of that foundation depend greatly on the application paid to your teaching whilst in school—and then you left the small school of training for the bigger school of life. It was the Master Himself who said, "Go ye into all the World, and preach the Gospel to every Creature."—So you too were sent forth equipped with all the armour we could give you—to preach the Gospel—to show it to others by your lives—to live out in the world the teaching of Christ received here in the Schools. Just a continuation of School, isn't it? With the same help waiting there as helped you here—the Spirit of Christ still seeking to help and guide you if you will let Him. Have you?

We know by record and report that many have; that numbers have gone forth from here and have led lives that are creditable both to themselves and their School—for we see it right here in the children; sons and daughters of old pupils of the Schools—God bless you for your lives so freely given to His service, for your children shall rise up and call you blessed. May you go on from strength to strength, sure in His trust and loyal to His cause.

And to those of you who feel that you have not got all out of school that you hoped for; to those who found the going rough and the way hard; and to those few, if any there be, who thought it better and easier to paddle their own canoes, to go their own way—to you all we have a message; remember, Christ in His love is always there to help—He longs for you to try and walk His way—the path of lowly Service—not always the easiest or the best paying from the worldly point of view, but certainly the best from every other. My friend, your School and all it stands for, is still willing to be your guard and guide—it watches patiently, prays daily that in God's good time you will turn to Him as you leaned on Him here in school—that you will see that His way is best—and that you will go forward for Him and with Him.
When on earth, Christ told us not to hide our light under a bushel, but to let it. So shine before men that they may see your good works." Like St. Paul, "Let us not be weary in well doing, but let us run with patience the race that is set before us." Let us do some active work for the Master. There is a crying need among our Indian people for more Missionaries. Are you doing your share - you who were sent forth to preach the gospel? Every boy and girl sent forth from these Schools is a Missionary, whether they will it or not, either for good or for evil.

Go to work, my friends, and help the cause of Christ. Your people need you, and they would sooner hear you than hear us. Are you now teaching the Word of God; taking your share and part in Church life seeking new sheep for His flock; and taking every opportunity of helping His work to progress? If you are not, may we not urge you now to at once make a start.

At this coming Easter tide, let us consecrate ourselves anew to the Risen Christ, to go forward in His strength to do the task that He has set for our accomplishment, trusting in His help and relying on His word, "Lo, I am with you always, even unto the end of the World."

Very sincerely your friend,

[Signature]
Principal.

Notes on Ex-Pupils of the Schools.

We were glad to have a visit last summer from Paul Mercer, a graduate of 1902. Paul's two boys are both in the school now and doing well. It is a pleasure for us to hear that Paul is a strong worker for the Church in his village on the Naas River.

George Luther, one of the earliest of our graduates still preaches at the teacher's desk in the Alert Bay Indian Day School. He also both preaches and teaches in Christ's Church and is a power for good among his people.

Nellie Hamilton, now Mrs. Reggie Cook, is the proud mother of a fine baby boy. The little man was baptised in our Church recently.

We regret to say that Caleb Starr of Bella Bella, is confined to the Hospital there with lung trouble. We trust and pray that he will be soon restored to health and strength again. He writes often to the school, and we wish that some of his old friends would write to him.

Elizabeth Mason, a graduate of 1927, was the winner of a medal from the Department of Indian Affairs for her essay on Confederation. We regret that we have not a copy of this essay for publication.

Simon Brown, that smiling youth from Klemtu, continues to make good progress in health, and we hope that he will soon be his old self again.

We would like news items from ex-pupils for our next issue. Send them along.
SCHOOL NOTES OF INTEREST TO ALL

Great advances are shortly to be made in land clearing when, through the kindness of the Indian Department, nearly thirty acres are to be brought under cultivation for pasture and farming land. This land will be most welcome in view of the possibility of an early increase in pupilage for the long looked for new school.

Our cows are all under regular test for T.B., and we are glad to say that Drs. Frank and Thompson found the animals all clear of the dreaded disease.

Manual Training. This most essential subject for boys was re-started in the spring of 1927, and though handicapped a little by lack of sufficient tools, the boys are making remarkable progress. They have turned out paddles, stop-ladders, wheelbarrows, and many other useful things, as well as making all the bench equipment for their shop. We are going to exhibit this fall at the Exhibitions, and try and wrest some of the honours from our good friends at Coquilletza. We hope to start basketry for the younger boys and girls shortly.

Sport.

Thanks to our good friend, Dr. Mandy, we have two complete sets of football uniforms, one red and white, and the other blue and brown. The boys enjoy football very much and we usually have at least two organized games each week. Contrary to usual practice, these youngsters play football as a summer game instead of during the winter, and will go through a gruelling game on the hottest days in summer. The girls are now taking up basketball, whilst the boys enjoy volleyball.

Cadet.

For the second year in succession the Cadets of this School won the I.O.D.E. Challenge Shield for the best Indian Cadet Corps in the Province. The boys are very keen on their work and thoroughly enjoy it. Great credit is due to Rev. F.S. Spackman, who in his time here as Principal, made such success possible.

The Senior Rifle team is now competing in the Dom. of Canada Miniature Range Championship. In the first month of the shoot, they averaged 92% and we hope to do better yet before we are finished. Peter Nensloos won a special medal for shooting last year. Well done.

The boys go to the Parish Hall for Physical Training every Tuesday evening. They play organized games, and are now taking up Badminton. Some of them show promise of becoming excellent players.

The Girls go to drill every Monday afternoon with their teacher, Mrs. I.D. Woods. They also enjoy it immensely.

W.A. Activities. We are proud of the fact that all our Girls are in the W.A., the senior ones belonging to the Girls' Br., and the Juniors to the Little Helpers. Wonderful, though secret plans are being made now for the Bazaar already, and needles ply busily through the meetings.
School Notes. (Cont'd)

Schoolrooms. Both the Girls' and Boys' schools won honours at the Provincial Exhibitions last fall, when they took first prizes in art and writing. Part of this collection was composed of a remarkable set of Indian Designs, which attracted very favourable attention.

The boys are now rejoicing in a fine new schoolroom built by the Indian Department last summer. The building is really the Manual Training shop for the new school, but will be used as a classroom until we move into our new home.

We re-print herewith the prize essay of Peter Neasloss, which won a medal and a special honourable mention from Ottawa in connection with the subject of "Confederation". Let us also take this opportunity of extending our congratulations to Minnie Wesley and her school at Coquileetza, for securing the first place in the Dominion.

"CONFEDERATION"...Peter Neasloss, Grade VII.

Years before Confederation took place, Lord Durham in his famous report, had advised a union to unite the British North American Provinces under one main Governor.

Upper and Lower Canada had their own Prime Ministers, one for the British and one for the French; who helped to guide each other's part. This the people did not like. Although one part had more population than the other, they only allowed equal representation. The people thought they should have representation by population, and so became dissatisfied. The country came to a state of deadlock.

The great men such as Sir. John A. Macdonald and George Brown of Upper Canada, Sir. George E. Cartier of Lower Canada, Sir. Leonard Tilley of New Brunswick, and Sir. Charles Tupper of Nova Scotia and several great men met at Charlottetown in September, 1864 to discuss what was best to be done for their country; the following month, thirty-three delegates together with E.P. Tache as their Chairman met again at Quebec; here they drew a bill and decided on a federal union. The conference had lasted for eighteen days, a result of seventy-two resolutions.

In 1866 there was trouble on the American border which made the people realise that they must have a Union.

In 1866 thirty-three delegates now known as the Fathers of Confederation went to London, England, with Macdonald as their leader.

On March 29th, 1867, the Bill was stamped and signed by Queen Victoria which is now known as the British North America Act, which formed Upper Canada, (now Quebec,) and Lower Canada, (now Ontario), New Brunswick and Nova Scotia into the Dominion of Canada.
The Imperial Government appoints the Governor General as the representative of the Sovereign.

Since Confederation each Province is allowed to have representation by population. Quebec is used as a base, who is allowed sixty-five representatives in the House of Commons.

Lord Monck was the first Governor General of the Dominion of Canada, and John A. Macdonald was Prime Minister. Today Lord Willingdon is the Governor General and Mackenzie-King is the Prime Minister.

Queen Victoria chose Ottawa to be the seat of government. On May 22nd, the Queen proclaimed July 1st to be set aside each year to be known as Dominion Day, to be kept for a great national holiday. This July 1st will be the Diamond Jubilee of Confederation.

By 1870 Manitoba, in 1871 British Columbia, and in 1873 Prince Edward Island had joined the Dominion. In 1905 Alberta and Saskatchewan formed a part of the Union. Newfoundland alone stayed out.

Now Canada is a great Dominion stretching from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean, and has made great progress ever since. She has a great railroad system from the Atlantic to the Pacific. She has wonderful educational systems. She is one of the leading countries of the world in her wheat growing, lumbering, mining and fishing.

Essay... "My Desk"... Frank Wilson, Grade 11, Sr.

My desk is made of wood which used to be a tree. A man cut me down and cut my branches off. I was so long that the man carved me in half. He then took me to the big mill, where the people sawed me into pieces, which they called lumber. After that, they made me smooth and I was put into a big pile to dry. A man then bought me and took me home and cut me into smaller pieces to form a nice little desk. Then when I was a desk, they polished me to make me look good so that somebody would buy me, and now I am in the Indian Residential School having a fine time with the boys who write on me.

IN MEMORIAM

It was with real sorrow that we at the Schools learned of the passing of Dr. J.C. Spencer of Bella Bella B.C., for many years United Church missionary at that centre. Both to his people, Indian and white, his family, and his Church do we extend our deepest sympathy. Dr. Spencer did a splendid work for the Indian people of the coast, and it is our prayer that God will raise up another great man to take his place among the Indian people at Bella Bella. For the work to go on to bigger and even greater things would be the greatest memorial one could give the late Missionary, and the one that he would choose.
We were pleased to receive a visit from the Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C., Dr. Westgate, with his genial smile and happy way won the hearts of all the children. Whilst here, Dr. Westgate gave an illustrated lecture on his Missionary experiences in Africa during the war. Very kindly, too, he showed and explained a set of M.S.C.C. slides to the Girls of the School, they unfortunately being down with epidemic measles at the time.

Other visitors during the year included Mr. R.H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, Mrs. Ferraboe, Dominion President of the N.A., Miss Dalton, on her way to India, Archdeacon Heathcote of Vancouver, Rev. and Mrs. Redman of the United Church, Rev. Robt. Connell of Victoria, and a number of local friends interested in our work.

His Lordship, the Bishop of Columbia, administered the rite of Confirmation to a class of boys and girls from the Schools last year. Those confirmed were Annie Williams, Gertie Hinchliffe, Rhoda Cook, Pauline Adams and Alice Johnson in the Girls' Home, and Jack Scow, Robert Mountain, Ernest Mason, Simon Hopkins, Mark White and Billy Joseph in the Boys' School.

Our School dining rooms now look very nice with their snowy white tablecloths and china dishes and you would hardly believe how few dishes the children break or how few bad spills occur on the cloths. We feel that they appreciate our efforts to make school life as 'homey' as possible.

It is often stated that institutional life at its best is not a very good substitute for the home (however humble it might be) in the upbringing of a child. We must bear in mind however that the Indian is a gregarious type and seems to take kindly to the mass activities of a large school—a relic perhaps of the community house custom or bygone days—Perhaps in the not far distant future the Church and the Indian Department might design a school on the 'cottage plan' at one of the new centres. It would be an experiment well worth watching from the viewpoint of modern child welfare ideas.

An unnamed friend donated a beautiful silver shield to be competed for monthly, the winner to be the best all round boy in the School. Keen competition and strenuous effort has won the Shield for the following boys this school year: August, Ernest Mason; September, Jack Scow; October, Peter Kendall; November, Gordon Reid; December, Ernest Mason; January, Fred Cook; February, Peter Kendall and Ernest Logan (tie). My Dear Friends:

The great thing in this "Adoption Scheme" of our Missionary Society from the point of view of the Schools is the linking up of the work in our Indian Missions with that carried on in the Parish life of the country. We like to feel that children all over the country are thinking of us, praying for our little ones, and helping to make the work of these Schools possible through generous financial assistance. We have ever so many children on our lists now, although there is room for more, and I think it would be so nice if some of you would try and influence others to take on the active support of some Indian child from this centre. We appeal especially to the Parishes of the big cities where often little is known of the Indian of this day, and where often the children have never seen an Indian child at all. It will help you to understand them by having one to care for, and to pray for; for we do need to know and understand our Indian people. The potentiality for good in them is tremendous, but it needs sympathetic understanding and careful guidance, so that in time, blessed by God and supported by His people, the Indian people of Canada may become a power for good in this great Canada of ours.

The Beaver........Annie Seevitt, Grade Jr. 4.

I am a little beaver and I am not lazy like some other animals. I build my house myself, nobody helps me. I cut trees down every autumn, as I have to cut trees down for the winter time. When I get the tree down, I run away to my house for a while because I am afraid the wildcat might eat me. Then I go back to work again and cut the tree into short pieces. I pull them into my dam and if there are any holes in it I put some sticks and stones and mud on it. I make a tunnel through it for the pantry so that we do not have to swim when I go out to work.

I have a little son and he thought there was no work to do and one night he came with me to the forest and cut a tree down. When it was nearly done, I told him to run away to our house to hide himself. Then we went back to work and we took it home.

When my son and I were working we saw a man. I told him to hide himself and the man tried to shoot me but didn't get me. I went to hide myself as I was badly wounded in the hind legs. I told my son to be very careful for the men will shoot him. One day he ran away from me and he never came back. I think he had some friends but where he had gone I did not know. Now I have a little daughter.

St. Valentine.............George Alfred, Grade V.

St. Valentine was a Bishop. The people liked him very much because he was so kind to everybody. He fed the hungry, clothed the poor, and did everything he could that was good. He soon became very old and could not go about to teach the people about God, but this did not stop his good work for he sent messages to his friends. The people who did not like St. Valentine got very angry with him, and put him in chains and threw him in prison because they were jealous of him for his goodness. In the prison he was very much ill-treated and there he died. When the people became good, they felt very sorry for what they had done so they said, "Weep for our wickedness, and we will keep in memory his birthday," and we have been keeping it ever since.

THE ALERT BAY MISSION

A Message from the Rector

"Come ye yourselves apart, and rest awhile." One day in the hurry and bustle of life our Lord addressed these words to His followers. The reason we are told was "That there were many coming and going, and they had no leisure." One of the complaints of modern life is that there is so much coming and going - so much rush and turmoil - that we have no leisure to think.

Many a modern man and woman longs for a desert place to rest awhile. What was to be the occupation of the disciples during this time of rest? I am sure that the correct answer is hard work. Probably the hardest task we do, is when we really concentrate on a certain subject with all the faculties God has given us. If you think it is not hard work, try it. We flit from one subject to another, because it is so easy to obtain a smattering of things today. The Radio, the modern newspaper and popular magazine enable us to do this without much hard work, for they give popular knowledge in a predigested form, and we are all so busy that we prefer it that way, rather than do any research work ourselves. We want enough knowledge to pass examinations of our fellow men and women, or the school Inspector.

To give two practical examples of what I mean - I was speaking the other day to an old Indian pupil and he gave me a long treatise on the Atwater-Kent system of ignition which he had recently installed on his boat engine. He described some of the advantages of the new system over the old, and I realised that it was time I endeavoured to learn something about this system of ignition in order that I might pass the examination he was giving me. The other example concerns the children who are growing up in Alert Bay. I visited a school recently during a lesson on Canadian History, and I was watching the faces of the scholars to try and discover who and how many were really interested. If they read this and I misjudge them, I apologise. But judging from the interest displayed in the faces, only a very few were really interested. Why not?

The great names in Canadian History were just names, no more. The boys and girls were not thrilled with the experiences of the early pioneers in this land. They were willing to try and learn enough to pass examinations. History to them was like the Atwater-Kent system of ignition to me. Yet we study history and especially the history of our own land, that we may be thrilled and try in our small way to be worthy of such an inheritance.

How can we who aim to be teachers really make a subject live, so that we rouse attention and interest? The men and women Jesus called to Him, in order that they might be first disciples and afterward teachers are called to "Come apart, and rest awhile"; to concentrate and learn. The greatest Teacher realised that men and women are very much like "wells"; in a time of drought, they soon go dry - Unless there is a spring in the well in August our water supply upon variations. A well can only give out according to what goes in. Men and women have to be constantly giving out soon become "well without water."

Jesus told the woman of Samaria that He was the source of Living Water, and "Whoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him, shall never thirst, but the water that I shall give him, shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life." The woman naturally answered, "Sir, give me this water." When Jesus called the disciples to "Come apart in a desert place" He saw there was a danger
of the wells in the disciples becoming dry. They were giving out day by day in service to mankind, and many of their nights were spent on the Lake providing food for themselves and families. Hence, Jesus said, "Come and replenish, so that you may have more to give. If I am asked to give the meaning of Lent, I do not know a better answer than that; it is a time for parents to come apart so they may have something more than 'bread alone' to give to their children. It is a time of replenishment for all of us, so that we may have something worthwhile to give to those who are spiritually hungry and thirsty.

Jesus, before He began His earthly ministry, spent a certain time in a desert place apart. St. Paul tells us his desert was Arabia where he was not taught by men but by God; he learned "The Master's Secret". Then, if you read the soul stirring message of Amos in the Old Testament, you will realise that he spent a long time as a herdsman and cultivating fruit before he was able to say, "Lo, He that formed the mountains, and createth the wind, and declareth unto men His thoughts, that maketh the morning darkness, and treadeth upon the high places of the earth, the Lord, the God of Hosts is His Name."

Furthermore the great Psalms that haunt us were written in the desert of captivity. St. John banished to the island of Patmos, sent out his message, not only to the Churches in Asia Minor, but to the Churches in the world today.

"Come apart" - It may be the hardest work you have ever done. I am sure the first disciples found it harder than toiling all night, dragging a heavy net and catching nothing; but they gained a rich experience that they share with us today. They were no longer wells without water, but men who had seen God face to face.

Don't be satisfied with just enough knowledge, and Bible knowledge too, to pass examinations but endeavour so to know a book, or some character that will reveal to you "The Master's Secret" - Then in the dark days of life, as well as in the bright ones, you will not only have enough "Living Water" for your own personal needs, but directed by the Master, minister to the thirst of others.

"The Kwawkewlth Agency"....W.M.Halliday.

There is an old saying that, "An old man talks of the past, a young man talks of the present, and the dreamer or the fool talks of the future."

I have been asked by the Principal of the Alert Bay Residential Schools, to write a short article on the Indians and the work of the Kwawkewlth Agency; and to write this article fairly it must partake of all three of the above mentioned heads. It is necessary to speak of the past and the present, and in justice to the Department of Indian Affairs and those associated with them in their work, also to go into the realms of the future.

It has been my lot to have been intimately associated with the Indian and Indian work for the past thirty-four years, over six years of which was as Trade Instructor in the Industrial School, and twenty-two years as Indian Agent, in which time many changes have taken place in the Indians, as well as much development of the country round about.

The Kwawkewlth Indian Agency embraces about Thirty Thousand square miles, and while there are many portions of this agency where there are no Indians living, still they have isolated reserves scattered here and there throughout the whole district. Thirty-four years ago when I first came to this part of the country I lived at Kingcome for about three years, where the nearest neighbours were the Tsawataineuk Indians, about two hundred and thirty in number. This band is composed of four subdivisions, the Tsawataineuk, Ahnhamun, Kwa'wakwainueuk, and Klwikswataneuk Bands. When I first came amongst them they had a very great distrust of the white man, and the white man's ways, and were at all desirous of having white neighbours live amongst them. This at first led to considerable friction but gradually they themselves recognised that the advent of the white man was for their betterment. During the summer months they wore very little clothing and lived very uncivilized lives. Today their men and women are well dressed in the very best of modern clothing, silk stockings for the ladies, patent leather shoes for the young men, and everything else to correspond with it. Their houses at that time were large barn-like structures, made entirely of split cedar boards and all the cracks left open, and anything but comfortable. Today they have very comfortable cottages, linoleum on the floors, gramophones, pianos and all the modern appliances, and can talk very intelligently on many subjects.

The Nimpkish Indians living at Alert Bay possibly have had better opportunity than any of the other Indians, as Alert Bay has not only been the educational centre for the Agency, but has also been the religious centre, as the Anglican Church have their headquarters here, and the schools are under their active management. Formerly the village of Alert Bay was principally noted for its totem poles, but many of these have been removed, some in Stanley Park in Vancouver, one I believe in Toronto, and others scattered here and there throughout Canada. Newer ones have taken their places, but not in the village itself, but are now being erected as monuments in the cemetery.

In the Southern part of the Agency, at Cape Mudge, they have an entirely modern village. Formerly the Cape Mudge (or Wewaikai Indians as they should properly be called) were a very dissolute lot, and bore a very bad reputation. Very largely through the instrument-
ation of one man, Chief Billy Assu, this village is now absolutely modern, and they have a very fine type of young men. They have a water system, and electric light plant, own two donkey engines, and the greater number of them own their own seine boats or other fishing boats and are practically independent.

The Wewaiaikum or Campbell River Indians have been a little slower in development, and unfortunately have been placed too near the scene of their great temptation - strong drink, but this is gradually being overcome, and they are now living in comfortable modern homes, each with a garden around it and several of them owning their own automobiles, and all of them owning their own fishing gear.

On the west coast of Vancouver Island the Kostemo and the Quatsino Indians are not very progressive. About twenty-five years ago their young men used to go out on the sealing schooners. Two schooners were lost with all hands, which left the tribe in rather a bad way, the result being that their women married and drifted away to other places, and they have very sadly decreased in numbers. The same may be said of the Newitti Band living at Hope Island where they have a very large reserve. The Nakwakto Indians living at Blunden Harbour and the Kwashola living at Smith Inlet, have not the same advancement as those living nearer by. The village of the Manalilikulla Band at Village Island is exceptionally well kept, while the two villages of Tsataisnukomi or New Vancouver, the home of the Tanakteuk Indians and Karlukwees, the home of the Kinawtsis and Matilpi Bands are beautifully situated and fairly well looked after. During the past ten years the old houses have nearly all been removed and modern cottages built in their place.

In the advancement that has taken place a great deal of credit is due to Missionary enterprise. Where there has been advancement the Missionaries have first taken hold and by showing them and by teaching them, advancement has followed. In the villages already mentioned where progress has been slow there has been little if any missionary work done. There has always been a very strong friendly feeling of co-operation between the various Missionary Societies and the Department of Indian Affairs, and the Department has always been very generous with financial help.

It has been decided that in the very near future, a large and suitable building will be provided, with a capacity of approximately two hundred pupils. The School will be on the Industrial School site at Alert Bay, and will be absolutely modern and up-to-date. A contract is now being arranged for to largely increase the acreage under cultivation.

The Department is contributing liberally towards hospital and medical attention, with the result that the physical manhood and womanhood of the Indians will be largely improved, and I can feel a great deal of satisfaction that our labours among them have not been in vain. There is still room for improvement, but to quote an old saying, "The largest room in the world is the room for improvement," and this saying pertains to the whites as well as to the Indians.
ALERT INDIANS PUBLISH PAPER

ALERT BAY, March 30.—There has been much activity inside and out at the Indian Industrial schools here. A large piece of land had been cleared this year, and a contract for the clearing of a further twenty-eight acres has been given. A school magazine has just been organized. It is called "The Thunderbird." A splendidly drawn design by one of the boys is on the front cover, and the back has a conventional design by a girl from one of the girls' classes. Articles by Rev. F. Conolly and Mr. Antfield, the principal, and some contributed by the boys themselves, together with events of the past year, form some of the contents of this number. Principal's Annual Report letter to Parents and Friends:

My dear Friends:—

By the time your mail reaches you with this letter, the long looked for annual vacation of our children will have started and the youngsters will be scattered up and down this vast Pacific Coast where they will engage in one or other of the different branches of the fishing industry of our Province of British Columbia.

To them all holidays are a testing time, to try and put into practice the lessons taught during the school year. We know well that this teaching is only valuable insofar as it will be applied during the long days of holiday life; when, if used well, it will act as a ground work for the bigger life of after-school-days. But these children are still young and there lies on the shoulders of the parents and those in charge of them during the two months of holidays an important and great God-given responsibility, and one that must not be shirked or put aside. Our children must be guided, guarded and helped, both by wise counsel and by prayer, so that no harm may befall them. Keep before them always the ideals of school life; urge them to live that life at home; to keep Christ ever foremost in their lives, and then, and only then, will have the holidays been a blessing to them. Fathers and mothers, your bounden duty as parents demands that you keep an ever watchful eye on your children, especially the girls. You know the dangers of cannery life, so please "watch and pray that they enter not into temptation." They cannot do it alone, but must have your help.

The children journeyed home on Wednesday the 13th of June. Unfortunately the "cardona" was packed and it must have been a very trying journey for all concerned. We must try and arrange things better next year, but with the great changes in fishing regulations that take place this year, it was difficult to gauge the best sailing date for this year, when holiday periods have to be set at least two months ahead of the date of departure. Miss E.W. Morryman, the Vice-Principal went as escort on the trip, and her own statement, "it would have been absolutely criminal not to have sent an escort," sums up the whole situation in regard to conditions on the coast at this time of the year.

Only a few children remain at the Schools now, six girls and two boys. Three of the girls are staying in at their own request, as they do not wish to go home. Poor Indian girls—there's is truly a hard lot, isn't it? One girl and one boy have to stay in for not returning on time last year, and we do hope that there will be no further trouble in this connection. The Department is allowing two months' holiday on the condition that the children return on time, and if you wish the privilege to be continued, make it your business to see that the girls and boys return on the date set, and not a day later.

Now about new children. We have so many applications for children to come to school that we cannot possibly put them all in, until the new school is built, so please do not send any new children to the Schools unless you definite word from me to do so. I will write during July and notify the parents which children I can take. I am sorry that it will be only a very few.

Sunday, the 3rd. of June was a great day in the life of the School,

Great honour has come to our School through the splendid shooting of our Senior Team in Musketry, who in the Winter Series II. of the Dominion of Canada Rifle Association took third place in the Dominion and first among the Indian Schools of the land. Seven of the team won medals which were presented at our Annual Prizegiving Day by Mr. W.M. Halliday, Indian Agent.

We are planning on sending a large and very representative exhibit of the work of the Schools to the Provincial and Pacific Exhibitions this summer. Outside of the competitive interest for the youngsters, these exhibitions do good work in bringing before the public just what the Indian children can accomplish.

Empire Day was joyously spent by the children in a long round of sports and games. After a flag raising ceremony in the morning, the youngsters watched the Championship game. During the afternoon, nearly fifty athletic events were run off and some good times were noted. Principal interest centred around the Mile Race, which was won by Claude Morvon of Aiyansh. Our Senior Football Team, we are sorry to say, went down to defeat in the game for the Martin Cup, but we were proud to see them lose like gentlemen, and we wish them better luck next time. As the Empire Day Sports are a community effort, we had our own School Sports on June 4th, after which the Junior Football teams played for the School Championship. Points were given for all events and the athletic champions were Helen Wilson at the Girls' Home and Alfred Lack at the Boys' School.

Annual Prizegiving Day dawned with cloudless skies, and in the afternoon the children and many friends of the School met on the lawn at the Girls' Home, where prizes and honours for the year were distributed by Mr. W.M. Halliday, Indian Agent at Alert Bay, who also gave the children some good advice and friendly counsel. Singing and drill exhibitions on the part of the girls and boys featured the programme. The School Honour Shield, premier honour of the year, was won by Ernest Mason of Klenotu, whilst the equivalent prize at the Girls' Home went to Louisa Gladstone. At the Boys' School, Patsy Wilson took the prize for Manual Training, Peter Nensloss for engineering, Ernest Mason for Farming,

N., Charlie Mason, Amos Vickers, Harry Joseph, George Wake and John Hanchitt. The Prize for Scripture at the Girls' Home went to Lena Kate Shaw, which is very creditable when one knows that this girl only came to school last fall.

Health. The general health throughout the year has been good. Although we were visited with epidemic measles last fall, no serious results were apparent at the close of the term, for which we are all truly thankful. A slight touch of flu and danger of chickenpox were noticeable this spring but happily they were averted from the Schools. A study of the weight charts of the Schools is interesting indeed, showing as they do a total increase of weight from August of last year until June this year of 709 lbs. in the ten months of School life. This averages out at 9 lb. per pupil, which is highly satisfactory from a health point of view. A great deal can be done by the parents to aid in keeping good health if they will see that the children look after themselves during the holidays. Cases of skin trouble should be taken to the nurse or doctor, and any signs of more serious illness should at once be looked after. During the holidays last year, there was a serious loss of weight among the children which this year should be prevented by more care and attention, as Indian children cannot afford to lose weight.

We will be publishing our second edition of our school magazine, "The Thunderbird" during the month of July, and trust that all will like it. If any of the readers of this letter have items of interest, will they please send them in at once.

This letter will give you a fair report of our year's work. The children have, as a whole, been well-behaved, and we feel that good progress has been made. What next year will bring, we do not know; but with steady and persevering interest on the part of the children; a keen and loyal co-operation on the part of their parents and friends joined with the blessing and guidance of Almighty God and faithful work from we who are entrusted by Him with the training of the children, we may go on bravely and thankfully to do what is His Will.

Praying that God's Blessing may richly endow you all,

Your sincere friend,

The children journeyed home on Wednesday the 13th of June. Unfortunately the ardena was packed and it must have been a very trying journey for all concerned. We must try and arrange things better next year, but with the great changes in fishing regulations that take place this year, it was difficult to gauge the best sailing date for this year, when holiday periods have to be set at least two months ahead of the date of departure. Miss E.W. Berryman, the Vice-Principal went as escort on the trip, and her own statement, "it would have been absolutely criminal not to have sent an escort," sums up the whole situation in regard to conditions on the coast at this time of the year.

Only a few children remain at the Schools now, six girls and two boys. Three of the girls are staying in at their own request, as they do not wish to go home. Poor Indian girls - their's is truly a hard lot, isn't it? One girl and one boy have to stay in for not returning on time last year, and we do hope that there will be no further trouble in this connection. The Department is allowing two months holiday on the condition that the children return on time, and if you wish the privilege to be continued, make it your business to see that the girls and boys return on the date set, and not a day later.

Now about new children. We have so many applications for children to come to school that we cannot possibly put them all in, until the new school is built, so please do not send any new children to the Schools unless you definite word from me to do so. I will write during July and notify the parents which children I can take. I am sorry that it will be only a very few.

The Legend of Qunnucilla and Namugwazalas,

Namugwazalas was the first man of one of the clans of the Nimkish Tribe of Indians. He was camped on the Nimkish River just below the Lake at the time of this story. Ozulas is the name of the present site of the fishing village of the Nimkish.

This man became tired of the migratory life he was living, and wanted a permanent home, so in his mind he made a plan of the present type of Indian Community house. To build it he secured and prepared huge cedar timbers, each shaped and cut with a hand adze. He put in the huge posts and cross pieces, but he had not foreseen that he could not put up alone the huge ridge beams, and so when all was ready he found to his sorrow that he could not lift the big timbers into place. When he realized this he was very sad. He sat out on the bank of the river and could have cried had he not been a brave man. As he sat there feeling so glum, he looked across the river and saw a huge Thunderbird sitting on a large stone.

He said to the bird, "If you were only an intelligent human being, what a help you could be to me with your great strength." The Thunderbird said to him, "Why, I am human, what do you wish?" As he spoke, he lifted up the visor of the Thunderbird costume, and showed his face, the face of a man. "I wish you could help me to put up the beams on my house," said the man. "Surely," said the Thunderbird, who closed up his visor and flew up and lighted on the middle of the big beam and seized it with his enormous claws, carrying it up and placing it in position on the posts.

He then asked the man what this building was to be. Namugwazalas told him of his idea of building for himself and his people a permanent home. The Thunderbird said it was a grand idea. "I think" said he, "I will join you and together we will form a tribe." Then the brave Namugwazalas told him that he would rejoice in his company.

So the Thunderbird undressed himself of his Thunder dress, and sent it back to the heavens with these words, "Go back to your home, and take heed that you thunder not out of season. At one time only shall your voice roar forth, and that only if one of my future posterity is near to the borders of death."

This is the Legend of the Thunderbird, telling why its spreading wings adorn all totems of the Nimkish Tribe. It is still believed that when there is thunder over the Nimkish River, one of the Tribe or line of the Nimkish is in danger of death, near death, or dead.

Written by Mrs. Stephen Cook, hereditary Chieftainess of the Nimkish.

That of the Future of Indian Education.

To all who live on this far Pacific Coast who are in any way interested in Indians, whether commercially, spiritually or educationally, there must at this time be a most recurring thought. What is to be the future of the Indian Race. In Cannery stores, on fishboat, in the porch of the Church and in the Schools, and above all in the homes of the Indians themselves, this question is being asked and thought over. For a change is coming and that before many years are by. The other day I was talking with the captain of a large seine-boat passing through to Bella Bella. A fine type of Indian he was, well educated and a Christian man. His children have been pupils at these Schools for many years, and his eldest boy, a second year high school student is this fall, through the generosity of the Indian Department to enter Technical School for a three year course in machining. This captain asked me, Mr. Anfield, he said, "What are you doing to meet the changing conditions of Indian life?" I waited for him to go on. "You know, times are changing. The time was when for an Indian to be able to read a little, write a little and know how to figure, coupled with a sound religious training was enough for our people. They could hardly handle more. But life was easy for them then. They had land logging, trapping, and fishing made them rich. They could hunt all the year round, and their bodily wants were easily satisfied. But what about now. Land-logging is gone, and the trapping is scarcely worth while. And as for fishing, well, the time is not far distant when that will be gone too. And then what? What are our children to do? Are our boys to have to loaf around all the winter because they have no trade?

And another day as I waited for the mail outside the Cannery store, I heard two men talking. They were looking across the Bay to the Nimkish where could be discerned the fishing fleet catching the sockeye in tens where formerly they netted them in hundreds, nay often in thousands. "Well", one of them said, "Fishing's nearly gone" "Yep", said the other, "and what are those Indians going to do then?"

And on yet another day further up the Coast, I talked with a cannery manager, and in answer to a question of the future of the fishing industry, he gave me this answer. "The fishing industry is not done yet, but there must be changes and big ones. The purse seines must be radically cut down in number, and there must be all round increases in economy of operation. More machines in the canneries and less human labour."

Thus the story goes, and when one sorts it all out and pigeonholes the facts where they belong, one thing is plainly to be seen, and that is that the day of the Indian in fishing is nearly done, unless he can be trained to fish scientifically like his white brother. For like it or not, the Indian must face the fact that the white man is consistently beating him at his own games. More and more are the canneries putting in white crews, and with the inevitable cut in gear that must come soon, it is the Indian that will be laid off. Then in the canneries themselves, machinery will in time oust the Indian women and girls who depend on work at filling cans to help support the large families during the winter months. On the trap line, the white man is fast encroaching on preserves formerly held almost entirely by Indians, and in many cases is consistently getting more pelts per line of traps too. Not that the white is robbing any land belonging to Indians, for all trap lines are registered, but they are more and more moving in on lands not previously trapped by...
the whites. Hardly anyone living on this coast can deny that the "writing is on the wall" as affecting the fishing industry. Last year was a terrible failure, and so far this year, things are not much better, though there is promise of improvement. Too much gear is the cause of the trouble, and cut down gear means cut down man power.

And so we on the Coast are facing what the Indians of the Plains faced some years back. They had to seek new occupations and they found the best in farming, and one has only to read the Annual Report of the Indian Department to see how well many of them are doing under careful supervision on the part of the Department and through systematic training on the part of the Schools.

But here on the Coast, hemmed in by gigantic mountains, the Indians cannot turn to farming. He has not the land for one thing. Many reserves on this coast could not be farmed even with the best intentions in the world. Then too, the Coast Indian is a man of seasonal occupations. In our Schools at present, one could count on one's fingers the number of boys who will return to areas capable of being farmed successfully.

The solution seems to lie in technical training for the boys and domestic science for the girls, so that the children can be discharged from Schools, the boys with some sort of trade, and the girls with a sound knowledge of housekeeping, dressmaking, and kindred subjects. Thus by economical living, coupled with the earnings brought in from seasonal employment in the restricted fields open to them, they will be able to make an honest livelihood. Indian boys should leave school with a good knowledge of carpentry, capable of building their own homes with help in planning, buying, etc. They should also be able to make or at least repair their own and their families boots and shoes, and in cases where intelligence and aptitude warrants such help, others should receive course in machinery and electricity. Native arts, now alas almost lost, should be revived for both boys and girls, for therein lies a sure source of income, outside of the fact that such a revival would preserve to posterity arts and crafts unrivalled in their class.

This is the programme that lies ahead of these Schools, but it will need much careful study and thought, coupled with sympathetic help and above all with Divine guidance and aid to make it the success that we would have it be. We have assurance that the Department of Indian Affairs are fully willing to help and are keenly alive to the needs of the Coast Indians. So we hope for great things in our new school, though a start on this programme has been made even with the poor equipment at our disposal in these old buildings, and results so far attained augur well for the future.

W.A. NOTES

For the W.A. of Christchurch, Alert Bay, B.C., to all members of other branches who may receive this magazine greetings. No doubt, you, as we, have been resting from the usual monthly meetings, laying up; we trust renewed strength and energy for the great venture before us during the coming winter months; namely to fulfil the mission which is our as members of the Woman's Auxiliary, which is none other than helping to carry on the great work entrusted to the Church by her Divine Founder and Leader; to make disciples of all nations.

It is true that some must tarry at home by the "stuff" (1 Sam. 30:24), but they are to have their part in the great reward and to them perhaps more than to others who go to the front lines, will the great "General" say, "Well done, good and faithful servant", so the soldier of Jesus Christ must also be a servant and to each one of us is given the opportunity to prove our faithfulness, even though we cannot all be successful.

It has been said by some, perhaps by many, that the W.A. seems to be just a money-making machine. If we omit the word "just", and instead call it a "Great" money-making machine, then it will be nearer the truth, "in fact, part of the truth", but not the whole truth. In answer to this criticism, we would ask what greater honour can we have than to raise the money for carrying out the last command of our Master?

How shall those, who today are still in the darkness of ignorance and superstition hear the message which will dispel the darkness without a preacher, and how shall they preach except they be sent, and how shall they be sent without money? It has ever been the same, if we would help, we must pray, give our time, our talents, money, for the service of the King of kings.

Even in our Lord's day, money was needed for the Temple and the Synagogue services, and Jesus sitting by the treasury one day took notice of those who contributed, and He said there were those who gave and had plenty left, for they gave of their abundance, but the one particularly mentioned was a widow and she was poor, but she gave and it was money she gave. "How little", some say, "only two mites", "How much", Jesus said, "for she has cast in more than they all, for she has given all that she had."

To those who depend very largely upon sales of work for raising their funds, it has been said that such is not the ideal way of giving, but recommend direct giving as the highest form. Granted that is so, we have yet to ask that whether as a whole, we are able to give the equivalent of what is now being raised by the sale of garments and other things made by willing capable fingers, costing much thought and time, as well as money, but the former added to the latter makes a sum much larger than could otherwise be given directly. Money makes money we are told, but no does brains and ability, and those who may have little of the one, yet who using the gifts that God has so freely bestowed upon them, are able to give back to Him all that they have and in this way speed forward the work of bringing His Kingdom on earth.

"And is it uphill all the way?"

"Yes, to the very end.

But it is the mountain climbers and especially those who reach the summit that can enjoy the most perfect view and purest air. Lest we grow weary in the climb, may God inspire us with fresh vision of His sustaining Grace and Power and something of the ultimate issue of our undertaking as W.A. members."
Much might be said and has already been said regarding the W.A. as a great praying machine, and which is of course the most important side of the work as well as the most difficult, but we need to remind ourselves that by raising the funds we are thereby used by God to answer the prayer of faith. How better can we aid and encourage missionaries than by helping to provide the means to carry on?

How sad the cry, sometimes heard from some of Christ's faithful soldiers at the Front, "unless men and money are forthcoming, we shall be obliged to close down" this or that station. Shall we not then take courage and go forward with renewed zeal, praying that we may be content to labour and not to ask for any reward save that of knowing we do His Will.

K. Dibben, Pres., Senior W.A.

Columbia Coast Mission News.

Many accounts have been written of journeys made on the mission ship Columbia, and it would be hard for the writer to cover new ground, though a few impressions of the journey recently made by me might be of interest. Thanks to the courtesy of Rev. John Antle and the crew of this most useful little ship, I was privileged to journey on the northern run and to view at first hand some of diversified interests of this British Columbia coast. Leaving the Hospital Wharf at the Bay on a Saturday we proceeded to Englewood, a huge lumbering and mill centre, where the L.O., Dr. Striner spent some hours in tending to the sick. A patient was brought back to the hospital and then off to the north. First call, Hardy Bay. No, it was Fort Rupert, a deserted Hudson's Bay post. What tales that place could tell if only its broken down stone fireplaces and community house could talk. It is now an Indian winter village, but a few of the older folks were living there then we called and social calls were made on them all. Ailments peculiar to old people were described and prescribed for, and then with an A-la-Ki-asia to all we were off to Port Hardy and Hardy Bay, key centres to the pulp mills at Port Alice. Hardy Bay is growing fast and many new houses were in course of erection. The missionary of the Columbia, Rev. W. Govier takes regular services at all these places all the year round. Shushartie was the next stop, but not much life was there found, as the Cannery has been moved lock, stock and barrel down to Bone Bay near to the entrance of Knight's Inlet. After a short call at the Indian village of Nalwitti, tenanted only by an old Chief who remained as watchman, we dropped our hook, which is nautical for anchor, in the still and beautiful bay of Bull Barbour, seat of a Government Wireless Station. This is an extremely beautiful place, with an almost landlocked harbour on one side, its very stillness accentuating the thunderous roar of the vast Pacific Ocean rolling in on the other side of the small peninsula. It must be a lonely life for these men, though they seemed cheery enough, and more than one boasted of over five years at the Harbour. The loneliness must tell on them, and a change of environment might not be out of place at times.

As evening fell, so fell the fog, and all night long the strident voice of the fog horn on Pine Island boomed out its warning call to "thee in peril on the sea". We waited the next morning until nearly ten and still the fog showed no sign of lifting to me, but the Skipper's sea-wise eye or nose, I know not which, told him otherwise, and off we went in a regular pea-souper of a fog, right out into the Pacific. Sure enough after half an hour or so of running up went the fog, and we speeded up for the other side, where we tied up at Allision Harbour at the mouth of Seymour Inlet. We were now on the mainland of the Renfrew B.C. Coast, and several trips took us up small inlets and harbours, visiting in most cases empty Indian villages, or small logging settlements, where the crew knew everyone and everyone knew the crew. Large stacks of papers and magazines are given out at all these places, and to hear a little girl of nine or thereabouts ask for "A grade II book, please", followed instantly by "Where's Mr. Govier", gives one most all the information needed as to the value of such a craft as the Columbia.

On down the coast, with a short stay at Blunden Harbour, where the doctor's services were rewarded by a big basket of strawberries for the engineer, and then into the logging settlements of Wells Pass.
The beauty of some of these Inlets, with their towering mountains abutting on either shore is quite indescribable and has to be done to be appreciated. Almost a dozen calls were made at logging camps, thus giving medical protection to hundreds of men. Very little work awaited the doctor but the chance to speak with these people and to give them all some reading material or pass on the news received over the radio seemed to be a sort of health cure in itself. Regularly every hour the Columbia engineer talks over the radio-telephone to the operator at the Alert Bay station, so messages, recalls or medical advice are never very far away, so matter how mountain enclosed the boat might be. That night saw us tied in the entrance to Kingcome Inlet. It's great how one can sleep on this boat.

Seven o'clock in the morning was the zero hour for Kingcome, but several other calls had to be made first, and it was nearly noon before we got properly into the Inlet. Up to now the scenery had been wonderful, now it became grand, as the somewhat dirty Kingcome river pours its waters into the swirling tides of the Inlet.

A long time was spent at Charles Creek cannery, some seven miles below the river proper, and the doctor was a busy man if the one can judge by the number of bottles of medicine he dispensed. A long chat with Miss E.G. Westbury, the Missionary to the Kingcomes, gave one an idea of the work to be done. Hers is a noble task, and nobly done. Miss Westbury hopes to start school for the children resident at the Cannery this summer, as a building is on the site though not jacked into position yet.

Late that afternoon all hands got into the longboat whose speedy little outboard engine soon drove us up the winding river en route for the Indian village and the Hallidays ranch. The latter was reached first, and the hospitality of these good people and welcome extended to the Columbia's crew, need no eulogising here. Visits to the other ranches of the settlement were made and it was in the wee small hours that we journeyed back with Reg. Halliday down the river in pouring rain and with the night blocker than the proverbial Kilkenny cat to the safe haven of the Columbia's decks. How that man found his way down there I know not, and what conditions must be like in winter I care not to think about.

The next afternoon saw us back in Alert Bay, and my thanks go to the boys of this boat for a chance to see the work being done. It is lovely in summer, but I know somewhat of what it is in winter too, then the southeasters roar for weeks at a time. Then it is not so nice. It is an indispensible work that this boat is doing and one worthy of all the help and support that our Church can give. "Let us not be weary in well-doing."

MEMO FOR FILE:

In 1881, Rev. A. J. Hall, an Anglican missionary to the Indians, believing Alert Bay the most central locality for his work, established a mission there and erected a classroom. Day school activities commenced, and, in addition, classes were held in the evening. This work was recognized by the Government in 1882, when a grant of $12 per pupil per year was allowed for the activity. He and his wife kept a few girls in their own home, without any grant for their maintenance.

Indian Agent R. H. Pidcock, of the Kwawkewlth agency, with headquarters at Alert Bay, wrote in 1889, urging the Government to establish a vocational training centre for Indian young men at Alert Bay and that the present school reserve be secured from the Provincial Crown for the purpose. A year later, Rev. A. J. Hall asked for the establishment of a girls' boarding school. In 1891, Mr. Hall was offered a $70 per capita grant if he would provide the maintenance and educate Indian girls in a boarding school there. Mr. Hall was unable to accept this offer at that time, because of his approaching furlough to England.

In 1892 and the following year, the boys' industrial school was erected and equipped. The funds were provided by Parliament. In 1894, under the principalship of the Rev. A. W. Corker, the school was opened. Per capita grant of $130 per annum was allowed for 35 pupils. It is interesting to note that the present Indian Agent, Mr. W. M. Halliday, was appointed in 1897 as the first trades instructor.

Rev. Mr. Hall renewed his application for a girls' boarding school in 1894. He and Mrs. Hall were boarding from 5 to 10 girls in their home at that time. The Department gave assistance for the first time, and, in the following year (1895) a pupilage of 10 and a per capita grant of $60 per annum was allowed. The building was owned, of course, by the church authorities.

Boys' school was conducted, without interruption, to the present date. From 1905, however, after some difficulty in connection with supervision and because of poor enrolment generally, the girls' school was closed. The Department erected a building for the girls' boarding school in 1911. It was opened in 1912, with the Rev. Mr. Corker principal of both schools. The management of the boys' school was in the missionary society, while the girls' institution was managed by the diocesan authorities.

Future principals were as follows:

- Mr. V. S. Lord - 1921
- Rev. F. S. Spackman - 1923
- Mr. F. Earl Anfield - 1927

Dear Mr. Anfield:

I am happy to have this opportunity to convey a message to the staff and pupils and to all friends of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. Your school magazine, "The Thunderbird," is a most commendable enterprise, and I wish to express the Department's congratulations and, through this medium, to reach the Indians for whose benefit the school has been established.

To understand and appreciate the present situation, it is necessary to cast a backward glance at the first educational efforts of the Church of England in your district. In 1861, Rev. A. J. Hall, believing Alert Bay the most central locality, established a mission there and commenced a school. Classes were held both in the daytime and in the evening, and a few girls were kept by Mrs. Hall in her own home. The work was recognized by the Canadian Government in 1883 and a grant of $12 per pupil per year was given.

Improvement was gradual but continuous. In 1892, the Department commenced the erection of the Boys' Industrial School, which was opened two years later, under the principalship of the Reverend A. W. Corker. It is interesting to note that the present Indian Agent, Mr. W. M. Halliday, was the first trades instructor at the school. The Boys' School has been conducted without interruption since that date.

The Boarding School for Girls, managed by Reverend and Mrs. Hall, was assisted by the Department of Indian Affairs in 1895 - an annual grant being provided until the

work was discontinued ten years later. In 1911, Parliament provided funds for the erection of a building suitable for the maintenance and education of girls. A year later, girls were admitted and the new institution was placed under the control of Mr. Corker, Principal of the Boys' School.

The Alert Bay training centre has become an important factor in the lives of British Columbia coast Indians. Encouraged by the constant zeal of those in charge, the Dominion Government has erected one of the most modern Indian school buildings in Canada. The re-establishment of the institution has been effected at a cost of $223,000.00, and I hope you will be proud of your new school and will face the future with new confidence.

Indian educational work at Alert Bay had humble beginnings; but, all through the years, representatives of the Church of England and of the Department have striven for success, and their efforts have been supported by Indian parents. The future appears bright. New standards of efficiency can be achieved. I appeal to graduates of the school and other Indian supporters, upon whose loyalty and interest success will largely depend.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Order of Service

(1) At 2:45 p.m., the school bell shall ring, and the children of the schools advance from their stations at the old buildings, small children in front, and seniors in rear. They shall converge at front of new school, girls to right of front door, and boys to the left. Peter Neasloss, head boy of the school, and Rhoda Cook, the girls' shall carry the flags of Church and State at head of their processes. Gathered on front verandah shall be the official representatives of Church and State.

(2) Then shall follow the flag-raising ceremony. Principal shall request Mr. W. E. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner, to raise the school flag for the first time. As the flag is being raised, the Head Matron shall lead the school in the National Anthem. As soon as the flag is hoisted, the Principal shall request the Inspector Commissioner to unlock the building and to allow the pupils and their assemblies to enter therein, for the purpose of occupation, and for dedication to the Glory of God and the education of the Indian children on this campus.

(3) Mr. W. E. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner, shall then unlock the front doors, assisted by Mr. W. M. Halliday, Indian Agent, and the procession shall then enter and pass into the auditorium in the following order:

- The boys of the school, under charge of Boys' Supervisor, assisted by Senior and Junior Teachers;

Sir:

I am enclosing voucher No. 67 for $68.85 for escort expenses incurred in sending the children home from the Residential School, for which authority was given in your letter of May 8th, No. 156/0/10.

I am more or less dubious as to the advisability of these expenses in connection with an escort. Looking at it from the view of an outsider, one would say why should the Department be called on to pay these expenses in the first place. The reason advanced by the Missionary Society is a very good one, that they want to see the children safely home and without being unduly exposed to temptation on the way. On the other hand, as soon as they get home they are turned loose, and if they have not sufficient character to stand up against temptation after they arrive home, why incur the expense in seeing that they get safely home; let them have the temptation when they first leave, instead of later. However the Department in its wisdom has decided otherwise, and in all probability for the sake of public appearances the view taken is the correct one.

The Principal has written to see if the per capita grant earning pupilage cannot be increased to the full capacity of the building, namely two hundred. He states in his letter that they have made such alterations as will give another dormitory and another classroom and if permission is granted to increase from 175 to 200 they will be able to fill to capacity as soon as the holiday is over.

In view of the wonderful structure that we have there, and of the need there is for the education of the Indian children, many of whom are unable to attend day school, I would recommend that the authority be given to increase the pupilage to 200. The building is capable of accommodating really more than that; the dining room has a seating capacity of 240, and this is the place where they usually run short in all these buildings.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

Thank you for your kind letter of recent date in connection with the United Church children who are pupils of this school. I quite appreciate your feelings in the matter of religious education of these children, who will be members of the United Church when they leave the school. May I impress upon you the fact that it is not, and never will be our desire to take United Church children from the church of their fathers, though this church is administered by the Anglican Church; it has always been my endeavour to see that the children have their opportunity to worship God in the manner in which they have been brought up. On the other hand, however, we have to consider the children themselves, and the question of admitting United Church children to communion in our church is a delicate problem. What are we to do if these children demand access to the sacraments of our Church? The preparatory classes for communicants is now in progress, admission to which is entirely voluntary on the part of the girls and boys attending. Several of your United Church children are attending, and I have spoken to them privately about the relationship of their own church ties. The children are quite insistent that they wish to continue in this communicant's class, and I do not in any way feel justified in refusing them such communion. In fact I think it would be a very serious thing if we were to refuse them equal rights with their fellow pupils of the schools. Nice distinctions of inter-denominationalism are quite foreign to the Indian mind, and it would be fatal in my opinion to try and distinguish such for them. Far better for them to grow up to learn the hopes and possibilities of one great church of Christ, be it named United Church, Anglican or otherwise.

I will be grateful to you for a frank expression of your opinion on this matter, as I am quite open minded on the whole thing myself. With very kind regards and best wishes for the success of your work, believe me

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) F. Earl Anfield.
Principal.

Dear Mr. Anfield,

Your's dated Sept. 13th to hand. I am very glad you opened your heart to me in this matter. Above all else I desire that our children should become Christians. And I would not mind if they were all members of the Church of England, but under present conditions it must be that they remain members of the United Church for that is the Church working in their home town.

Now I see no reason at all why our children could not attend the preparatory or communion classes and when the time comes for Confirmation, let it be understood that they are members of the United Church of Canada, and I could send membership cards to you, and you hand them to the children. I see nothing in the Confirmation Service that would conflict with such an arrangement.

I understand that the Rev. Raley has invited a Church of England Minister to go into his School and instruct Church of England children.

With kind regards,
