Dear Mr. Barner,

I am sending you letters which passed between Mr. Anfield, Principal of the Anglican Residential School at Alert Bay and myself. They will explain themselves.

I have been dismayed reading a letter from Rev. G. A. Wilson, D.D., Supt. of Missions, Vancouver. Which letter is a report of a joint meeting of the Anglican Church and the United Church on the building of Residential Schools. A copy has no doubt been sent to you.

There are three resolutions which were adopted by the conference. The item which troubles me is No. 2, which reads thus - That each Church should recruit only from its own constituency.

To enforce this section would be to inflict upon the Indian people a great wrong. At this time when there is so much talk of Union and cooperation surely this is a backward movement, and will be misunderstood, for the Natives of this Coast make no fine distinctions. Both Churches are as one to them.

I find children coming home from the Anglican school are quite as good as those coming from our own schools, so WHY make a difference? And why send children hundreds of miles away from home when there is a good school near at hand? Of course some parents have a decided choice, but most want their children not so far away.

In case of sickness it is a real hardship upon both parents and children.

At the present time we have about twenty-five children at the Alert Bay school and about sixteen at Coqualeetza.

You will see by the enclosed letters the arrangement between Mr. Anfield is working fine.

I beg to remain yours faithfully,

(Signed) W. H. Gibson.

Dear Friends:

We hope this school year to be able to send out to you all regular news letters from St. Michael's giving you an idea of what the youngsters are doing, and at the same time to keep in touch with the parents and friends interested in our work for Indian children.

School re-opened on August 16 with an almost record opening attendance of 205 children which number has now reached the full capacity of 210. From the emptiness of holiday days to the happy laughter of the children these days is a considerable and very pleasant change, and we are glad indeed to have the children back to school and settled down for the year's work.

Generally speaking, the health of the children was reasonably good when they returned to school, though unfortunately since re-opening we have had several down with a nasty type of flu. Under the providence of God, and with good care and nursing, all are now well again, and the school infirmary practically empty. We hope it may remain so.

We had better speak a few words about fishing, the natural industry of our Indian people on the entire coast. As predicted earlier in the year, fishing has in no way approached the plentifulness it showed in 1930, and as a result many of our Indian people are going to be in hard luck this coming winter. We would at this time urge most strongly on all the parents not to send large amounts of clothes or food to their children at the school. Your children are well fed and well clothed, and apart from an occasional gift of fruit or dried fish, they do not need much more. You will need all your money to care for your own homes, so please learn to say "NO" when your children write and ask for the most unnecessary things. Of course, as long as you will send, they will keep on asking, for that is the way of children.

The latest report from the northern districts show a decrease of over 300,000 cases compared to last year's catch, mostly in the pink variety. Sockeye was fairly good, especially the Skeena, but the poor old Nass River was almost a complete failure. Prices were low all over, which has made things harder. Smiths Inlet was a failure, Rivers Inlet Fair, and Alert Bay fair. The outlook for fall fishing is only fair, though a lot of dog salmon will be put up by the salteries, with low prices all around. This condition will mean trying times for our Indian friends, but we trust that they will see the need of storing and saving in good times, so that they may have something when fish harvests are bad.

Our many friends will be extremely interested to hear the results of the Indian school competition at the Vancouver Exhibition, ten Residential Schools competing. St. Michael's won twenty-eight awards, including the grand diploma and first prize for manual training, and second for the educational exhibit. The Vancouver press spoke very highly of the work done, and we are sure that the parents who are con-
We are glad our many friends may know that this year for the first time several of our senior children have undertaken active work for the Church by becoming Sunday School teachers. Over one hundred ten of our junior children attend the parish Sunday School in Alert Bay, and nine of our senior children, Mary Martin, Agnes King, Violet Ross, Allen Newman, Richard Carpenter, Leonard Mercer, Daniel Henwood, and Freddie Cook have offered themselves as teachers, in the work of teaching the young. Such a work is a very creditable one, and we would ask the prayers of all interested in our school that these young people may in their work find a real field of service and inspiration to bigger or and greater things when their time comes to leave the school. We realise that we must get the senior children actively interested in Church work whilst at school if they are to carry on when they go home to their villages. Hence you will realise the great importance that we place on such an enterprise.

You will be interested to hear three of our children wrote the Entrance Examinations in June and we have to congratulate George Alfred of Alert Bay on making a very satisfactory pass. He will be taking High School work with us this fall.

Quite a number of children, mostly from Massett in the Queen Charlotte Islands stayed in school during the summer months of this year, and we are glad to say that they had a most pleasant time. The move to allow children to stay in school during the vacation is meeting with a great deal of favour by our Indian people, as those who stayed in during the holidays are without exception in better condition when school opens than those who went out to the canneries. The youngsters who stayed in with us this year, had a wonderfully happy time and as a result of their regular meals and plenty of sleep, that they were able to obtain at that time, are off to a flying start in the new school year. If more of our Indian friends could see the value of leaving their children in school, say every other year, there is no doubt that the health standard as well as the moral and academic would be considerably advanced. All too often, the two months holiday set them back in health to a considerable extent.

We are all now looking forward with interest to keeping St. Michael's Day at the end of this month. This day is to be a great one in our school year, as far as athletics are concerned, and our children are now busy practising for the races and other events of that day. We will give you a full report of the events of St. Michael's Day in our next newsletter.

We would like all our Indian people and parents of our children to make a real effort this year to write to their youngsters at least once a month. We encourage the children to write home regularly and provide them with paper, envelopes and stamps. Yet we do have children who do not hear from home once during the school year. This tends to make them forget the ties of home, as well as making them considerably unhappy at times. Now as most of our Indian people can either write themselves, or can get someone to write for them, there is really no excuse why the children in school should not hear from home at least once every few weeks. We would suggest if stamps cannot be afforded, that three or four families might put their letters together and send them direct to the Principal, who will see that the
We also wish to tell you that this year, any money or parcels sent for the children will be acknowledged direct from the office of the school with a school receipt form. We have found in the past that some children do not always acknowledge gifts from home, and we know how anxious parents must be if they send parcels or money to their children and then hear no word as to their arrival. If you do not get a receipt from the school inside of two weeks, please write and enquire further from the Principal.

Such a lot of our new children especially the younger ones, seem to have such bad teeth when they come to school, that when the dentist comes, all he can do is to pull a lot of them out. This is too bad, as mothers should try their best to take care of the first teeth, which are very important to the health of the children. Bad and decaying teeth such as we find in so many mouths are responsible for a lot of the sickness among the younger children. Will you not try this winter to take more care of the youngsters' teeth. Teach them to clean them with a brush, or better still clean them yourself, and then keep the brush in a proper place. The large amount of candy eaten by so many Indian children makes it absolutely necessary that they clean their teeth twice a day at least.

Wishing you all a very happy winter and praying the work of all the missions along the coast may be greatly blessed as they settle down for the winter's endeavours,

Believe me, with kind regards,

Dear Canon Gould:

"Some time ago Mr Anfield who holds the position of Acting Principal of our Society's Indian Residential School at Alert Bay, requested the Commission to have his status changed to that of Principal. He was informed at that time of the ruling of the Society that Principalships were given to men in full Orders only, and after they had been in charge of a school for some years. He was also informed that appointments to Principalships were subject to the approval of the Indian Department, who, if they approved the same, would have the appointment confirmed by an Order-in-Council.

Mr Anfield has been in charge of the Alert Bay School since January 1st. 1927, and in view of the satisfactory services he has rendered, coupled with the fact that the Rector of Alert Bay is able to discharge the duties of Chaplain to the school, the Commission agreed, at a meeting held on the 8th inst. to ask the Executive Committee M.S.C.C. to recommend to the Indian Department that his status be changed from "Acting Principal" to that of "Principal".

In taking this action the Commission did not desire it to be understood that they favoured a change in the existing policy and regulation which requires Principals to be men in full Orders. It is their opinion that the situation at Alert Bay is exceptional - (1) because of the close location of the Rector of the local parish to the school, and the happy relationship which exists between the school and the parish, and (2) because the Acting-Principal, although a Layman, has rendered such faithful and efficient services for nearly six years. They feel, therefore, that Mr Anfield is entitled to the encouragement and recognition which the change in status would afford, and they trust that their recommendation may be accepted by the Executive Committee and also by the Indian Department.

With kind regards,

Faithfully, Yours,

October 17th - 20th, 1931.

Alert Bay was honoured when, on the afternoon of Saturday October 17th, H.M.C.S. "Skeena" carrying His Honour, the Lieutenant Governor of British Columbia and suite arrived in the harbor for a four days visit to this historic settlement. Accompanying His Honour were Major H. S. Humphreys, A.D.C., and Mr. A. M. D. Fairbairn, Private Secretary.

As soon as the anchor of Canada's own warship dropped into the placid waters of the Bay, the Provincial Police boat bearing an official welcome party moved alongside and were received by Commander Brodeur of the "Skeena" and the Governor's Secretary, who escorted the party below where they were introduced to His Honour. Arrangements for the four day visit were rapidly consummated, and that evening His Honour came ashore and was entertained at the home of Mr. W. M. Halliday, Indian Agent, where a representative gathering of citizens spent a pleasant evening.

The "Skeena" was thrown open for public inspection on Sunday and a large number of residents boarded the splendid vessel on a tour of inspection.

At 2:30 P.M. Sunday the Lieutenant Governor and party came ashore and were met by the Principal of the Indian Residential School, Mr. Indian Agent Halliday, and Rev. C. K. K. Prosser, the Chaplain of the school. Arriving at the school, His Honour planted a tree in commemoration of this, his first visit to Alert Bay, and then the party proceeded into the large and spacious auditorium where the entire student body and staff, numbering over 225, rose to greet him. A short programme was carried out, the children taking part in the singing of "O Canada" and the National Anthem. In a few well-chosen words, His Honour gave a message to the children of the school, and informed them that he was giving for annual competition a medal to be presented to the pupil earning the highest marks in the Provincial Government Entrance examinations. A picturesque touch was added to the ceremony when two of the younger children carried forward a flag-draped table which was presented to His Honour as a mark of esteem and as a souvenir of this, his first visit to an Indian Residential School. The gift proved to be a beautifully inlaid chess table in five native woods, the entire work having been done by two of the boy pupils of the school in the manual training section.

Following the brief ceremony in the auditorium, the official party inspected the entire school and were then entertained by the Principal and staff at a delightfully informal tea, following which His Honour proceeded back to the "Skeena".
That evening a community service was held in the Anglican Church at which the Rector, Rev. C. K. K. Prosser and the United Church minister, Rev. W. H. Ashford, officiated. His Honour the Lieutenant Governor and A. D. C. attended this service, during which Mr. Ashford gave an inspiring address on the need of broader views and firmer faith if the destiny of Canada was to be fulfilled and this country become the home of a Christian race.

Nearly four hundred children from the settlement of Alert Bay were, through the courtesy of Commander Brodeur enabled to pay a visit of inspection to the "Skeena" on Monday afternoon, when the launches of Mr. W. M. Halliday, Indian Agent, and Mr. Harry Douglas, Fishery Inspector, were placed at the disposal of the youngsters to take them out to the warship anchored in the Bay. The children were thrilled at the sights unfolded before their eyes, as the large majority of them had never at any time seen a vessel comparable in any way to the "Skeena". From the deepest depths to the highest bridge they ran, in spite of rain and the slippery decks, and though the adults may have "inspected" the ship on Sunday, it is a truism indeed that the children "searched" it very thoroughly on Monday. They kept the sailors busy with weird and wonderful questions, none of which however seemed to lack for an answer of some kind or other. The thanks of the residents of Alert Bay are certainly due to Commander Brodeur, his staff and crew for their extreme courtesy in making such a visit possible.

The playground of St. Michael's Residential School was the scene of a stern combat when football teams representing the "Skeena" and the School met at 3:15 P.M. on this day in a very exciting match. Honors went to the School, to the tune of 6:0 but the disadvantages of poor ground and a gravelly pitch made things very difficult for the sailors. The game was refereed by Constable F. Putland, but we are glad to say that his official services were not at any time in demand. The score was not indicative of the game, which was a very good one, and in the first half might have been anyone's victory.

Teams from the "Skeena" and the School met again, in the evening in a basketball game which was a duel to the finish. The "Skeena" boys netted a long fast shot with less than twenty seconds to go, winning a victory of thirteen to the twelve scored by the School. This was one of the finest exhibitions of basketball ever seen in this district, and the boys from the ship are to be congratulated on having such a team, more so when it must be remembered that opportunities for practice must necessarily be few.

The visit of His Honour the Lieutenant Governor and the "Skeena" wound up with a magnificent public reception and dance on Monday evening when four hundred citizens met to do honor to the representative of His Majesty the King in this province. The affair was informal, and all made themselves at home and were made to feel at home by His Honour who received them with a hearty handclasp and a word of welcome. Dancing was carried on until well on into the night hours, a large party of sailors from the "Skeena" enjoying
themselves in their characteristically nautical fashion.

Early Tuesday morning a short puff of smoke from the steam whistle of the "Skeena" signified the hoisting of the anchor and the closing of a chapter that will go down in memory as one of the most pleasant in the history of Alert Bay.
February 10, 1932.

Dear Canon Gould:

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.D., D.C.L.,
General Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
604 Jarvis St.,
Toronto 5, Ont.
"Easter Triumph, Easter Joy" - This surely must be the keynote of this message to you all from St. Michael's. Like yourselves, our children have gone through the forty days of the Lenten season; they have tried in special services to understand how to love God in everyday life; they journeyed on Good Friday with those who with sorrowful hearts saw our Blessed Lord walk the road to Calvary; but our hearts were not as sad as theirs, because beyond the veil and through the gloom and darkness that overhung the Tree of crucifixion, we could see the dawning glory of Easter which was so soon to turn a seeming failure and defeat into the most glorious triumph of all time. And if you had heard the children sing the great hymns of Easter, you, like us, would thank God for their beautiful faith, for they really rejoiced in the glory of the Risen Lord, and we believe that their Easter was the more greatly blessed because they had tried so hard to keep a good Lent.

Easter Monday the sun shone for the first time for oh so long. It seemed like a special Blessing, so we all had a wonderful Sports Meet on our new racing track. Fifty-two events were run off before 2 P.M., when, because we had finished, down came the rain again. Some very good races were seen, the senior champion, Fred Cook of Alert Bay running the 100 yards in ten and two-fifths seconds. The mile brought the same boy home, first in four minutes thirty-eight seconds, which was pretty good for a new and yet rough track. Jack Hanuse took the pole vault at 6'4" and the 120 yard hurdles in 35 seconds, whilst Frank Wilson captured the broad jump with 16'6". Young Billy Alfred took the Intermediate championship winning four out of five events entered, as also did the running-up Daniel Hanuse, whose little brother Freddie won the Junior championship, also winning four out of five events. In the girls' side, Stella Robinson took senior honour, Mary Boyd the Intermediate and Alice Macdonald the Juniors for the non-one time running. The younger girls did some very good work, but the seniors are still rather shy. Sports are now to them and our hopes at this line of endeavour must perform like in the younger generation.

In the evening the youngsters enjoyed seeing Harold Lloyd in "Welcome Danger" and the roof almost lifted between screams of laughter and those of terror. They had a great time and are now happily back at their studies for the last lap of the school year.

We are sorry indeed to tell you all that due to the need for economy, the Olympic will not be held this year. It will be a keen disappointment to the children who have been working faithfully to earn places on the school team. However they are young, and we are sure that many of them will make the grade for the Meet in 1933. Our school football team are they getting tuned up for May 24th, when they have to meet all comers to hold the Football Challenge Cup for the second time. It should be a great game.

We have added another teacher to our staff, making five classrooms working here and all children up to and including Grade 3 junior go to school all day. This is in line with Mr. Taylor's lowering the grade age in this school and will prove a decided help in getting the children along more quickly. The Principal recently went north to Bella Bella and was royally entertained by the entire village, to whom he was privileged to speak both in Church and in their community Hall on the work being done for their children in school. At the Sunday evening service, over four hundred were in church, which was packed to the doors. At a very wonderful concert...
lasting from 7:30 P.M. until well after midnight, ex-pupils joined in many varied ways that they have learned much, both in skill and happiness. At another meeting an association of ex-pupils was formed, forty-nine signing the charter roll of members. One cannot pass on without raising a tribute to the wonderful work being done by Rev. & Mrs. Gibson and Dr. Darby, Medical Superintendent of the R.J. Large Memorial Hospital.

School health continues fairly good, though we have had several children quite ill. This past winter has been a severe one on children all through the coastal villages, and we have not been free of our share of worry and sorrow. We have had a dentist here during the past month and it may interest you to know that he put fillings in 631 teeth and extracted 632. We can hardly say the youngsters enjoyed it, but they are very brave and good.

Sixty children are now busily preparing for the examiner of the Royal College of Music, whilst five are studying hard for the Entrance examinations. One boy is shortly to take up his Grade X studies in commercial work in Vancouver; you will wish them all success we are sure. They are busy days and they just fly along.

All interested in our Indian people will hear with regret of the retirement of Dr. Duncan C. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, who after fifty-five years work for the Indian people of Canada, is now to earn a well-deserved rest. Dr. Scott recently wrote to us wishing all in the school every success, and we echo back the wish that the success he has already earned may be attended by those joys and blessings that accompany the evening of a life well lived in service to his fellow-men.

All too soon we will have to give thought to the question of holidays and we will be glad to hear from some of our friends in the Indian villages giving us their views as to the most suitable dates for commencement of the annual vacations. We may say quite definitely that it is not our intention to allow as many children out as usual, though more of this latter.

Already we have a considerable waiting list of children seeking places in the school this fall, and parents desiring to have children admitted should arrange for the applications to go in to the Indian Agents as soon as possible.

Spring is here now and our school gardens are soon to be beautiful with flowers and our fields with vegetables. We hope many of you will enjoy the same pleasure as we do in planting and growing the bountiful gifts of a loving God.

This must be all for this time, and with kindest regards to you all,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Principal
St. Michael's Residential School
Alert Bay, B.C.

Dear Mr. Newnham:

After considerable thought we have to ask you to place the question of vacation for the pupils of this school before your Department for their consideration and advice.

We have to apply for a vacation period for this year of two months, same to start on June 15 approximately ending August 15 approximately. This period will be for the main body of the school. There is a group, however of local boys with perhaps a few girls, regarding whom special consideration is asked. As you are aware, fishing opens in the Nimpkish River on May 1st and we have among our senior pupils a number of boys who belong to the Nimpkish tribe who have been asked to take positions in boats working in the river this year. Parents have applied to us for permission for them to leave school at the start of the fishing season and we have informed them that we cannot concur in any such request as it would mean the disorganization of most of our senior classes of the school. We have however promised to recommend to the Department that this special group be allowed to take their vacation as from June 1st for a period of two months on a grant earning basis. If for any reason it was felt necessary or advisable to extend this period, it would be understood that the school would draw no grants for the additional period of leave granted. The problem this year appears to be largely an economic one, and the only hope of many of these youngsters earning any money this year would seem to be by their taking these positions not later than June 1st. In their case we would request that you recommend to the Department to allow their vacation to start from this date.

Enclosed please find copies of correspondence between the School and Inspector of Schools G.H. Barry of your Department. Our entire High School Entrance class writing examinations this year is composed of boys of an age permitting them to work and earn funds for the maintenance of their people during the coming winter and to assist in the necessary expenses of cloth-
ing and transportation to and from school. This correspondence speaks for itself and we would request that you consider it with a view to giving your concurrence to the suggestion outlined by the Inspector. This would permit all pupils of the school to get away on their vacation on the date recommended for the closing of school for the two summer months.

We would be grateful if you would ask the Department to give us their views regarding which children are to be allowed home and which retained in school, and further as to the possibility of the Department making any grant towards transportation for pupils proceeding home on vacation. It will, as in former years, be necessary to send escorts with the children proceeding home, and we would ask that you recommend an amount of $72.00 to cover expenses in this connection.

We would also appreciate a ruling from the Department as to whether or not children whose courses are completed and who are being graduated from school this year may expect the Department to pay their fare home.

Thanking you,

Sincerely yours,

"F. Earl Anfield"
Principal.

Dear Sir:

We would much appreciate your views as to whether or not we are justified in holding our pupils for Entrance exams until the end of June, when by so doing they will forfeit their chances of getting a job at fishing this summer. As perhaps you know, fishing starts early in June this year, and in the Nimpkish before then. There are signs of considerable curtailment as regards the number of boats, and already the parents are writing to their children informing them that they have positions for them provided that they are there to take the boats over on the first day of fishing. We have six boys in the Entrance class, five of whom came from the Shuswap Agency and already have jobs booked for this summer on the one condition that they are available by June 16th to take them on. The other boy is a local and has an offer of a place in a drag seine over at the river if he can be there by the 1st of June. He is Daniel Hanuse, with a widowed mother. We have two Grade IX pupils Jack Hanuse and Agnes King. The former was sick all last summer and has not earned anything to help his mother and a large family for two years. Again, there is the question, are we justified in holding him to write Grade IX Government exams and thereby depriving him of his chance to earn enough to make it possible for him to come back to school next year and continue his course.

The problem seems to be an economic one entirely; the parents are glad and in most cases anxious for their boys to go on and complete their courses provided that they themselves can earn sufficient to make expenses of fares and clothing needed, and where possible contribute something to the support of the family. Otherwise the parents say that if the children are not given an opportunity of earning, then they cannot return them to school. We are quite satisfied that competition is keen enough this year to deprive late arrivals of any opportunity of getting boats or gear.

Your remarks will be awaited with interest.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant in which you refer to the question of justification in holding some of your Grade 8 and Grade 9 pupils in school long enough for them to take the examinations set by the Provincial Department of Education at the end of next June.

In your letter you mention that Agnes King is one of your two Grade 9 pupils. In the list you gave me during my last inspection of the school your Grade 9 girl is named Ellen Newman. Are these just two names for the same girl? It was Ellen Newman who was examined by me, and who made a score of 95 in the B.C. Achievement Test on October 17, 1932. Perhaps you would be good enough to clear up this matter in your next letter.

I have given some considerable thought to the questions raised in your letter, and have come to the following opinion.

The parents of the children concerned should be communicated with, if this has not been done, and it should be pointed out that for the children to miss taking their B.C. Departmental examinations is a grave matter, and may have a very unfortunate result on their future educational progress. I wish to make it very clear that those children who fail to obtain Entrance Certificates will be unable to take advantage of High School instruction under the B.C. Department of Education, either in the way of a Correspondence Course or by instruction at a Technical High School. The substance of this paragraph should be communicated to the boys themselves, and their wishes taken into consideration.

Owing to the peculiar economic conditions of the present time, and to the fact that you certify that the six boys of your Grade 8 class will be actually employed during the period for which they are given leave of absence, I consider that it would be unfair to keep them in school till the end of June. To thus force the boys to remain till after the conclusion of the Entrance examination would probably cause strained feeling between the boys, their parents and the school authorities. This would be particularly unfortunate in the case of the boys from the North.

Should you so desire, I am prepared to visit your school during the early part of next May, to carry out a testing programme with the Senior grades, particularly with the Entrance candidates. If I do this, the decision as to the promotion of these children to a Grade 9 class in September must be left in my hands. Those whom I do not consider fit then for High School must, if they return to school, repeat Grade 8 next year.
Your wholehearted agreement in this is necessary if I am to devote several days during a particularly busy period of the year, to the carrying out of this special work for your Indian children. The matter contained in this letter is to be taken as a professional opinion, and in no sense an authority for the giving of this special leave of absence to some of the boys of your school. The Indian Agent will no doubt have to be consulted, and the matter taken up in the ordinary manner.

Your Senior Teacher should have the Grade 7, Grade 8 and Grade 9 children write examinations in all the subjects of their courses. These examinations might well be taken just before Easter. The marks out of 100 in each subject ought to be tabulated against the name of the candidate, so that I can see at a glance the Name of the child, Standing in Class, Age, Mark in each subject, Total percentage obtained, and teacher's estimate of attitude to work and suitability for promotion.

My own work in the classroom will be supplementary to this and will take the form of Standard Tests in certain of the subjects, and an Intelligence Test.

Please consult your Senior Teacher with regard to the above, and let me have a reply when the matter is finally approved through the Indian Agent, so that I may plan my future itineraries to suit. I should have to visit you on my way to other schools on the coast and in the North, and a number of arrangements have to be made well ahead.

Your obedient servant,

"Gerald H. Barry"

Sir,

In connection with your letter dated June 10th, re the above, I have to state that when the matter referred to therein was first brought to me, it had reached a stage where it was obviously impossible for the Principal to adjust it, he being one of the parties against whom the complaining teacher had a grievance and I succeeded in inducing the lady to consent to having it brought to the notice of Dr. Westgate of the Anglican Indian Residential School Commission, in preference to her having her case put into the hands of a lawyer.

At no time did it reach a stage where it was necessary for the Department of Indian Affairs to enter, although it was undoubtedly in my capacity as acting Indian Agent that Dr. Westgate requested me to act in company with Rev. C.K.K. Prosser and Mr. F.F. Anfield in investigating the matter. The result of this investigation has been reported to Dr. Westgate and certain staff re-adjustments are being made at the Residential School. I have now withdrawn from the case entirely.

Apart from the combination of unfortunate circumstances which led to the trouble, I would point out that amongst the white community of Alert Bay—not a large one—there are certain people who are always ready to criticize, condemn and also obstruct the different phases of work involved in taking care of the Indians and just now keen resentment is being expressed by this particular faction of the white community, at the public expense entailed in the maintenance of the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay with the result that the slightest opportunity of attaching the slightest breath of scandal to the institution is made the most of.

In this case, it is believed that the loyalty and the proper conduct of the staff as a body, in the contacts with outside members of the community, have obviated the possibility of any reflection being cast upon the honour of the School.

Sir,

Pursuant to my letter dated June 3rd, I have to report that in compliance with a request from Dr. Westgate, head of the Anglican Indian Residential School Commission telegraphed from Winnipeg, a committee was formed consisting of the Rev. C.K.K. Prosser, Anglican Rector at Alert Bay, F.E. Anfield Esq., Principal, St. Michael's Indian Residential School and myself as acting Indian Agent, for the purpose of determining whether the complaints of Miss Annie Ripley, a teacher of the Residential School warranted an investigation by the Commission.

I declined to make any comment or take part in any discussion relating to the lady's teaching abilities, stating that this was within the purview of Capt. G.H. Barry, District Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., who was due to arrive at Alert Bay on June 7th, in connection with other business.

On June 5th, the committee dealt with the matter, a series of discussions taking place first between Rev. C.K.K. Prosser and Mr. Anfield, then between Mr. Prosser, Mr. Anfield and myself followed by one between Mr. Prosser and myself.

On Miss Ripley being called, Mr. Anfield requested to be allowed to withdraw but was subsequently recalled on my support of Miss Ripley's contention that he should be present during the whole of the proceedings. The final discussion was by all three members of the committee with Miss Ripley present, submitting her evidence both documentary and oral, which was dealt with and the following decisions were reached.

(1) So far as the Commission were concerned, the allegations of unprofessional conduct made by Miss Ripley against the head matron—Miss Leonard—had been disposed of, as Miss Leonard was leaving the institution on June 30th, next, whether by resignation or dismissal was not disclosed, but apparently she was content to leave without making any defence to the charges against her. Miss Ripley was not desirous of taking her case to a lawyer and stated that as Dr. Westgate was now evidently giving it further consideration, she was prepared to abide by his decision. This phase of the matter was therefore not pursued.

(2) The Principal—Mr. Anfield—admitted that he had not
he had not

been aware of all the facts and agreed that a "terrible mistake" had been made which had caused Miss Ripley considerable physical hardship and mental worry during the past six months. He therefore approved of Miss Ripley writing a report to the Commission stating her case in full, which would be accompanied by a covering letter from himself in which he would seek to nullify the effects of an adverse report which he had previously submitted on Miss Ripley and which no doubt had led to her being officially notified that her teaching contract which automatically terminated on June 30th next, could not be renewed. Miss Ripley stated that she would like to remain on the Residential School staff if possible, but if not she had no desire to leave "under a cloud". This was her chief concern and had led to her bringing her case to me, she and the Principal apparently being at cross purposes. She implied that her father would go to any expense to see that she was justly dealt with. However she was satisfied with this decision and again agreed to abide by Dr. Westgate's decision.

Last December, whilst playing basket-ball at the school with pupils and other staff members, Miss Ripley was accidentally hurt. She suffered great pain but continued with the game and in the course of a few days was admitted to hospital where she was treated for pleurisy being subsequently diagnosed as tubercular by the local doctor, she was not "X-rayed" at that time, but it later transpired that she had actually sustained fractures of a number of ribs. Suffering great pain but being unaware of the nature of her injury she had carried on teaching after discharge from hospital, under most difficult conditions which had made her irritable and drew some censure from the Principal. She then obtained leave to go to Vancouver, where she was examined by Dr. G. Barker a specialist, who furnished her with a certificate stating that she was not tubercular and which in fact was a "clean bill of health".

Whilst in hospital, she came under the care of Miss Leonard, at that time on the hospital staff and who a short time later was appointed Head Matron at the Residential School where evidently the bad feeling which existed between her and Miss Ripley was renewed, Miss Ripley being subjected to further mental stress by Miss Leonard's allegedly open statements to the effect that she (Miss Ripley) was "tubercular" "a mental case" and other remarks as to her physical condition, which lead to her being practically ostracized by other members of the staff. Sir,

On June 1st, Miss Annie Ripley, a teacher on the staff of St Michael's Indian Residential School called on me and made certain complaints against the present matron of the school and to a lesser degree against the principal.

The lady was distressed and somewhat overwrought and undoubtedly indulged in personalities which I persuaded her to eliminate. She sought my advice in my capacity as Justice of the Peace. After hearing her story I decided that if the matron's conduct had been as Miss Ripley stated and which was corroborated by the affidavit of another member of the school staff, that the matter could not be dismissed as trivial, particularly as, apparently through no fault of her own, circumstances had arisen which would in a most unfair way jeopardise Miss Ripley's future career.

The most serious of Miss Ripley's allegations are in regard to the fact that after being examined by the local doctor, she received an adverse report as to her physical condition which was publicly discussed by the matron of the school, who is a qualified nurse and who before assuming her present duties was engaged at the Alert Bay Hospital. Being considerably distressed and subjected to unnecessary annoyance she was subsequently examined by a specialist in Vancouver, who furnished her with an absolutely clean "bill of health" and whose report she showed to me.

Miss Ripley further informed me that on lodging a complaint with the principal—Mr. P.E. Anfield—he had dismissed it with a remark to the effect that "the Commission at Winnipeg were always receiving complaints and took no notice of them". I then decided to accede to her request and wire to Dr. Westgate head of the Indian Residential School Commission and I have today received a telegraphic reply that the Commission is taking the necessary steps immediately to inquire into conditions at St Michael's.

In its present stage the matter does not appear to come within the purview of the Department of Indian Affairs. I was appealed to judicially and feel that in bringing it to
the notice of the Indian Residential School Commission, I have done all that it is necessary for me to do, unless the Department gives me other instructions, and therefore refrain from all comment.

It is perhaps unnecessary to state that under normal circumstances, I do not interfere with the management of the St Michael's Indian Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

E.G. Newnham

Miss Winstanley is quite unsuitable for a teaching position in any Indian school. She is a very small girl, not as big as many of the girls at Alert Bay, her control of her class is simply non-existent. Her appointment here was authorized by Dr. Westgate, M.M. of the L. S. C. C., and like many other of the appointments made by the Anglican Church to the teaching staff here, appears to me to be most unfortunate. Dr. Westgate told me this girl has a B. C. Teaching Certificate. As a matter of fact only INTERIM CERTIFICATES are issued at the close of Normal training, and it is one of these which Miss Winstanley holds at present. The mere holding of a teaching certificate of this nature does not imply any particular ability to teach or control Indian children. We have numbers of well trained and recommended ANGLICAN teachers, and I fail to see why such inferior candidates should be selected by the Church. I WOULD RECOMMEND MISS WINSTANLEY'S DISMISSAL AT THE FIRST OPPORTUNITY. This matter has been thoroughly discussed with the Principal of the School, Mr. Amfield, and I believe he agrees with me.
St. Michael's Indian Reserve School, Alert Bay, B.C.

News Letter No. 1 - 1933-1934

To the Parents, all Ex-Pupils & Supporters of the School:

My dear Friends;-

A long time has passed since last we sent out a news letter to you all, but it has not been on account either of lack of news or of interest, but due to a combination of work and financial stress. We feel the need of contact between the school and our friends is however so important, that whatever expense is required will somehow or other be forthcoming, so here we go for Number One news letter for this term.

School re-opened with a capacity attendance towards the end of the month of August. The children who did not go home had a wonderful time at our school camp, and they are certainly among the healthiest of our children today. It is hoped that the camp will continue each year and that more of our Indian people will see the wisdom of leaving their children in charge of the school each summer, especially in these times when money for fares is so difficult to obtain.

We are sorry for our Indian people in the far north who this year faced one of the worst fishing years in the history of the Coast, but it is a fine thing to know that so many of them worked hard to be able to send their children back to school. What a big step forward it would be if more of our people could see the wisdom of leaving younger children at home in the villages with the older people and those without work, instead of all going off to the Cannaries where living is so much more expensive and where so many often have to live on the small earnings of the few. If more people stayed in the villages, more gardens could be planted with potatoes, fruit and vegetables and there would be a lot less distress and poverty during the winter months. It is hardly worth while to plant a garden in the spring and then go and leave it for three or four months, where as if more people spent their summer months at home, they themselves would be healthier and the gardens would have good care and would produce much more food for you. It is quite certain that the young children would be better at home than around canneries where machinery within and wharves without are ever present dangers to the youngsters. It is hoped that our Indian young people will try and see the wisdom of this suggestion and then sell the idea to the older folks.

The bad summer and fishing season had its effect on the health of the children who went out from school for vacation, as most of them returned underweight and became easy victims of the flu which visited us just after school opened. At the time of writing, however, the general health of the student body is very good and the children are practically all gaining in weight and look well. They are certainly a lively crowd this year and keep us all on the jump.
All the classrooms are busy and the children working with keenness and energy. We have the biggest High School class in the history of the school and it is our hope that as the years go by, the standard will get steadily higher and the general grade age of the children improve. It must be the effort of us all to build up the mental equipment of all our Indian young people, not just a few here and there, and here is where the villages must help more and more. We are all facing difficult times and it is hard to see just what the future holds. I am quite certain, however, that the future holds more for the boy or girl with an education than for those without, and it is the duty of every Indian mother and father to see that their children have as good or better chance than they had themselves, because the need of men and women trained to think things out in bad times is greater than in good times when life moves along easily and we do not have to worry from whence is coming our next meal. Your greatest duty is to see that your children get to the day school when they are young. See that they attend regularly and back up the teacher and missionary in what they are trying to do. The biggest difficulty we have to face in the Residential School is the lack of day school education in the children that come to us. We have to spend money on primary education you should have given to your children in their own villages. This money could well be spent on more technical work for the older children, but, until our Indian people really get in and use the day schools provided for the young children, they are holding back the work of these larger schools and it is their own children that suffer as a result. When a girl or boy comes to us at eleven or twelve years of age, unable even to get into grade one, you can hardly expect us to be able to do as much for him or her as for a child who has been going regularly to the day school and goes right into grade three or four when admitted here. This is one of the biggest reasons for keeping children at home during the summer. It would mean that the day school could be started in September instead of November. Do you know that as I write this letter, there are day schools not yet started because children are still out with their parents fishing. This is not right and the day will come when the parents will be bitterly sorry for it, because their children will blame them for not giving them a chance to equip themselves with education for the battle of life.

Now a word or two for those girls and boys who graduated this past term. Do not think, will you, that your education is completed because you have ceased to be a pupil of St. Michael's? You have only changed your school, from Alert Bay to your village. Whether you have gone up a grade or down depends pretty largely upon yourself, doesn't it? Your teachers have changed too, from those here to your parents, the missionary and your friends. I do hope you will all give them the same attention and respect as you gave to us here at school. You enjoyed learning here or you should have - I hope you will enjoy learning in your school, that of home and village life. Be careful that you choose only the best teachers. In school you learned that everything depends on our Christianity or lack of it, and really, it is just the same at home. Be as faithful there as you were here.
regular in your attendance at the services of your Church, take a real and active part in Church life. Make a real friend of your missionary. I know most of them and you will find them fine fellows and anxious to be your friends. They are hoping great things of you; so are we; and of course God is too. Don't disappoint anyone, will you. It is not always going to be easy, sometimes it is going to be as tough as possible. You are going to miss School I know. I did myself when I left school many years ago, and so can know how you will feel like. But I have found one friend all through life. I met Him first in school where I went when I was only five. So will you, Jesus Christ, the same today, yesterday and forever. In Alert Bay, at St. Michael's, in your home; in your parents, in your missionary, your Church and games and work; and oh I hope in your heart. He will help you make friends, good ones, who will stay with you when the storms come and that is when you need a friend, don't you? By the way, we would like ever so much for all girls and boys to write sometimes to the old school, your home for many years. Tell us how you get along, your joys and triumphs, yes and your defeats. We have them too and may be able to help you sometimes.

Do you know that 1934 is our Golden Jubilee year? Fifty years ago the old school started and since then 450 boys and 200 girls have been through the school. We must try and plan a great re-union of ex-pupils next spring. What do you think about the month of February for a big re-union at St. Michael's? How many will come? Bring your basketball and football teams, and we could have a wonderful ten days of re-union and fellowship together.

Our monthly challenge shield system is working again this year and on the girls' side, Lydia Brown's team, the Crescents won the Shield for September and October. On the boys' side, Madrick Nelson's team won in September and Roger Mercer's team in October.

It is nice to hear that Dave Bernard of Rivers Inlet, an ex-pupil of the school and a returned soldier, is a regular and trusted employee of the Dominion Government Hatchery at the Inlet.

Twenty pupils are taking music this year, thanks to Mrs. Kenmuir, who gives her services so wonderfully in this way. As the course is free, we choose a few pupils from each village, thus trying to spread musical education over as large an area as possible.

The children have been greatly interested in the campaign for the Restoration Fund and have subscribed this year the sum of $85.00 to this great cause.

Our Harvest Festival this year was held on Sunday, October 15th and as a result of a special appeal, the collections totalled $210.00.
Our first word to you all must be one of very sincere greetings and all good wishes for the New Year now opened before us. May this year be to one and all the hope and answer of our deepest thought and prayer; may it be a period of making good the failures and disappointments of last year; and may the blessing of the good God and Father of all be upon you.

With these letters going out to the parents, you will find the half year reports of your children. Will you study them carefully and write to the youngsters about them, as it is a great help if they feel and know that you are deeply interested in their progress and welfare. As we look over the reports, we are impressed with the splendid health of the children. In spite of a short attack of colds, which was more or less general on the staff, our youngsters were not in better health than they are now and everyone who visits the school remarks on how wonderfully healthy and well they all look. With a family as large as ours, it may be expected that some sickness will prevail, but we are glad to tell you that throughout the Christmas festival, not one child was in our infirmary and only one little boy in the hospital.

You will of course want to know about the Christmas, won't you? We certainly had a very wonderful time, made the happier, I know by our children's efforts to make others happy as well as themselves. The great festival started with a pageant of the Nativity, shown in our Church, when the children were able to see the glorious story of the Incarnation acted before their own eyes. We believe there is room for great development of the dramatic form of teaching for our Indian children and we would be glad to offer our experience to any villages interested. We are giving careful thought at this time to staging on Good Friday the story of the Passion of Our Lord, using the entire staff and student body as the actors in the story.

But we must get back to our Christmas activities, mustn't we? The joyful day dawned fine and early, almost too early, and down into the school, beautifully decorated for the holiday, surged our huge family of over two hundred. Santa Claus had visited the dormitories during the night and so breakfast was chiefly an occasion for exchanging cards and greetings; following which, all prepared to offer their welcome to Him who at the first glad Christmas gave Himself to mankind for evermore, and Who, in very truth, came once again to earth to greet us and be greeted; and together we knelt in Communion with Him. It seemed no time till noon had come and all sat down to partake of the good things provided for the Christmas dinner. During the afternoon many group leaders were busy preparing for the great school service and Christmas tree. Once more as in previous years, the entire student body was divided into groups, representing the eight large tribes enrolled in the school, and our Hall was a glorious sight. At one end was the altar, the gift of the Staff to the School, with its riddles and beautiful hangings. In the centre of the Hall a huge Christmas tree, blazing with lights and banked with gifts for the children.
All around the walls were the wigwams, teepees, community houses and camp fires of the various tribes, the members of which were all dressed in costumes of the olden days. One does not describe these things well; one just remembers them; and as the organ pealed out the opening notes of "O Come, all ye faithful", a great silence reigned the whispered excitement of the children; and on silently thanked God for the privilege of being used in the work of showing Christ to these, His native children. It was a real Indian service, all in Indian dress, many painted and be-feathered; here and there gorgeous dancing blankets and grim masks - some stood, others knelt and yet others sat on the blankets strewn upon the floor; but all worshipped Him, the Lord of Light and Peace, Jesus Immanuel. Once more the children were given the opportunity of giving what they could for the needs of children less fortunate than themselves, and it was possible to send away next day a worthwhile gift to one of the poorest parishes in Vancouver. Our worship over, our gifts presented, the children prepared to receive their own and to the tinkling of bells, the old yet ever young Santa arrived and in short order our Christmas gift tree was stripped and the children playing with their presents. And so to bed.

During the week that followed, high festival was held, group after group met for parties, culminating in a Xmas pantomime, staged and acted by the staff and entitled "Robinson Crusoe and Mr. Ffriday". We certainly did not realise until we saw them in this play, what talents had been hidden by our staff. This pantomime was presented twice; on the first night for the school and the second, it was given as a token of goodwill from the School to the whole community, and in all some seven hundred adults and children were enabled to enjoy a good laugh and a pleasant two hours of entertainment. All too soon the week passed by and we met at the close of the old year to thank the great Giver of All for blessings received; to ask His forgiveness for opportunities wasted; and as the New Year dawned; that His blessing may remain with us.

Such was Christmas, and it was a good time too; it gave us a chance to get close to the great love of God to men; and its joys; its divine spirit; and its great urge to give will stand us in good stead in the days that lie before us.

We have been thinking seriously for some time about starting a school band, we can get a good instructor locally; but the great drawback is the enormous cost of instruments, and we were wondering if some of our Indian friends in the villages of our Coast would not be able to donate us a few pieces here and there. I know that the people are keenly interested in music for their children, and we have a piano and organ class of nearly twenty who make wonderful progress. But as far as a band goes, we cannot do much without the instruments. Surely in each of our villages there must be unused instruments? Will you think of this and look around and if you have any instruments you care to donate, we will be glad to pay the freight on them. We would even be glad to accept them on loan and will take every care of them, should it not be possible to donate them outright.
Much thought is being given to the question of our anniversary this year, and we are inclined to think that a celebration might be arranged to take place here at the school around May 24th, as this would seem to be a time when most of our villages could send teams for a week's games and festivities. Nothing definite has been settled, but enquiries are being made and we hope in our next letter to be able to tell you something fairly definite.

Now a few words for our graduates and ex-pupils. Much thought is being given to your needs these days, ways and means are being sought to help you use the teaching, training and experience of school days, but I wonder often if we all really do enough ourselves. In every village of our Coast are groups of young men and women who passed through this school. If they were united in aim and effort to make their village the best there is, what a power they would be. We cannot do very much alone, we may say! Well, what about joining together in a group and, having definite aims and objects see what can be done. I am certain our missionaries will stand behind such an ex-pupil's association. Will you not give thought to forming a "St. Michael's Club" in every village—ask your Missionary to become one of its officers, say the Chaplain. If any group will meet and form such a Club, and will write to me, I will send up a suggested outline of rules and possible forms of service that might be undertaken. There will have to be officers; there must be regular meetings and the Clubs must set a definite plan of how they will help forward the work and life of the village. What a help to some of our hard worked Missionaries it would be if a Club of say twenty or thirty young people would say "him and mean it—"Here we are, what can we do to help your work—we will stand with you and back you up in anything and everything that will extend the Kingdom of God in our village. Some Missionaries I know would at once think Heaven had come on earth. You would need a watchword. How "All for Jesus" and I say this because there is always the danger in Clubs of having a motto that works out like this "All for us"—which is the cause of half the trouble in the world today. Above all, Clubs of this kind would mean much a lot to the graduates when they first reach home; something to carry on with from school days and something to join school life with the new life of a young man or woman at home.

May we in closing this letter thank one and all who in ways known and unknown, helped to make Christmas the happy time it was for our children, and may I add a personal word of thanks for the scores of cards and gifts sent me from friends up and down the coast and across Canada, and very especially the ex-pupils who wrote to me at the blessed time of Christmas. As I looked at my piled up desk on Christmas Day, my heart was very full for you all, and it shall ever be my prayer that I may be found more worthy to carry on this great work for you and yours.

With every good wish,

Yours very sincerely,

F. Earl Anfield,
Principal
Ottawa, February 23, 1934.

Dear Friend:-

St. Michael's School, Alert Bay, is planning to keep this year its 50th Anniversary, and should it be possible for us to raise sufficient funds for same, we would like to arrange a week's celebration during which time we could have a re-union of graduate pupils of the school, represented by a delegation of graduates from each of the villages from which pupils have in the past been drawn to the school.

Bearing in mind the fact that nothing certain can be arranged until (a) we are sure of a financial grant to cover the expenses involved in such a celebration and (b) we have definite information from the villages re what part they can take in such a proposed re-union, it would be greatly appreciated if you will arrange at the earliest possible moment to call a meeting of all graduates and ex-pupils of this school, to which meeting we would earnestly beg you to invite your Missionary or any resident officer of the Indian Department so that their advice and help may be sought, and then to advise me as soon as possible of your views on the following points,-

(1) Do you think this a suitable year in which to arrange for a re-union? If not, will you tell us why you do not agree?

(2) What do you think about the week of May 20th to May 26th as the best time?

(3) Could your village send 12 men who could form a football, basketball and track team?

(4) Could your village send a team of girls as a basketball and track team?

(5) Should the re-union be possible will your village take part?
(6) Should your village take part, will you agree to provide transportation for all members of the delegation? (Should the re-union take place, we are recommending that the school will provide food and accommodation to all competing delegates from villages north of Vancouver Island.)

(7) What do you think of this as a general outline of the week's programme?

(a) Special religious services some of which to be lead by members from visiting villages.

(b) Lectures by outstanding people on such subjects as Indian education and round table conferences on how the schools can help the Indian people more; what the Churches can do to help and what the Indians can do to help the Churches; and other subjects.

(c) An inter-village track meet in which the school would enter competitors.

(d) Football, baseball and basketball games between the competing villages and the school teams.

(8) Have you any suggestion as to other activities that would be well included in the programme?

(9) Should your village send a delegation, how and when would they arrive?

(10) How many graduates boys and men - women and girls are resident in your village? We really hope you will give this matter very earnest consideration, and as time is short, an early reply will be appreciated.

With every good wish,

Your very sincere friend,

News Letter No. 4. - ooOoo - March 12, 1934.

My dear Friends:

Time flies along so fast at school that it seems only a very little while since we last wrote to you all, and yet it is getting on for two whole months, so it would seem a good thing to let you all know something of what is being done at St. Michael's for your children.

First of all we are pleased to tell you that the children keep well and practically all of them are in splendid health. In a school as large as this it seems almost impossible to escape from sickness altogether, but the number of children ill seems to get less each year, which looks as if the general health standard is slowly improving in the villages, a tribute to the patient work being done both by the Indian Department and the Church in those places. The children are now well into the second half of the school year and many of them have been moved to higher grades, where we trust they will continue to make steady progress in their studies.

After a very long and trying winter from the point of view of weather, the spring at last seems to be arriving and glorious sunny days are with us now, bringing new joy and healthy sun rays to the youngsters, with longer hours and brighter days for outside games.

So too in our Church life, the long days of Lent are moving on, and we strive to see beyond the darkness of the approaching Passiontide the glorious and certain hope of new and better life in the triumphant glory of the Feast of Easter.

On Good Friday in our Church we will endeavour to portray the "Story of the Passion" and many from the school, both pupils and staff, are among those chosen to act in this solemn play. May God help them all to reverently portray those terrible days in the earthly life of His Beloved Son; that through their service in word and action, others of His flock may learn to love Him more.

Through the kindness of the Superintendent of the Oriental Mission of B.C., we have secured the loan of a very fine set of slides on the life of our Blessed Lord, and these are being used in the mid-week Lenten services at the School. It is very wonderful to observe the reverence of the children as they see and hear that old but ever new story unfolded to them.

During Lent we are undertaking our second year's drive for the Restoration Fund and once more the children have taken this great cause to their hearts and are giving generously as they did last year.
On Sunday next, March 18th, over fifty of our children will be presented to the Bishop of the Diocese for the sacred rite of Confirmation. For them all we ask your prayers as they take upon themselves fuller citizenship in the Kingdom of Our Lord and Saviour. May they go from strength to strength and be a power for good among their people.

With these newsletters to the parents, go out the holiday applications for this year and we would ask your careful attention to them and their quick return to the school so that plans may be made in plenty of time for the annual vacation. We would like you to know that a splendid site is being secured for a summer camp for the children who will remain with us during the holiday, and we would urge on you to give careful thought before deciding whether to take your children out or not. We know that last year was an exceptionally bad year for fishing, with the result that many of the children had but a poor holiday in the canneries, especially from the health standpoint. From the money side it was very bad and the school was put to considerable expense in getting some of the children back, so we want you to be very careful in what you do this year. Things do look a little better for this summer and I think fish prices will be higher, but we would urge our Indian people to keep away from strikes at all costs. They do nothing but harm and when the fish runs are so short, the fishermen are always the greater losers in the end.

During the winter I have been able to visit several of the villages from which our children come to school, and I have been much impressed by the brave way in which our Indian people are trying to meet these difficult times. A long overdue visit was paid to Massett on the Queen Charlotte Islands, where the people gave me a splendid reception and welcome and when it was possible for them and the Principal to really get together and try to understand the problems and viewpoints of both parties. A remarkable band and choir concert was given, as a result of which I am the more certain that greater attention must be paid to choral and instrumental work in the school.

It is a pleasure to tell you that the proposed Re-union of ex-pupils of this school has been settled to take place in the week of May 20-26th, when we shall fittingly celebrate a half century of Residential School work in Alert Bay. We do hope that delegates from all the villages will be with us and every effort will be made to see that a worthwhile programme is put on. More detailed news of this great event will go forward to the villages direct in a little while.

In closing this letter, may we wish you one and all a very Happy and Holy Eastertide, with the prayer that into our hearts and minds may come the power and strength of the Risen Christ. May the victory that was His that first great Easter morn be ours by His help; may we learn that in Him, we too may conquer sin and death, and like Him, we too may rise to new life in His service, both here on earth and hereafter in Heaven above.

Yours very sincerely,

F.E. Anfield, Principal
Ottawa, May 28, 1935.

Sir,

On September 14th last I wrote the Department enclosing copy of a letter received from Mr. F.E. Anfield, Principal of St. Michael's Indian Residential School in which he requested an increase in per capita earning pupilage from the present scale of 200 up to 210.

The Department replied to this letter on September 25th, No. 156-0-1 stating consideration would be given to the matter of providing grant for an extra pupilage when the Estimates were being prepared for the next fiscal year.

Mr. Anfield has again written me requesting that this be granted for the next term commencing after the summer holidays. It might be as well for me to explain the situation somewhat so that the Department will be fully aware of our position. My dear friends,

Holidays are over and the school is once more filled to overflowing for a new term of work which started officially on September 1st. On the Pacific coast the subject of talk during most of the year is fishing, which industry reaches its zenith during the two months our youngsters are out on vacation, giving most of those who are old enough to work an opportunity to earn some much needed money to buy clothes for themselves and to help their parents through the winter. I have in the past ten years at Alert Bay been much struck with the self-sacrifice of many of our older girls and boys who have done well during the fishing season and yet who, during the school year, have very little pocket money and I have often found that they have given almost all their earnings to their people, after buying an outfit of clothes for themselves. This is a nice thing to notice and makes us happy in our work for the children.

On the coast this year we have had the extremes of poverty and wealth in the different fishing areas. In our own district around Alert Bay we have seen the greatest run in years and our Indian people should all be very well off. The same can be said for Rivers Inlet, where in the last week of the run, literally hundreds of thousands of salmon were caught by the gill-netters, glutting the Canneries with fish to an unheard of extent. Whilst the fishermen did so well in Rivers Inlet, getting 45¢ per fish with an average catch per man of over 1200, the Cannery Companies will not profit greatly as this fish was not of very good grade for sock-eye, and will not bring high prices. The Bella Coola run was a failure as was also that of the Naas River, which was the worst in years. The run in the Queen Charlotte Islands was very poor, and that in the famous Skeena River was only fair. Generally speaking, our northern Indians will be very badly off whilst those of the south have done remarkably well. It is a great pity that more of them do not learn to save their money, though I am happy to say that some of our ex-pupils have brought their money either to the School or the Indian Agent to have placed in a bank for safe-keeping.

Only a few children were in school during the summer holiday, so few that we did not consider it worthwhile operating our camp. However, they had a very nice time and all but one improved greatly in health. The one exception who unfortunately has never had much of a chance from infancy, was finally taken to a hospital near his home where our prayers for his recovery follow him with our love and best wishes. We had a busy summer due largely to a superabundant crop of good things from the farm, and the staff were strenuously engaged in putting up jam and pickles, over 1½ tons of which were put by for the winter.

The largest class of graduating pupils we have known left this year to try out in their new village life at home the foundation they have been building at school. Few of us will ever forget the service held in our School for them at the close of term, and we do pray and beseech your prayers as well, that the resolutions there formed may be helped and strengthened in them all; and that the blessings there besought may be ever around them, to protect and fortify as they meet the cold challenge of the outside world. To you graduates, I say, be strong and of good courage and hold fast to that which is good. Make firm friends and counsellors of your village missionaries and teachers, and above all, get actively into God's work among your people. Write when you can and tell us of your joys and sorrows and remember always that your school is your home for you and will welcome a visit whenever you are near Alert Bay.
As a result of the large graduating class, we have a smaller school from the individual point of view, but every bed is full and five classrooms are working well. We have happily been able to relieve several difficult situations this year, taking in children from areas where no schools exist, and from others where children needed so badly a measure of home life, which, in spite of the size of the place, we do strive to give in this school. The health standard is good at the time of writing and it is our hope that this year, as last, we may be spared any undue worry over the physical welfare of our children.

During this summer, thanks indeed to generous help from friends in the different Government Departments at Alert Bay I have been able to follow up the children at the Canneries, and by boat and seaplane have visited them and their parents, much to the joy of us all. It was a tremendous help to see and feel the welcome they gave me at the Canneries this year, and also to know how well the Cannery officials co-operate - getting net lofts ready for services at which, thank God, we sometimes had over a hundred attending. Our Indian people need all the ministration we can give them, and especially so during the fishing season when violent sin is so often all around them. One feels, in services such as those taken this year something of the joy that must have animated our Master, when beside a lakeshore, lined with fishing boats, He taught the people that man does not live by bread or fish alone, but by the living word of God.

The first special event for the opening School was of course, St. Michael's Day and we did indeed have a happy Patronal Festival, made more so by a pleasant remembrance in the form of a cablegram from Rev. G.K.K. Prosser in England. Rev. Prosser was the School Chaplain for five years and he won the love and esteem of all at St. Michael's. A perfect day saw a well run programme brought to a successful conclusion, and the champions who came up to receive the Challenge Cups were Hester Jones of Massett and Marjorie Wilson of Letlakathla on the girls' side; Sam Guno and Jacob Davies, both of Aiyansh, on the boys' side.

A week later we kept Harvest Festival and welcomed to the School for the first time our new Bishop Co-adjutor, Rt. Rev. H. E. Sexton, whom the School took to its heart in a great way. He brought wonderful messages to us, and with them the loving greetings of the Diocesean, our dear friend, Bishop Schofield, whom, we were glad to hear, is rejoicing in better health. Bishop Sexton was present at a special service in our school when the school captains were commissioned for their year's work. Those who lead the school this year are: Patricia Thompson - "Eagles", Alice Mason - "Ravens", Hester Jones - "Orchids", Mary Munday - "Royal Rose"; Stanley Adams - "Vikings", Reggie Percival - "Comets", Jacob Davies - "Crusaders", Edwin Cook - "Wanderers".

The School was also pleased to welcome our friend, Dr. Westgate, Executive Secretary of the Indian Residential School Commission of our Church. We are always glad to see him and to listen to his friendly counsel and wise advice and we wish he would come more often. With him on his visit was Canon Vale, Principal of the School at Chapleau, Ontario, and a veteran missionary among our Indian people for the past 28 years. The visit of these two good people was ended greatly by one and all and helped us get off to a happy start in the new school year.

We welcome several new members on our staff this year, and especial Capt. J. E. Allsopp of the Church Army in Canada, who comes to us as Vice-Prin. I believe this to be a very fine choice by the Commission in view of the large played by the Church Army in the work of many of our northern villages.

The letter must close, it has been far too long. We shall write again to you all after Christmas and in the meantime wish you one and all God speed every blessing.

Ever your sincere friend,

Principal.

Sir,

It has come to my notice that aeroplanes landing at Alert Bay generally approach the landing location by flying low over the Residential School farm located at the head of the Bay. In doing so the planes follow a course which takes them immediately over the playgrounds of the school, often flying very low, where there are sometimes two hundred children playing on the grounds.

It appears to me should anything happen to the plane while flying low over the playgrounds in making their landing, a very serious accident might be the result. This office does not desire to interfere in any way with the air service coming into this station, and we are only thinking of the safety of the children in case of an accident, and wish to bring this to the attention of the Department so that some definite location can be set aside for the planes to use other than flying immediately over the playgrounds and thus avoid any accident which might occur.

I would appreciate if the Department would kindly take the matter up with the proper authorities and see if this cannot be arranged satisfactory to all concerned.

Your obedient servant,
