My dear Friends,

In our last letter we told you something of the Season of Renewal held for staff and pupils during the season of Lent, an opportunity God given, for spiritual research and fresh endeavour. Weeknight lantern services with instructions during the weeks of Lent prepared the way for an intensive day by day Mission during Holy Week, and we will not soon forget those wonderful services conducted by Captain Allsopp of the Church Army, now the Vice-Principal of our School. On Good Friday evening at the concluding service of the Mission, nearly one hundred of our company, staff and pupils alike, in response to a definite challenge, came forward from the congregation and kneeling before the altar, publicly renewed their Baptismal and Confirmation vows and re-dedicated their lives to fuller Christian service. For each and all of them we ask your prayers that they may continue loyal and faithful members of the living Church of Christ. Nearly half of those who made decisions in the mission are preparing themselves for Confirmation, when Bishop Sexton comes to us at the end of May. Just as it required a Calvary to glorify an Easter morn, so our mission of renewal brought to us all its own reward in a wonderful Eastertide; one of the happiest we have ever known at St. Michael's, for so many of our children had learned the real meaning of "everlasting life" and in their Communion on that glorious day sought and received from on high the power to live a life that lasts, triumphant over time and space; a life which can conquer sin and death and which can be used as the Evangel of a new day in the hearts of all mankind.

Due to the nearness of Empire Day to which the children are looking forward with great glee, we did not have a Sports Meet on the Easter Monday holiday this year, but treasure hunts, picnics, and a very fine football game in which our boys were victorious over the Village team, 2 - 0, seemed to fill in quite nicely and the children voted the day, which ended with a party, quite one of the best yet. They seemed quite contented to be back at their studies the following day and now they are on the last lap of the school year. Their minds of course, are looking ahead to vacation time, which will be upon us all too quickly. The holidays will start around the end of June, and I am sure even our smallest and youngest child can, without hesitation tell you the exact number of days still to wait. In some ways, prospects for a good fishing year seem brighter than those of last year, but the fishing industry is a rather elusive one on which to prophesy.

Toward the end of April it was possible for me to make a trip north, and in two weeks I travelled over 1300 miles and visited practically every Indian village north of Alert Bay to the Alaska boundary, most of the travelling being done in motor launches. I would be most ungrateful were I not to express thanks and appreciation to the Indian Agents, Missionaries, Doctors and teachers who made the visits possible and so greatly worthwhile. Leaving Alert Bay on a Wednesday, we worked north to Bella Coola by steamer, and en route visited the people of the Oweekayno tribe in Rivers Inlet, and
met Dave Bernard and John Thompson, graduates of 1915 and 1935 respectively. They were busy building a gill net boat for this season's work, but dropped the tools to hear news of the school and their relations therein. So quickly did time fly that I had almost to fly, too, to get the boat and run 100 yards faster than I have moved for years. The steamer had freight and passengers for every cannery in Smith and Rivers Inlets so it was not until 2:30 a.m. on Friday that the ship's whistle blew for Bella Coola, but even such hours of arrival have their compensations, for I sat on the front steps of the Church in the village and watched a perfectly glorious sunrise splash gold on the glacial peaks on either side of the Bella Coola valley. Shortly after nine, accompanied by Inspector Barry and the Indian Agent, Mr. Fougner, we visited the village and the day school, where after a few words with the children, I left to look up the Missionary and then the ex-pupils. If I were to name all I met on the trip this letter would become a magazine, so I must just say I met them all and if I was glad to see them, I know they were glad to see someone from the old school and quite soon they were hot-foot after news. I was lucky to have with me photos of most of the present pupilage and the gift of these to the parents was a great joy. As one of them said, "It is almost as good as seeing them ourselves." The Missionary, Rev. G. Knox, warned me that the Young People's Association had asked that I speak at the Church that night, so after a visit to the Hospital, I went off for a walk towards the river to think things through, but had to go further afield as the olachun grease makers were just skimming off a boiling. As it is from this village that we get the olachun grease for the School, I strolled over later to see how they were getting on - they were doing fine. In spite of a nasty outbreak of 'flu in the village, the Church was filled that evening for a very enjoyable service made doubly pleasant for me by the sight of so many young people who in the past years have learned within these walls. The ushers and bell-ringers were all ex-pupils, and it was so encouraging to hear the Missionary speak of them as his right hand. But all good things must end, and so noon on Saturday saw us pulling out on the Agency launch, which under the skilful piloting of Constable Levelton was to be our home for a week's trip to Prince Rupert.

Saturday night was spent at Ocean Falls where I met and had a short talk with Bishop Rix of Caledonia Diocese, and after attending Matins on Sunday morning in the beautiful little Church in that busy paper-making town, we left for Bella Bella, in which village live scores and scores of our graduates. We were welcomed by the Missionary, Rev. W. R. Welch, and the entire rising generation of Bella Bella; then, accompanied by the odd dozen or so we made our way towards the Mission House for supper following which we went back to the wharf to meet the "Thomas Crosby", of the United Church Marine Hospital, on which ship I met Principal Scott of the Coqualeetza Residential School. He, like myself, was on a tour of the Indian villages in the interests of the Church and School, and it was a splendid gesture on the part of the Missionary that we should each be asked to preach a sermon at the evening service. We did, and perhaps our mutual friends will hope that in future, School Principals will not travel in couples. The following day passed with lightning speed, and into a very few hours were crowded interviews with the parents of children in St. Michael's; a check on new pupils; and a visit to the
school, where in this village as in many others, simply splendid work is being done under very difficult conditions. A visit to the Hospital and a quiet talk with the patients known to me, and then the journey started again and the good ship turned her bow towards Millbank Sound, which stretch of water can, under given circumstances, produce conditions that would devastate one's wildest imaginings. The Sound was fortunately, on its best behaviour, but the skipper decided to show us the inside channel and we turned in just below Ivory Light to calm waters, through channels deep and narrow, and scenery of indescribable beauty quite unknown to those who travel in steamers and tourist boats. Just as the sun went down we entered Jackson Passage where one could touch shore from either side of the boat, and two hours later saw us tied up at Klentu village. A visit to the Mission House and Church and an hour with ex-pupils, watching the girls' teams play basketball, completed the day, and we retired to our berths for the night. Next morning we were awakened to the noise of hammering, and going out on deck found the men of the village all busy building a deck and freight shed on their new wharf. As many of them had children in School, I stayed on the launch and they came down to see me about their youngsters' progress. Later on I visited the day school and at noon we once more cranked the willing engine and set off for Kitamaat, arriving the following day at noon.

In this village live some 250 Indian people; there is a United Church Mission and Residential School for 30 pupils and a day School. It seems rather isolated as they only get mail boats once a month, but they were all cheerful and busy with their tasks. We spent several happy hours among them, rowing out later into a beautiful moon-lit night to where the launch was anchored. Almost before sleep came to me at all, I heard the anchor being hoisted and we were off at 4 a.m., towards the Skeena River, via Hartley Bay, at which village we stopped for a couple of hours to inspect the day school and pay a call on the Missionary and his good wife. It is a long run up Gronville Channel, which seems to maintain the same width and straightness for hours on end, but eventually we saw the opening of the Skeena, one of the greatest salmon rivers of B.C., and at seven in the evening the engine slowed down at Claxton. Here occurred the only mishap of the trip - just as we were pulling into the wharf, the clutch chose that moment to break in two and we had a pleasant few minutes making a landing. Going ashore, I was delighted to meet some of the ex-pupils, especially Rogor and Leonard Mercer, and Claude Morven, all of whom are now happily married. We had a most enjoyable chat in the home of their father, Paul Mercer, a licensed lay reader of Caledonia Diocese and a graduate of this School in 1902. I was most impressed all through the trip with the large number of really happy marriages which have taken place between boy and girl ex-pupils. In only two cases did I find genuinely unhappy marriages, and in both cases the ex-pupil was married to a partner who had not been to school at all.

After repairs were completed next day, we moved up river to Port Essington where the Inspector had work in the day school. This town is, apart from some 100 Indians, almost entirely populated by Japanese, and I understand that in keeping with the Nationalist movement among these people, they are building a Buddhist Temple in
Essington. Our work completed, we finally reached Prince Rupert after calling at Cassiar and Inverness Canneries to see parents of pupils at present in the School. Here ended the first part of our journey and after bidding farewell to our genial skipper, we left the launch and embarked on the "Nanskeena" of the Prince Rupert Indian Agency, and on the following day set sail for the Naas River, via Port Simpson, with a population of 650 Indians, the largest village I believe, in B. C. We had with us in addition to the Inspector and Indian Agent, the Asst. Director of Medical Services for the Department of Indian Affairs in the person of Dr. McQuarrie, and I am more than grateful for the opportunity afforded for a long conference on the problem of T. B. control, and the educational opportunities of the Residential School in this work.

After a short call at Kincolith, we anchored for the night off the deserted cannery at Naas Harbour, and the following morning we once more changed boats, this time into a river boat in charge of Captain Stephen Clayton, a native of Gitlakdamix, under whose extremely skilful guidance we started the twelve hour trip up the Naas River, whose shallow waters and innumerable sand bars in the lower stages, and roaring canyons and rapids further up, were a challenge to the highest degree of skill and river lore. Captain Clayton's father was a river man before him, and Stephen had started to learn his trade of river pilot as a boy. On this trip his own son Silas, a fine strapping young man, was in the bow of the boat watching the river, making it part of his very being, so that in turn he, too, could follow in his father's steps. The boat was a thirty-foot tunnel craft with a 40 H.P. engine, built and equipped by the skipper himself. A stop was made at Fishery Bay, the old Indian camp of the Naas River people, where I met both parents and ex-pupils. Grease making was nearly completed, and I was glad to note that even in this camp in which the people would spend at most but two months of the year, they had built a splendid little Church, capable I suppose of seating 150 people. It was late that night, about eleven, when we saw the lights of the village of Gitlakdamix, to which village many years ago, the people had returned following the flood at Alyash Village started by the late Rev. J. B. McCullough of missionary fame. Tired after our long trip, we were more so after climbing the 89 steps up to the Mission House, but the very genuine welcome of Rev. and Mrs Kinley, and a bounteous supper soon put things to rights. As there was a phone from Gitlakdamix to the Big Canyon, word of our progress had gone before and the good missionary and his wife were ready with smiles (and Irish ones too), food, and restful beds. One could not ask for more, and we had a wonderful rest, fitting us all for our respective tasks on the morrow, when doctors examined the sick, the Inspector the schools, the Agent heard various and sundry delegations, and I went forth to find ex-pupils and parents. This village of 240 people is one of the best on the B. C. coast, wide streets and sidewalks, large halls for athletics and meetings, and one of the largest and most beautiful Churches one could visit anywhere. They also have a fine Church Army Hall, and in the tower of the Church a large illuminated clock which keeps the village on time. The houses are all fairly modern, though bad fishing seasons in the north have held back the building of as many new homes as I noticed further south. In Gitlakdamix and in Greenville, further down the
one would almost imagine that a town planning commission had been at work, so well and spaciously laid out are the homes, and there is a telephone in almost every house. It is more than evident that mighty solid foundations have been laid by those who pioneered the faith in these parts. At noon the flag was hoisted and an hour later we met the Council to discuss education. They appealed for a Residential School, and one can hardly blame them for they have not even got a day school, the teaching being done in a room in the Mission House by the Missionary who is, however, a qualified teacher. As there is no likelihood of further residential schools being built, I urged them to support their teacher, and send their children to school at the Mission House until such time as the Department can find the means of building a proper day school for them, but that the Residential School would help by taking in special cases where and whenever opportunity and vacancies permitted. Since writing this we are very glad to note that the Department has, in the supplementary estimates, sanctioned the building of a day school for this village.

After a two-day stay we once more set our faces toward the south, and the run down the river was accomplished in about four hours running time. There were, however, two villages to visit on the way down, Canyon City, perched up on the rocks in the middle of the Canyon, and Greenville. At Canyon City I met the Azak youngsters, Ernest, Percy and Dorothy, now all grown up to be fine young people. It was nice to hear such good reports of them from the missionary. This village lies opposite the Naas River lava beds, the volcano of which pushed the river five miles out of its course some 200 years ago. From the village one can see clear across the ten miles of lava to the mountains along which the river must have run in days gone by.

By noon we were off again, and in the afternoon we moored our craft at Greenville, a village about the same size as Gitlakdamix. We had not much time here, but managed to visit the missionary, Rev. W. Cooper, spend some time in the day school, attend a meeting of the Council at which the same plea for a Residential School was made and later we were all the guests of the Council and Village at a splendid banquet in the Town Hall, where we enjoyed a feast of spring salmon with all the trimmings. One could not have had a better cooked or more tastily served repast anywhere, and the good people must have gone to a lot of work to entertain us. I was especially impressed with the day school in this village, and urged the people to support it fully. At 6.30 p.m., as night was falling, we set out on the last stretch of our journey for the day, and at 22 miles per hour came down to Kincolith in black darkness and pouring rain across the sand-bars. At midnight the very welcome and hospitable roof of Dr. Macdonald's home at Kincolith was over our heads; our soaked clothing was changed and we were at peace. There is a fine day school in this village and it was a pleasure to once again meet Miss Aylwin, the teacher, who was on the teaching staff at St. Michael's some years ago. During the following day, I paid a call on the Missionary, Rev. O. Thorne and his wife, real veterans on the Nans. The good man was busy in his garden, one of the finest in the north and a great joy to him. Most of the people of Kincolith were away at the Canaries so we did not see much of them, but in Dr. and Mrs Macdonald and Rev. and Mrs Thorne they have real friends and helpers, who have all given a lifetime of service to the Nishga people.
The following morning saw us on our way south once again, with grateful thoughts for all who had so hospitably entertained and cared for us on our wanderings. Back in Prince Rupert to a long conference with the Agent and Inspector on school matters, and then off home on the steamer to our big family at Alert Bay.

One must make a trip such as this to know the worthwhileness thereof. The personal contact means so much, doesn't it? One ex-pupil, writing to one of the pupils in school after my return said "Mr. Anfield's visit meant so much to us all, it gave us new life to go on with." Putting aside the personal element, one can only say that it surely is our duty, who have these children in our hands for as long as ten years in some cases, to see that the link of friendship and trust is not broken by neglect. We owe it to our ex-pupils and the parents to visit the villages as often as possible, and I can assure you that our Indian Residential School Commission is both anxious and glad for such visits to be made. The improvement in the day schools is tremendous and this is a good sign indeed. The work of this School is clearly defined, and need never interfere with or overlap that of the day schools. We stand ready to help by taking children orphaned or neglected from any village; and also children from villages where there are no day schools and from villages where the day schools are overcrowded; and this School can be filled twice over with children from these groups alone.

This has been the longest letter yet, but I know many will be glad to get some little insight into the extent of the work undertaken by our Church for the Indian people on the coast of British Columbia.

With kindest regards and all good wishes,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

May 18th, 1936.
On October 11th I left Alert Bay on a business trip to Victoria and Vancouver and while there besides attending to Departmental business I attended the International Arts and Crafts Festival which was held at the Vancouver Hotel from the 14th to 17th inclusive. St. Michael's Indian Residential school at Alert Bay displayed the work done by the pupils during the past term, which created a great deal of interest amongst the people who visited the exhibit, and many genuine favourable comments were made as to the workmanship and Indian designs. Arrangements had been made by the Vancouver School Board whereby the children of the Vancouver schools were escorted by their teachers to visit the exhibit, and each day thousands passed through the building, and I am sure the work from our Indian school taking into consideration the ages of those doing the work was far superior to any work done by the same aged children in the white schools in Vancouver. We feel this is something really worth while as it gives us an opportunity to show the general public just what is being done by the Indian children at our schools.

M. S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Mr. F.E. Anfield, Principal of St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay, has written me in connection with plans for a celebration to be held here next year when all ex-pupils of the Residential School and other Indians on this coast will be invited to participate.

As next year is Coronation Year, and celebrations will be held throughout Canada, it is our desire that the Indians take part on this historic occasion and thus emphasize the relationship between our Indian people and the Crown.

Mr. Anfield and I have discussed plans for this event, and we feel it would be of great value to the Indians in many ways, but in order to carry out our programme it is necessary to have some financial help, and I am therefore writing the Department to see if they would be good enough to give us a grant of $300.00 to put on this Pageant of Empire in the interests of all Indians.

It will entail a great deal of work and money, but we feel if the Department would assist us in the amount requested, the celebration could be made a real success. The Indians along the coast have expressed a desire to attend, and it will no doubt be the only celebration put on in the interests of Indians on this coast. I would therefore kindly ask the Department to approve of this amount and advise me as soon as possible in order that our plans may be got under way.

Your obedient servant,

Your letter of February 10th, 1947, addressed to the Department regarding the need of repairs etc., at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, has been referred to this office.

The maintenance of government owned school buildings and equipment, is one that should receive the attention of the Indian Agent. I am unable to find anything in the Department's instructions issued to the Inspector of Schools, which indicates that responsibility in this respect devolves on him, although I am sure the Department would welcome information from the Inspector in this regard in cases of evident neglect.

The Department expects the Indian agent to discuss with the Principal, the matter of repairs and improvements necessary to maintain the buildings in proper condition, and make provision for the expenditures indicated in the annual agency estimates. It does not follow, however, that the Department will be in a position to approve the total expenditure involved, but it would be reasonable to expect that under normal conditions some of the work will be provided for. Repairs and improvements at the school should be carried out in so far as possible during the summer months, when the school is not in session.

You should confer with the Principal, Reverend S. J. Wickens, regarding the repairs that should be attended to this summer, advising this office of the cost involved in order that the matter may be placed before the Department for attention.

ALERT BAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

We have in the past received recommendations that the old classroom block at the above school be replaced when conditions improve. It is hoped that steps can now be formulated for the replacement of this classroom block.

The following proposals have been discussed with Major Mackay and are submitted for your comment and for action where necessary by Inspector Davey:

(1) That a four classroom block or larger be erected to replace the present classroom block building. The new classroom block would be similar to that at St. Catherine's Day School. A plan is being forwarded under separate cover.

(2) That this new building along with the four room day school now nearing completion be used by both the day and residential school pupils.

(3) That the teaching staff at this school be appointed entirely by the Department.

(4) That the present residential school be a hostel for those children who have to come from isolated reserves as at present. This hostel would be operated by the Church of England.

(5) That the hostel children attend the new day school on the same basis as the children from the village.
In other words, we are considering a somewhat similar set-up to that operated at the Fairbridge Farm School where the Provincial Department of Education operates a day school within the frame-work of the farm school. This proposal has been discussed with Mr. Todd and we would appreciate your views on this matter.

It should be realized that the above proposals constitute a departure from the present system and are in the nature of an experiment.

It is felt that Inspector Davey should make:

(a) Specific recommendation as to the size of the classroom block which would have to be erected. The plans forwarded are only a suggestion.

(b) Recommendation as to the most suitable site for the new building bearing in mind the location of the four classroom block now nearing completion.

The residential school pupils would, of course, attend on a full day basis. Provision should be made for eventually providing High School education for these children either by the Department or through co-operation with the Alert Bay School Board. The Department appointed principal would be in charge of both the proposed classroom block and the block now nearing completion. The Anglican Church would appoint a superintendent for the hostel.

The above proposals have not yet been discussed with the Indian School Administration of the Missionary Society of the Church of England.

BFN/HH.

Director.

Minimum Wage Order No. 52 (1946)

Enclosed herewith please find correspondence received by the Director of Indian Affairs from Major General G. R. Turner of the M.S.C.O. This correspondence, it will be noted, relates to the application of the Minimum Wage Order No. 52 of the Province of British Columbia to the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. This school was built and equipped by this Department, from appropriation, and is maintained from year to year by per capita grants also provided from appropriation.

The balance of the funds required, which is considerable, is provided "by missionary contributions of various church congregations throughout Canada". This statement does not apply to this school in question as the said per capita grants pay the salaries of all staff including the teachers.

Please advise if, under the circumstances, the Minimum Wage Order No. 52 of the Province of British Columbia applies

(a) to the employees of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School which is operated entirely on per capita grants furnished from appropriation, or

(b) to employees of other Indian Residential Schools where the employees are paid partly by per capita grant from appropriation and partly from funds provided by missionary contributions of various church congregations throughout Canada.

If you are of opinion that in either or both of the above two cases this Minimum Wage Order applies the charge upon public funds in cases of this kind will, by necessity, be greatly increased.

Dear Doctor Keenleyside:

Re: Enforcement of the Indian Act in British Columbia

1. Please refer to your letter of the 7th of November, 1947, addressed to Gordon S. Wismer, Attorney General, and the latter's reply of the 3rd of December, 1947.

2. In accordance with Mr. Wismer's suggestion, I communicated with Commissioner Shirres of the British Columbia Police. Copies of correspondence in this connection have been forwarded to Mr. R.A. Hoey, Director of Indian Affairs Branch, under date of the 8th of December, 1947. Particular reference is made in the above correspondence to those sections of the Act having to deal with the illegal sale, consumption, etc., of liquor by Indians.

3. We pointed out at that time that an old Order-in-Council was still in effect under which responsibility for enforcement of the Act rested upon the Provincial authorities, and the fines collected in relation to liquor offences go to the Treasurer of that Province.

4. It has recently been necessary for me to survey some of the work the Force is doing with a view to effecting some economies in manpower. In that survey I found that among other things we carry out certain work in and about Vancouver in relation to the enforcement of the Indian Act which employs one man full time and another part time. For the period from April 1st, 1947, to March 1st, 1948, this effort resulted in 134 convictions for violations of the Act, of which all but 13 pertained to liquor offences. I am informed also that the fines collected are eventually credited to the City Treasurer in Vancouver and do not go to the Province, also that the Provincial Police do not undertake any work of this sort in Vancouver.

5. Our Officer Commanding at Vancouver - Supt. J. Healey - has been in touch with your Commissioner, Mr. Arnell, and with Mr. Taylor, the Indian Agent at Vancouver. There is apparently some dissatisfaction with the general enforcement arrangement.

6. I feel that until the policy is altered by Order-in-Council this Force should take no part in the matter and should restrict its activities to assisting the British Columbia Provincial Police when that Force asks for our help. I am loath to permit a situation to continue which might cause some confusion as to the actual division of responsibility.

7. As matters stand now the British Columbia Provincial Police are responsible for the enforcement of the Indian Act in that province and the fines should go to the Provincial Treasurer. If the policy is to be changed, I submit that the old Order-in-Council would have to be cancelled, and if this is done the R.C.M.P. Police detachments would have to be strengthened very materially and, in fact, new ones might have to be opened. This I am prepared to do.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) S.T. Wood
(S.T. Wood)
Commissioner.

Doctor H.L. Keenleyside,
Deputy Minister,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Alert Bay Residential School

I refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of March 2nd concerning the construction of a four room classroom block at the above mentioned school and the suggested combination of the academic work for the Day and Residential Schools at Alert Bay.

Mr. Hoey has asked for a definite recommendation from me regarding the size of the block and the site.

Size:

In addition to the four room block just completed, six classrooms are required to accommodate the expected combined enrolment of the Day and Residential Schools of 320 pupils. There are three ways of providing these six classrooms:

(1) The construction of a new four room block and the use of the two classrooms in the Residential School building for primary classes. These rooms are excellent for classroom purposes and would also obviate the primary children walking in inclement weather to the combined school from the Residential School and would also reduce the distance which the junior pupils would have to walk from the more distant parts of the reserve.

(2) The construction of a four room block with manual training and domestic science in the basement and the use of the building to be constructed from the materials at the Port Hardy Army Camp which was originally planned for use as domestic science and manual training for two additional classrooms.

(3) Construct a six room classroom block and use the vocational training building as originally planned. This would provide
ample play space in the basement when the weather is not favourable for the pupils to play on the school grounds.

Of these three suggestions I favour the second plan because:

(a) It would avoid any possible friction due to the presence of pupils in the dormitory building who do not normally come under the control of the person in charge of that building.

(b) Because it would simplify the problem of administration by having all of the classrooms centralized.

The third suggestion I do not favour because the advantages hardly seem commensurate with the additional cost.

Site:

You will recall that when we visited Alert Bay we were in agreement with Mr. Indian Agent Todd that the new classroom block should be constructed on lot 23, on the west side of the road and across from the new Day School building.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.

Dear Commissioner Wood:

This will acknowledge your letter of March 19th addressed to the Deputy Minister re enforcement of the Indian Act in British Columbia, which has been referred to me for attention.

The copies of correspondence referred to in your paragraph 2 have been reviewed carefully.

As you intimated to the Attorney-General, the Order in Council P.C.2535 with amendments dated December 11th, 1890, whereby the Province undertakes Indian Act enforcement and receives the fines imposed under the Indian Act, is still in effect.

On the whole the arrangement made between the Dominion and the Province under this Order in Council has worked out reasonably well over a long period of years. I believe you will agree with me when I say that in any co-ordination of law enforcement work as between the Dominion and a province, occasional local difficulties and problems are bound to arise from time to time. We have had our share of these, but it has always been possible to find a solution through consolidation and co-operation with the Provincial authorities. In the present instance, I feel satisfied after reading a letter of November 10th from Commissioner Shirras to you, that the situation will receive proper consideration and attention from the Provincial authorities responsible for law enforcement. The specialized control problems that have arisen in recent years in the Prince Rupert area are difficult.

On this subject in a report dated January 20th, 1948, the Indian Agent for the Skeena River Indian Agency whose critical observations concerning the work of the British Columbia police gave rise to the present correspondence, has this to say:

"In the City of Prince Rupert, the sum of $10,178.00 was paid in police court fines on all charges in 1947. In the same year, 196 natives were convicted of offences under the Indian Act, paying fines totalling $2,612.25 and serving 731 days imprisonment.

A total of 102 suppliers were charged, of whom 96 were convicted paying a total of $4,425.00 in fines.

In the year, the number of Indians charged decreased over previous years, whilst the number of suppliers charged and convicted

........ increased
increased, due to a real effort by the B.C. Police to cope with the Indian liquor problem. A lot of credit is due Sgt. L. Potterton, I/c Prince Rupert City Detachment of the British Columbia Police, for this increased activity.

The liquor situation on the Reserves is serious, particularly on the Nass River where the natives can bring in liquor from the American side. It should be noted that apart from the "P.M.L. 15", there is no organized police protection on any reserve in the Agency. Native constables, without supervision, are of no real value."

This seems to be an encouraging indication of improved enforcement efforts in Prince Rupert, although unsatisfactory on the reserves.

After mature consideration and discussion with the senior officials, who have followed the problem on the ground over a long period, the conclusion has been reached that it would not be advisable at this time to undertake a major change in policy involving the rescinding of the Order in Council governing the agreement between the Dominion and the Province as mentioned in your paragraph 6.

At the same time, I should like to say that this Department greatly appreciates your offer to increase your establishment if necessary in British Columbia, and information is being sought as to where this might be done with advantage to both forces.

Dear Mr. Wismer:

I had hoped to have the pleasure of calling on you during my recent visit to Victoria but unfortunately for me you were out of town during the three days of my visit. I am now taking the liberty of writing you to mention a matter that has recently been giving me and the members of the Department of Mines and Resources some concern. I am writing to you personally as the suggestion I have to make is a little out of my field and I do not wish to interfere with the official responsibilities of others.

When I was in Prince Rupert ten days ago I found that the liquor situation there as it affected the Indian population in the city and in the Skeena Valley seemed to be pretty much out of hand. The local Provincial Constables were doing their best but were finding it difficult to get time to handle this matter in addition to their other responsibilities. The same situation existed with regard to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Post in Prince Rupert.

It has occurred to me that this situation might perhaps be more effectively handled if a Provincial constable of Indian race (preferably a Haida or Tsimtslaim) could be appointed and sent into the district in order to handle this particular problem. It might be easier for such a man to discover just how widespread the bootlegging is and to take effective action against both the Indians and Whites concerned. It would moreover do something for Indian morale for one of their people to be given the dignity of membership in the Provincial Police and the responsibility of applying the law to the White residents of the area as well as to the Indian population.

I don't know how this idea may appeal to you but I think perhaps it might be worth considering and Commissioner Parsons who knows the Indians very well indeed might be prepared to express an opinion in regard to it.

Editor, The Sun: Sir,—Apropos the recent letter of Rev. Canon C. F. Hives, "The Work of One Indian School." I would inform that I have had some contact with St. Michael's Indian Residential School at Alert Bay, B.C., back in the '30s and knowing how that institution was conducted during that time and, since returning from overseas, having heard of the difficulties now experienced by the Columbia Coast Mission in financing. Edmonton Girl Works With Indian Children

Indian Children Lovable, Natural, Adapt Themselves to Learning

When Betty Kingsett left Edmonton for Alert Bay, B.C., last January, she probably didn't imagine herself president of an Anglican Young People's group of 25 members, all Indians except herself and another white girl. Yet, that's what she is today when she returns.

Miss Kingsett is on the staff of St. Michael's Indian Residential School at Alert Bay, 200 miles north of Vancouver, and she is back here for two weeks.

Finding her work intensely interesting, she loves the children, who range in age from 6 to 16 and follow her around like little puppy dogs. "They need help, but love them," she says. "They are all so affectionate and natural."

Despite the fact that she would rather have a group of Indians children to manage than any others, she explained that they are not spoiled or extravagant and make no fuss about things like having inoculations or taking medicine.

Indian children are quick at learning and if given the same chance could equal white children, according to Miss Kingsett. The big trouble, she says, is that their environment is backward and antiquated and they don't learn the little things that are basic to a white child is taught.

Education and a feeling of equality with white people are what the Indians need most in Miss Kingsett's opinion. One example of this was accomplished by that of a young Indian boy, a graduate of the school, who is now doing his last year of law at university.

There is a farm in connection with the school where the boys receive agricultural instruction. Many of the older girls want to be nurses and teachers. A lot of their spare time is taken up with Girl Guide activities.

A shortage of staff at the school makes it necessary for persons to be employed to do anything including nursing. During a recent flu epidemic, there were 120 children in hospital. Miss Kingsett. There are 220 at the school.

A well-known singer, when she was in Edmonton, Miss Kingsett has started a choir at the school. She finds that music and stories will keep the children satisfied for hours even the 68 small boys in her Sunday school class.

Some of the native people know few of the war chants and songs but they can sometimes be coaxed to perform the native dances.

MEMORANDUM

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From: The Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.

Re: Alert Bay Residential School

I refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of September 26th concerning the report of Mr. Todd on the above mentioned school.

It is quite obvious from Mr. Todd's letter that the above-mentioned school is far from operating efficiently, in spite of some improvement. It would appear that Mr. Todd's criticism is based on two things. First, the failure of the school to obtain qualified teachers and second, the unsatisfactory service of the engineer, Mr. W.P. McNeill. To my mind there are three contributing factors which make it difficult for this school to secure satisfactory staff. The first of these is the school's inability to operate on the grant and consequently pays salaries insufficiently high to attract good staff members. The second factor is the unsavory reputation which this school has acquired in the last three years. The third factor is the deplorable working conditions at the school. Two of the classes are held in an old condemned building locally known as the "old girls' home". The principal informs me that the roof of this building leaks so badly that it has been necessary for him to discontinue classes on several occasions during the current academic year, and it is also impossible to keep these class-rooms warm. The main building, as the Department knows, is not kept sufficiently warm for the staff members. This has resulted in both illness and resignations. I understand however, that the Department has already advertised for tenders for the necessary repairs to the heating system. It was also planned to construct a class-room block to permit the abandonment and dismantling of the old building formerly used as a residence for girls.

It might be interesting to contrast the policy of administration of the Alert Bay School with that of the school at Alberni. The primary concern at Alert Bay appears to be to operate the school within the budget, whereas at Alberni
the policy is to operate the school efficiently and give first consideration to the welfare of the children. The Alberni Residential School has adhered to this policy in spite of the fact that it has not been able to finance the operation of the school within the funds made available by government grants. In the last year the Alberni School received a loan of $5000.00 from the United Church.

R.F. Davey

In reply to your letter of September 1st last, file #6-11-2, the Rev. J. E. Allsopp, Principal of Alert Bay Indian Residential School has forwarded me a list of present employees at that institution showing their respective positions, net salary, value of board and living accommodation and gross salary.

You will please note there are two vacancies in the present set-up of the staff: Manual Training Instructor and Intermediate Teacher. I have had a chat with Mr. Allsopp this morning and he informs me he is going to Vancouver to-morrow with a view to try and get a teacher to fill the intermediate room. He is also going to discuss the matter with yourself. Mr. Allsopp informs me he has had several opportunities to employ teachers but they refuse to accept a position there at the salary offered. This is the reason why one classroom is without a teacher.

It is also noted that both the senior and junior teachers are not qualified. They are only working under a permit.

It has always been my understanding that the fundamental function of a Residential School is education. Here we have over two hundred children in residence for that purpose. The M.S.C.C. evidently cannot obtain qualified teachers because they refuse to pay adequate salaries, with the result this school has only one certified teacher, two teachers teaching under permits and one classroom with no teacher. The same applies to the Manual Training. In other words we only have one qualified teacher for this school of over two hundred pupils.

This seems to me a very serious situation and one which should be rectified forthwith. To make a comparison with the salaries paid at the Residential School and those paid at our Indian Day Schools, I will give you one example. If Mrs. K. Bridge, primary teacher in the Residential School, who holds a second-class certificate, was paid under the same schedule as Day School teachers she would be getting 150% more salary. It is no wonder the M.S.C.C. cannot find teachers who will work for the disgraceful salaries they pay them!

p.t.o.
The result appears to be that the Department is still allowing this Residential School to operate as a hostel rather than an educational institution, and the children's education cannot help but suffer. I am dwelling on this because I think the time is overdue when the Department must insist that the M.S.C.C. appoint certified teachers and pay the same salaries as paid Day School teachers; and failing this, the Department should assume the responsibility of appointing qualified teachers and paying them direct, just the same as Indian Day Schools. This applies to Manual Training as well.

I should like to refer to Mr. W. P. McNeill, whom the M.S.C.C. have employed as an engineer. Several reports in respect to the services and qualifications of this employee have been made previously. I am informed he tried to write off his fourth-class papers this year but was not allowed to sit for the exam on the grounds that he had not had sufficient experience. I must again point out to the Department that the Government have a very large investment in valuable, important equipment installed in this school, all of which comes under the supervision of Mr. McNeill. In my opinion as well as others, in a better position than I, who are conversant with the needs of a proper engineer, feel that a qualified engineer should be appointed in charge of this equipment, otherwise we are going to be faced with endless repair bills and finally replacement of equipment which will be of major proportion.

Alert Bay Residential School has almost the same equipment as the old Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, Sardis, now under the administration of the Department of National Health and Welfare. Here at Alert Bay we have a man in charge of similar equipment who cannot obtain his fourth-class papers, receiving a net salary of $72.50 with a gross salary of $132.50; as compared to the present staff at Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, Sardis, where they have a Chief Engineer and either two or three Assistants. I am given to understand the Chief's salary is $215.00 a month, and his Assistants' starting at $165.00, graduating to $190.00 a month. Surely there must be something wrong!

I would feel satisfied myself if we had one good qualified engineer, someone who could and would take care of our equipment and do ordinary maintenance work. How long is this situation going to continue?

I am satisfied that the Rev. J. E. Allsopp cannot do otherwise than carry out his instructions from the M.S.C.C. in respect to staff salaries. Therefore, no blame can be attached to him in this respect.

The Department must not overlook the fact that this school is now twenty years old and requires more maintenance work than when it was originally built. Even in early days we had good qualified engineers when maintenance work was at a minimum.

p.t.o.
The evident policy of retrenchment by the M.S.C.C. through employment of inefficient help is slowly but surely costing the Department large sums of money for repairs and replacement. In my opinion we have two major situations to deal with:

(1) Employ a qualified engineer who can do maintenance work and give proper care to equipment.

(2) Employ qualified teachers in every department.

Other minor problems can be dealt with locally.

I am writing at some length as we are doing everything possible to put this Residential School back to enjoy the same good administration as it did years ago.

(M. S. Todd)

MEMORANDUM TO ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER:

Alert Bay Indian Residential School

Two years ago the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada agreed to have the children from the above-named Residential School educated at the Alert Bay Indian Day School. We have gradually been providing sufficient accommodation at the Alert Bay Indian Day School to carry out this agreement.

Two years ago a four-classroom block was provided from buildings secured through War Assets Corporation from the Fort Hardy Military Camp. A two-classroom building from the same source is to be provided this summer.

It is planned to erect another four-classroom block this year, but to date plans have not yet been completed.

In accordance with our agreement with the Church of England, it is therefore recommended that the Department take over the payment of the salaries of the three remaining teachers at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. This will mean nine divisions being operated with approximately three hundred and sixty pupils. About two hundred will come from the Residential School and the remaining one hundred and sixty will come from the Alert Bay Indian Village.

This will provide a unified system of education at Alert Bay and will ensure a better calibre of teachers.
The Residential School teachers have been resigning regularly each year due to the higher salaries, better working conditions and superannuation benefits which can be obtained in teaching in Indian Day Schools.

I would recommend, therefore, that the Acting Minister grant authority in the usual way for the payment of salaries of these teachers at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. It is anticipated that the salaries involved will amount to about $6,500.00 a teaching year.

Acting Director.

Recommended.

Acting Deputy Minister.

Approved.

Acting Minister.

MEMORANDUM

TO: Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C.

FROM: Mr. R. F. Davey, District Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

Re: Consolidation of Classroom Work,
Alert Bay Day and Residential Schools.

With reference to Canon Cook's letter of July 12th, to Mr. Neary, I was very surprised by the tone of this letter, particularly in view of the events which preceded Mr. Allsopp's conversation with Mr. Cook. On June 24th, I made a special trip to Alert Bay in order to arrange the details necessary before any consolidation could take place and on the evening of June 26th, I met with the two Principals and Mr. Todd so that a full discussion could take place with respect to the arrangements. At this meeting there was complete accord on all proposals except one. This point was raised by Mr. Allsopp and was with respect to the observance of Days of "Obligation". Mr. Allsopp wished that the pupils in residence at his school should be permitted to observe three days and be granted leave from classroom work for the whole or part of these days. I stated that I did not believe it was the Department's policy to grant leave to Protestant children on such occasions. I further stated that I felt that since the classroom work would take only five hours of the day there was ample opportunity for the Residential School to give whatever religious instruction the Principal thought necessary outside of classroom hours. Mr. Allsopp stated that it was probable that such an arrangement could be made but he was unwilling to make an adjustment in the routine of his school when he knew that the Roman Catholic Church received these privileges.

After a discussion of probably ten or fifteen minutes, in which only Mr. Allsopp and myself participated, Mr. Todd suggested that, after all, this was a matter of policy which should be decided by the Department rather than at the meeting. With this I concurred. This seemed to be a reasonable solution to the impasse which had developed and I was certainly under the impression that Mr. Allsopp was quite content to have the matter left to the Department. I wish to repeat that this was the only point upon which there appeared to be a difference of opinion and also that the discussion was entirely between myself and the Principal of the Residential School, aside from the final suggestion by Mr. Todd. At no time did Mrs. Scanlon enter into the discussion.
In view of the above, I am at a loss to understand Canon Cook's statement: "Mr. Todd apparently is taking the attitude that he and Mrs. Scanlon are going to be in full control of the activities of the children and that St. Michaels will simply be a place where they eat and sleep".

In order that the Department may be fully informed, I shall outline all of the decisions which were made at this meeting on June 26:

1. It was decided that as a temporary arrangement three classrooms would be held in rooms made available by the Residential School.

2. The assignment of Teachers to the rooms and grades was made.

3. Mr. Allsopp agreed to provide living accommodation for two teachers, namely, Mrs. Lamperson and Mrs. Bridge. The amount of board and lodging was to be set by the Principal of the Residential School at a figure which would be fair and reasonable.

4. The pupils from the Residential School would be escorted to and from the Residential School.

5. A report would be provided by the Residential School each morning of the absentees of Residential School pupils.

6. The Classroom Teachers would report each morning to the Principal of the Day School any absentees from their classes.

7. In order to permit ample time for the Residential School children to return to the Residence for the lunch hour, the morning session would be closed at 11:45 and the afternoon session would open at 1:15. The afternoon session would end at 3:30. This adjustment in hours was to be tried to see if the hour and a half lunch period was suitable.

8. No child was to be detained more than thirty minutes after school and no child in the Primary grades (Grades 1 to 3) was to be detained at all.

9. Teachers detaining children in Grades 4 to 8 were to report such detentions to the Day School Principal so that the Residential School would be informed.

10. Teachers in classrooms at the Residential School were to
share the responsibility of supervision of the Day School pupils in the lunchrooms and playgrounds at noon and recess.

11. The Principal of the Day School would be responsible for the grading and grouping of pupils.

12. All village children would report to the Day School for class assignment on the first day of school.

13. The matter of the observance of Days of Holy Obligation would be referred to the Department for a decision.

14. Copies of these arrangements were to be duplicated and copies sent to the Principal of the Day School, the Principal of the Residential School, the Indian Superintendent and to each of the Teachers.

---

You will note from the above that at no time was there any suggestion that the enrollment of pupils from the Residential School at the Day School implied that the Day School Principal would exercise any authority over the pupils once the normal classroom day had ended, nor is there any suggestion that the Principal of the Residential School should interfere with the operation of the Day School. If Mr. Allsopp felt that there was any attempt at interference with his authority or responsibilities, he certainly did not say so in my presence. I am confident that there was no wish on the part of either Mrs. Scanlon or Mr. Todd to do so. Surely Mr. Allsopp is not suggesting that he should control the operation of the Day School, particularly in view of the very inefficient manner in which the classroom work has been conducted in his school in the past three and a half years. I am at a loss to understand what Canon Cook means in his sentence: "In their zeal to 'secularize' the school system there is grave danger that Mr. Todd, Mrs. Scanlon and the School Inspector are going to overlook the fact that the children in the Day School from St. Michaels are still residential school children". If he means that I feel that children from the Residential School in attendance at the Day School should conform with Day School regulations, he is quite correct.

I take very strong objection to the implication in the third paragraph of Canon Cook's letter that the Day School has not a good standard of discipline; in fact, the Alert Bay Day School has made a very great contribution to the improvement of the behaviour of the children in Alert Bay. Unfortunately, a similar statement cannot be
made with respect to the Residential School. I have no hesitation in saying that the Alert Bay Day School is the most efficiently operated Indian Day School in British Columbia and compares very favorably with Provincial schools.

Canon Cook makes inquiry concerning religious instruction. It has not been the practice of the Alert Bay Day School to devote 25 minutes per day to religious instruction as is permitted by Departmental regulations, but I know that the Day School has made a considerable contribution in the way of moral instruction and character building through the efforts of the teachers. There is no reason why the Residential School should not follow the practice that is general in many Residential Schools of holding a brief religious period before the commencement of the classroom day or in the evenings, which I understand is the time set aside at the Alert Bay Residential School for prayers.

Canon Cook asks: "Our handicrafts have played an important part in school life and this year an exhibit has been sent to Victoria - is this to be forfeited?". Some time ago I was asked by Mr. Allsopp whether the Residential School would be permitted to retain the tools now used at the Residential School for Industrial Arts. I informed him that as far as I was concerned I could see no objection to such an arrangement and I was fairly confident that the Department would permit this. I certainly do not feel that the Residential School should dictate to the Day School the program that should be instigated or interfere with Industrial Arts program which we are able to establish at the Day School.

I regret that it is not possible for me to sit down with Canon Cook, Mr. Allsopp and Mr. Neary for a discussion of this whole matter, but I cannot help but feel that this problem has assumed proportions quite beyond what is warranted. It is possible that Canon Cook gained an impression from Mr. Allsopp which the Reverend Principal did not wish to give.

R. F. Davey,

Dear Colonel Neary: Re: St. Michael's School, Alert Bay

In conversation with Principal Allsopp, after our visit with you, (It's a pity it was not discussed when we were with you) he brought up the matter of co-operation between the St. Michael's School authorities and the day school authorities at Alert Bay when the experiment of having the residential school children attend day school classes goes into practice.

In their zeal to "secularize" the school system there is grave danger that Mr. Todd, Mrs. Scanlon and the School Inspector are going to overlook the fact that the children in the day school from St. Michaels are still residential school children. Mr. Todd apparently is taking the attitude that he and Mrs. Scanlon are going to be in full control over the activities of the children and that St. Michaels will simply be the place where they eat and sleep. Such an attitude is altogether different from I.S.A. understanding of the experiment.

It must be remembered that through the years the Church of England has expended thousands of dollars and the labors of many of its adherents at St. Michaels in an effort to give the children a Christian upbringing and help them to adjust to changing conditions. If the control of the children is going to be taken out of the hands of the Principal the experiment is doomed to failure before it begins. We are willing to cooperate most certainly and fully expect to have to make many adjustments in residential school life but if the St. Michaels children are going to be allowed to become undisciplined youngsters such as the village children now are the whole purpose of the Church maintaining workers at St. Michaels is lost.

As in the Roman Church - we too have days of obligation - is the observance of these special days to be discontinued? St. Michael's Day has, since the founding of

What about religious instruction - is time in the curriculum to be allowed for this? We realize that because of this experiment we shall have to concentrate more and more on extra curricular and evening activities largely to overcome the influences the children will experience in their association with the village children. This letter is not meant to be a stumbling block in the way of progress - not by any means but simply to show how problems will arise unless all parties concerned have a firm understanding of the whole purpose and conduct of the experiment.

MEMORANDUM

TO: Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C.

FROM: Mr. R. F. Davey, District Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

Re: Consolidation of Classroom Work,
Alert Bay Day and Residential Schools.

With reference to Canon Cook's letter of July 12th, to Mr. Neary, I was very surprised by the tone of this letter, particularly in view of the events which preceded Mr. Allsopp's conversation with Mr. Cook. On June 24th, I made a special trip to Alert Bay in order to arrange the details necessary before any consolidation could take place and on the evening of June 26th, I met with the two Principals and Mr. Todd so that a full discussion could take place with respect to the arrangements. At this meeting there was complete accord on all proposals except one. This point was raised by Mr. Allsopp and was with respect to the observance of Days of "Obligation". Mr. Allsopp wished that the pupils in residence at his school should be permitted to observe three days and be granted leave from classroom work for the whole or part of these days. I stated that I did not believe it was the Department's policy to grant leave to Protestant children on such occasions. I further stated that I felt that since the classroom work would take only five hours of the day there was ample opportunity for the Residential School to give whatever religious instruction the Principal thought necessary outside of classroom hours. Mr. Allsopp stated that it was probable that such an arrangement could be made but he was unwilling to make an adjustment in the routine of his school when he knew that the Roman Catholic Church received these privileges.

After a discussion of probably ten or fifteen minutes, in which only Mr. Allsopp and myself participated, Mr. Todd suggested that, after all, this was a matter of policy which should be decided by the Department rather than at the meeting. With this I concurred. This seemed to be a reasonable solution to the impasse which had developed and I was certainly under the impression that Mr. Allsopp was quite content to have the matter left to the Department. I wish to repeat that this was the only point upon which there appeared to be a difference of opinion and also that the discussion was entirely between myself and the Principal of the Residential School, aside from the final suggestion by Mr. Todd. At no time did Mrs. Scanlon enter into the discussion.
In view of the above, I am at a loss to understand Canon Cook's statement: "Mr. Todd apparently is taking the attitude that he and Mrs. Scanlon are going to be in full control of the activities of the children and that St. Michaels will simply be a place where they eat and sleep".

In order that the Department may be fully informed, I shall outline all of the decisions which were made at this meeting on June 26:

1. It was decided that as a temporary arrangement three classrooms would be held in rooms made available by the Residential School.

2. The assignment of Teachers to the rooms and grades was made.

3. Mr. Allsopp agreed to provide living accommodation for two teachers, namely, Mrs. Lamperson and Mrs. Bridge. The amount of board and lodging was to be set by the Principal of the Residential School at a figure which would be fair and reasonable.

4. The pupils from the Residential School would be escorted to and from the Residential School.

5. A report would be provided by the Residential School each morning of the absentees of Residential School pupils.

6. The Classroom Teachers would report each morning to the Principal of the Day School any absentees from their classes.

7. In order to permit ample time for the Residential School children to return to the Residence for the lunch hour, the morning session would be closed at 11:45 and the afternoon session would open at 1:15. The afternoon session would end at 3:30. This adjustment in hours was to be tried to see if the hour and a half lunch period was suitable.

8. No child was to be detained more than thirty minutes after school and no child in the Primary grades (Grades 1 to 3) was to be detained at all.

9. Teachers detaining children in Grades 4 to 8 were to report such detentions to the Day School Principal so that the Residential School would be informed.

10. Teachers in classrooms at the Residential School were to
share the responsibility of supervision of the Day School pupils in the lunchrooms and playgrounds at noon and recess.

11. The Principal of the Day School would be responsible for the grading and grouping of pupils.

12. All village children would report to the Day School for class assignment on the first day of school.

13. The matter of the observance of Days of Holy Obligation would be referred to the Department for a decision.

14. Copies of these arrangements were to be duplicated and copies sent to the Principal of the Day School, the Principal of the Residential School, the Indian Superintendent and to each of the Teachers.

---

You will note from the above that at no time was there any suggestion that the enrollment of pupils from the Residential School at the Day School implied that the Day School Principal would exercise any authority over the pupils once the normal classroom day had ended, nor is there any suggestion that the Principal of the Residential School should interfere with the operation of the Day School. If Mr. Allsopp felt that there was any attempt at interference with his authority or responsibilities, he certainly did not say so in my presence. I am confident that there was no wish on the part of either Mrs. Scanlon or Mr. Todd to do so. Surely Mr. Allsopp is not suggesting that he should control the operation of the Day School, particularly in view of the very inefficient manner in which the classroom work has been conducted in his school in the past three and a half years. I am at a loss to understand what Canon Cook means in his sentence: "In their zeal to 'secularize' the school system there is grave danger that Mr. Todd, Mrs. Scanlon and the School Inspector are going to overlook the fact that the children in the Day School from St. Michaels are still residential school children". If he means that I feel that children from the Residential School in attendance at the Day School should conform with Day School regulations, he is quite correct.

I take very strong objection to the implication in the third paragraph of Canon Cook's letter that the Day School has not a good standard of discipline; in fact, the Alert Bay Day School has made a very great contribution to the improvement of the behaviour of the children in Alert Bay. Unfortunately, a similar statement cannot be
made with respect to the Residential School. I have no hesitation in saying that the Alert Bay Day School is the most efficiently operated Indian Day School in British Columbia and compares very favorably with Provincial schools.

Canon Cook makes inquiry concerning religious instruction. It has not been the practice of the Alert Bay Day School to devote 25 minutes per day to religious instruction as is permitted by Departmental regulations, but I know that the Day School has made a considerable contribution in the way of moral instruction and character building through the efforts of the teachers. There is no reason why the Residential School should not follow the practice that is general in many Residential Schools of holding a brief religious period before the commencement of the classroom day or in the evenings, which I understand is the time set aside at the Alert Bay Residential School for prayers.

Canon Cook asks: "Our handicrafts have played an important part in school life and this year an exhibit has been sent to Victoria - is this to be forfeited?". Some time ago I was asked by Mr. Allsopp whether the Residential School would be permitted to retain the tools now used at the Residential School for Industrial Arts. I informed him that as far as I was concerned I could see no objection to such an arrangement and I was fairly confident that the Department would permit this. I certainly do not feel that the Residential School should dictate to the Day School the program that should be initiated or interfere with Industrial Arts program which we are able to establish at the Day School.

I regret that it is not possible for me to sit down with Canon Cook, Mr. Allsopp and Mr. Neary for a discussion of this whole matter, but I cannot help but feel that this problem has assumed proportions quite beyond what is warranted. It is possible that Canon Cook gained an impression from Mr. Allsopp which the Reverend Principal did not wish to give.

R. F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

MEMORANDUM - Mr. W. S. Arneil:

Re: Consolidation Classroom Work,
Alert Bay Day and Residential Schools.

On September 17, 18, 20 and 21 I visited the Alert Bay Day and Residential Schools in order to make an assessment of the effect of consolidating the classroom work of the two schools. In spite of some unavoidable difficulties occasioned by the recent railway strike and the late arrival of teachers, this scheme has gone into effect with less difficulty than I had anticipated. These minor difficulties were overcome quite quickly and I was impressed with the smoothness with which the scheme was going forward. The calibre of the teaching staff is good, the movement of children from the Residence to the Day School is taking place without friction, the classroom facilities, although inadequate at the present time, are far superior to the arrangement which prevailed at the Residential School in preceding years. Both the Principal of the Residential School and the Matron have stated that far fewer difficulties have arisen than they had anticipated. I am sure this scheme will be even more effective when the new classroom block is provided, which will give adequate classroom space and relieve the crowded conditions which now prevail in the Residential School and also lighten the teaching load.

The Principal of the Residential School informs me that his staff is overworked at the moment because of two staff vacancies. In spite of this, my observation of the Residential School indicates that conditions there are much better than they have been since 1947 when I first visited the Residential School. In addition, all of the pupils are attending class on a full day basis under competent teachers. A review of my reports indicate that in both these respects there has been a very marked improvement. The general tone of the children's behaviour has also greatly improved.
The chief difficulty is the failure of the two schools to coordinate their extra curricular work. This point was discussed at a meeting of the two Principals and Mr. Superintendent Todd. At this time I expressed the belief that there was no reason why there should not be more co-operative work and both Principals have agreed to try and work out a program which would make fuller use of the recreational facilities at both schools. I cannot help but feel that part of this difficulty is occasioned by something less than full confidence on the part of the Principal of the Residential School in this experiment. I do not wish to imply that the Rev. Principal has not made some effort to be co-operative, quite the reverse is true, but it was evident that he wished to retain as much control as possible over his pupils and seemed to resent the loss which had already taken place. I feel confident, however, that as time goes on the effectiveness of the experiment will convince Mr. Allsopp that the scheme is practical and that there is no loss in moral instruction and character building.

The primary weakness appears to be the lack of an over-all authority to control and co-ordinate the work. I am hopeful that this deficiency will be minimized by the full co-operation of both schools.

The use of three rooms at the Residential School and the shortage of staff at the Residence has placed an unfair load on Mr. Allsopp and I should like to state that he has in this respect been the most co-operative and most understanding.

Although it is somewhat early to make a complete assessment as to how effective this scheme will be, there is no doubt that it has already made a marked improvement in the efficiency of the educational program at Alert Bay.

Memorandum to

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Alert Bay Indian Residential School

Two years ago the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada agreed to have the children from the above-named Residential School educated at the Alert Bay Indian Day School. We have gradually been providing sufficient accommodation at the Alert Bay Indian Day School to carry out this agreement.

Two years ago a four-classroom block was provided from buildings secured through War Assets Corporation from the Port Hardy Military Camp. A two-classroom building from the same source is to be provided this summer.

It is planned to erect another four-classroom block this year, but to date plans have not yet been completed.

In accordance with our agreement with the Church of England, it is therefore recommended that the Department take over the payment of the salaries of the three remaining teachers at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School. This will mean nine divisions being operated with approximately three hundred and sixty pupils. About two hundred will come from the Residential School and the remaining one hundred and sixty will come from the Alert Bay Indian Village.

This will provide a unified system of education at Alert Bay and will ensure a better calibre of teachers.
The Residential School teachers have been resigning regularly each year, due to the higher salaries, better working conditions and superannuation benefits which can be obtained in teaching in Indian Day Schools.

The present per capita grant rate at this school is $290.00 per annum. The last audit report for the year ended December 31, 1949, shows that the dollar cost per pupil at this school was $300.75. In view of this information, I would recommend that we do not reduce the per capita rate at this school but leave it at the present amount. We should also inform the M.S.C.C. that this school has been given an increase in grant in that the Department has assumed the cost of paying the teachers.

I would recommend, therefore, that the Minister grant authority in the usual way for the payment of these teachers at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, now to become teachers at the Indian Day School. It is anticipated that the salaries involved will amount to about $6,500.00 an academic year.

Director.

Recommended.

Deputy Minister.

Approved.

Minister.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

R. 8569

Indian Agent
12th June, 1940.

The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Dear Sir,

Herewith Requisition for School Material for the Preventorium. The Matron of this unit in submitting her requisition states as follows:

"Considering the number of patients (14) at the Preventorium, it is realized that some items on this list may seem in excess of normal requirements. This is due to several factors. In the first place, the Preventorium is operated as a unit separate from the school, and it is felt it will be much more satisfactory and more economical in the long run if the supply is established at the Preventorium. There can, of course, due to circumstances, be practically no "doubling up" in the use of textbooks, and since we are subject to an irregular change of patients there is an unpredictable change of grades. However, there is a careful supervision of supplies with no waste.

With regard to material for occupational therapy, which includes such things as raffia, paints, build-up posters, etc., even a small amount would be greatly appreciated since mental contentment plays such an important part in eventual cure, and it is a problem to keep little hands happily occupied with a minimum of physical expenditure.

Careful consideration has been given to the quantities and varieties of school supplies requested, and it is hoped that the requisition will meet with favourable consideration."
The Indian Agent,
Alert Bay.

In spite of this request, I have cut this requisition drastically in line with the Department's request in their circular C 1-1-4 of April 13th for economy, and it is hoped that as it now stands the Department may see fit to sanction the items requested.

Yours very truly,

FEAL.
