Alert Bay, B.C.,
18th June, 1940.

Sir,

Attached please find a requisition for school material for the Preventorium operated in connection with St. Michael's Residential School, Alert Bay.

The enclosed letter from Principal Anfield will be self-explanatory, and I agree in his remarks and would kindly ask the Department to furnish the requisition if at all possible, as submitted.

At the present time there are fourteen patients in this Preventorium, and splendid work is being done by the staff in charge, and while the requisition may appear a little large, nevertheless once a certain amount of the material is provided, future requisitions will be more of a minor nature.

I would therefore recommend that the requisition as requested be shipped direct to the "Matron-in-charge, St. Michael's School Preventorium, Alert Bay, B.C.".

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Canada.

Ottawa, May 15th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your requisition dated the 29th of April for Bible and Prayer and Hymn Books for presentation to graduates, I would point out that the Anglican Prayer and Hymn Books are printed in England. The Government Stationery Office has tried several firms, but up to the present time has been unable to secure these books, although an order for a large supply was placed several months ago. As you are aware, the delay is due to shipping conditions.

These books may arrive at any time, and we are forwarding a requisition to the Government Stationery Office, so that they can send them on as soon as they are received.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Earl Anfield,
Principal,
Alert Bay Indian Res. School,
Alert Bay, B.C.
Sir,

As the end of the school term is approaching, Principal Anfield has forwarded a list of the graduating pupils of the Alert Bay Residential School, and is making request that the Department grant to each pupil a Diploma as a record of this achievement. Eleven diplomas are requested, and the names of the pupils are shown on Mr. Anfield's letter of April 29th, copy of which is attached. I would request that the Department give this matter early attention so that the diplomas may arrive in time for the closing exercises.

In another communication of the same date, copy attached, Principal Anfield is placing before the Department a request for Bibles and Prayer and Hymn Books as graduation gifts to pupils leaving the school this year, and has submitted a requisition covering the quantities required. Such gifts have been the practice in the past, and if possible I would recommend that the Department continue this very worth-while gesture. These too would be appreciated, if granted, in time for the closing exercises of the School.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 22nd instant and also copies of correspondence relating to the purchase of a "Book of Knowledge" for the Alert Bay Residential School.

The records here indicate that a few years ago, when money was plentiful, a few sets of these books were purchased by way of experiment. In a period as critical as this, however, and at a time when we are called upon to use both sides of the paper, a request such as this cannot be even considered.

Indian Agent Todd's reference to canvassers, who sold approximately $1500.00 worth of cheap jewelry to Indians, is somewhat disturbing. I appreciate very fully, of course, that it is exceedingly difficult for Indian agents to keep a close check on such matters. It might be advisable, however, to remind Indian agents again and residential school principals that canvassing on Indian reserves and canvassing at Indian residential schools should not be permitted. Now that the Indian Act is up for revision it is just possible that certain amendments may occur to you that would assist Indian agents and residential school principals in correcting these abuses.

Yours truly,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,

Dear Sir,

The enclosed correspondence and Order Form received from Principal Anfield of St. Michael's School will be self-explanatory.

While no doubt this set of books would be valuable equipment for the school, nevertheless I cannot understand Principal Anfield making such a request when the Department are having difficulty in obtaining funds for the essential services which must be provided if our schools are to be kept in operation, and I cannot recommend that the Department make this purchase at this time.

I might add the Agent for this Society called on me, and I gave him no satisfaction and requested that he not prevail upon the Indians to purchase this set of books. I pointed out to him that I felt the Indians should be expected to put their money into Victory Bonds or War Savings rather than into this sort of thing at the present time; however I understand he did sell one or two sets to Indians, and quite a number to the white settlements in this district.

While I appreciate the value of this set of books for children in ordinary times, it seems to me these matters should be drawn to the Government's attention when they are striving for a total war effort, as there are thousands of dollars yearly being spent in this way which would otherwise be available to help finance the war if such sales were prohibited for the duration.

I would like to also point out that during the past year an Agent selling jewellery made a canvass of Alert Bay, and it is definitely known to me that he sold approximately fifteen hundred dollars' worth to Indians in the district before I got to know about it and ordered him to leave the Reserve.

No doubt there will be other Agents in this district at the close of the present fishing season when the Indians have lots of money, and I personally will do everything I can to discourage sales of this nature.

Your obedient servant,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Vancouver, B.C.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Todd:

We recently had a series of visits from the representative of the Grolier Society, Mr. R. B. McLure. He asked me to consider through the Department the purchase of a set of the "Book of Knowledge". They purchased a set for the School some fifteen years ago, it did yeomen service, and was highly valued by both Teachers and Pupils alike.

I have no wish in these days of war to request unnecessary equipment, and pass attached bids on for consideration should the Department find itself towards the close of the year with a few unnecessary dollars from School Votes.

Dear Mr. Todd:

Attached please find Supplementary Requisitions for Classroom material.

You will recall that the main Requisitions were submitted some months ago, and have now been filled by the Department. It is regretted that this Supplementary Requisition is necessary at this time, but it was considered unwise early in the year to try and estimate the texts books required. We have now completed the annual classroom examinations, and these text books have been ordered in the light of the new grading set-up for the next School year. In the Past we have been in the unhappy position of either having too many or too few texts for the grades. And either situation is particularly wasteful in these times of war.

In connection with the Hymn Books, these are absolutely essential for school use. The Department has not been asked to supply any of these for some three or four years, and extraordinary care has been taken to look after the hymn books supplied. Our present supply is completely worn out and cannot possibly be used next term. We would appreciate the small cloth covered hymn book only, which costs about twenty-five cents retail.

Your approval of these Requisitions will be appreciated.

Dear Mr. Todd:

It is regretted that we must place before you for consideration the attached School Requisition, which we would ask you to place before the Department with the following explanation.

The last large Requisition was sent in December 42. In accordance with a circular from the Department this requisition was for supplies for the entire 43-44 School year. Unfortunately our Senior and Intermediate class rooms were in the hands of inexperienced teachers, whom we now find grievously underestimated the requirements of their classes. The Senior class room teacher in particular competely failed to appreciate the text needs of his room.

This year we are fortunate indeed to have four experienced and highly capable teachers, and a survey of our stock and class room material has proven alarming. After a conference with these teachers and a careful check of supplies I instructed them to prepare the attached requisitions which are minimum requirements to get us through the present academic year 43-44.

The School is filled to capacity, we have a Grade 5 class of 5 pupils, and it is certified that the texts and material on this requisition are urgently required and essential for the efficient operation of the School.

Ottawa, May 10, 1944.

Mr. J. W. Driscoll, Supt. of Stationery, Dept. of Public Printing & Stationery, Ottawa, Ont.

Re Requisition No. 24315.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 9th instant in which you state that an official of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School has advised you that the 3 packages of industrial weaving mats ordered on the above requisition have not been received.

We have had so much difficulty in endeavouring to have these particular supplies delivered to the Alert Bay Residential School that I would suggest you ask your supplier to send the weaving mats which are ordered on the attached requisition - No. 24742 - by registered mail. My reason for asking this is that the teacher in question has been pestering us with letters about the non-receipt of weaving mats ordered by her and if we can keep her happy by delivering the mats it will certainly have a good effect on the school.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

Last year I received none, so that our graduates proceeded to their homes without the accustomed gift. On January 15th of this year I asked for one hundred copies. Dear Sir:

I am newly appointed teacher here. I find I need school supplies for the quarter beginning promptly Sept. 3. What is the procedure to secure good service immediately?

We need Health material for 18 students - 4 Grade 8, 1 Grade 5, 1 Grade 4, 1 Grade 3, 3 Grade 2, 8 Grade 1 & Kindergarten. I would like Health Verses and Posters depicting care and prevention particularly of T.B., other communicable diseases, pretty pictures of good food, care of eyes, proper posture.
when sitting, lying, standing. We need health stories for these grades, particularly in the Sage Dick & Jane series.

We need any and all sufficient suitable Social Studies texts for these grades, also a map of B.C., the surrounding district, and Canada, the World entire, and U.S.A., any others you think might be handy.

We need art material. Where does that departmental series on Classroom Projects come from? We need a book on crafts for beginners. Where and how much would material be and come from? If here can I get some tasteful and instructively beautiful, framed pictures? Where does one get those wall posters out-outs of farm and city, and how little people live in far-away lands?
Have you any free horticultural supplies or books on easy agriculture, suitable for bed-side study? What film slides for a little electric projector are available?

Is there by chance a travelling library system I could get in touch with? Is there a similar travelling picture study group available?

You have never failed to supply information most willingly before, so I shall most happily look forward to my requests being filled as nearly as possible now.

Thank you very much,

Yours very truly,

January 7, 1948.

Dear General Turner:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, file AR-6, arrangements will be made to forward you a cheque for $4.80 covering the cost of pencils purchased for use at the Alert Bay Residential School.

I note the principal's statement that "the Indian Agent had wired and written Ottawa without result". Our files show that in a letter dated October 30th the Indian Agent forwarded a letter dated October 22nd from Reverend Mr. Wickens stating that they had not received a sufficient number of lead pencils. On the original requisition we had ordered the number of pencils requested by the principal and when we received the letter mentioned above we immediately communicated with the Government Stationery Office and arranged to have them check the matter and send the additional pencils if they had not already done so. We have no record of any telegram coming from the Indian Agent.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

On October 22nd of this year a letter was written from the School advising you that we had not received our full requisition of lead pencils. We have been in communication with you in this regard from time to time and have had to buy pencils locally, but to date have not received definite word as to when we may expect the balance of this requisition.

The pencils are urgently needed for the opening of the new term in January, and it would be appreciated if you could arrange for us to receive them at the earliest possible date.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Books and Pictures for Alert Bay School.

Your File: 875-4(36)

Thank you very much for the information of your letter of January 31, 1952.

I have written Principal Cheales advising him to see Mr. Todd as soon as possible in regard to borrowing some books from the Indian Day School.

It is unfortunate that no pictures are available for use in the children's dining-room. The place is rather drab and a few pictures on the walls would have cheered the place up considerably. At a later date I intend looking around to see if some pictures cannot be procured from some other Government Department.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Attention: Supt. of Education,

With reference to your letter 875-4(B6) dated January 28, 1952 and attached requisition for textbooks etc., for Alert Bay Indian Residential School, Preventorium.

As the Preventorium is a separate unit from the Alert Bay Indian Day School where all the children of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School are educated, it is thought that it would be more advisable to have these items shipped direct and separately.

Your action as necessary or further advice would therefore be appreciated.

M. S. Todd,
Superintendent,
Kwawkewlth Agency.
January 31, 1952.

Rev. Canon H.G. Cook,
Superintendent,
M.S.C.C.,
102 Bank St.,
Ottawa.

Dear Canon Cook:

With reference to your letter of January 28th regarding books and pictures for the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, we have reviewed our files and note that library books valued at $235. were shipped to the Alert Bay Day School this year and similar allotments were shipped to the day and residential school during the past number of years.

It is presumed that you would like to have a number of books placed in the reading room adjoining the dormitories in the residential school for the children to use in the evenings. It is felt that a satisfactory circulating library can be arranged between the day school and the residential school for the purpose you mention. The Principal of the residential school should be able to arrange with the teachers to loan a quantity of books from each classroom for a period of two or three weeks and place these in the residential school reading room.

After a period agreed upon, these books can be returned to the day school classrooms and new lots brought to the residential school. In this way, the books will serve two purposes and will become more attractive to the children in new surroundings.
I am forwarding a copy of this letter to Indian Superintendent Todd in order that he may bring this matter to the attention of the principals in both schools.

With reference to the pictures, I regret to inform you that we have no suitable pictures in stock and are unable to supply them.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
January 28, 1952.

Mr. P. N. Phelan,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Pictures & Books

I've just completed a visit to St. Michael's School, Alert Bay, and noted that there was a lack of reading material for the children in the way of light fiction. Could you please let me know if there is any way the Principal can requisition for a quantity of good fiction for both boys and girls? There are 210 pupils in the School and a goodly number of them like to spend their free time reading.

It was also noted that the walls in the dining room were rather bare. Is it possible to procure through Indian Affairs Branch six or eight of the cardboard reproductions in frames which one sees in government offices? Such pictures placed about the dining room would do much to brighten what is now rather a plain room.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office.

Superintendent.

Mr. M.S. Todd,
Supt. Indian Agency,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir,

You will recollect having discussed with me requisition for Office and School supplies on your last visit to Alert Bay. Recently I sent a reminder to your office in Vancouver and have had no acknowledgment of same. Just this week I heard that you were transferred to Ottawa, and am writing you with the hope that you will look into this matter.

Memorandum -

The undersigned begs to submit herewith a letter of the 25th inst. from the Visiting Indian Agent for B.C., as well as one of the 12th inst. from the Indian Agent for the Naramata Agency, having reference to the proposed establishment of an industrial institution on Cormorant Island, Alert Bay.

In connection with this matter the undersigned begs to report that the plans and specifications, as well as the estimate of the cost of the building submitted by the Agent, are for a regular industrial scheme, whereas the Dept. understood

To the Hon.

E. Dunbar,
Dept. Sec'y of Ind. Affairs.
from the commencement
that it was not proposed
to establish a school at
which Indian boys should be
boarded, but that merely
workshops were to be erected
at which young men and
boys could be instructed in
trades, such as carpentry,
blacksmithing and boatbuilding,
instructors being provided
at the expense of the Dept.
It was supposed that the
pupils would give daily attendance
at the workshops for the
purpose of receiving instruction
in these industries, and that
they would reside at their
homes in the vicinity. Mr.
Agent Pidcock, in a previous
communication, expressed the
opinion that, were an
institution of this kind
established at Alert Bay, it
would induce many Indians
from other parts to remove
there and settle down in the
vicinity of the institution; and he submitted estimates of the cost of erecting a building for such an institution and of affording instruction in the above lines of industry to the pupils attending thereof. The first estimate submitted by him placed the whole cost at from $1500 to $2000. Subsequently this estimate was amended; and he then stated it as his opinion, in which Mr. Adrian Reserve Comte O'Reilly concurred, that the building would cost $1200; that the wages of the instructors in the three trades above mentioned would amount to $2700 per annum, being $75 a month each; and that the cost of articles required to be purchased in order to admit of the instruction being given would be about $300—making the total amount of his estimate $4200.
In the supplementary estimates for 1890-91 this amount was included, and it is still available for the purposes of the institution.

Now, however, Mr. Pidcock submits a more extravagant estimate based upon plans and specifications for a regular industrial school at which pupils are to be boarded, the cost of which he estimates at £4000, without including furniture, clothing for boys and other requisites, which he estimates at £1600, and the cost of maintenance and salaries of employees, which he places at £1500, besides £500 for unforeseen expenses; thus making a total estimate of £7600 to get the proposed institution fairly started. This last estimate, it will be observed, is £3400 in excess of the preceding one; and no provision has been made for the excess of cost. Mr. Agent Pidcock gives no reason or explanation in his
letter for his championing his views in regard to the character of the institution to be established.

The undersigned considers that, before the Dept can intelligently take his proposal to establish an industrial school at which pupils shall be boarded into consideration, he should be called upon to explain why he has made the recommendation in the direction which his last communication on the subject indicates; and that the Visiting Indian Dept at Victoria should also be asked to give his views on the proposed change in the original intention in regard to the suggested establishment.

The undersigned would add that, in view of the uncivilized character of the Kawawkewth Indians who, as stated in a previous report, are probably the most debased in the Dominion, it is exceedingly questionable whether the time has come for the
establishment of a regular industrial school at which children would be admitted as boarders, and whether it would not be more prudent, before expending a large amount of money, to commence operations at Alert Bay in a moderate scale by establishing some such institution as was at first proposed, and for which Parliament has voted the money.

Dear Sir,

I have recently ascertained from the Indian Department that the industrial school which is to be proposed should be built on Cormorant Island and will not be built this winter; if at all.

This communication "if at all" is a great blow to me.
I am aware there has been a change made in the original proposal which has caused delay, but surely the Indian children should not suffer on this account.

Such a school as the Department has at Metlakahtla is most desirable for this Agency and there could be no better site than the one chosen at Alert Bay.

There is not the slightest doubt there are sufficient pupils to fill this school. Four years ago I sent three lads to Bishop Reder's school at Metlakahtla where they did well and two months since a lad came three times asking to be sent to this "good" school.

He is now with Mr. Scott at Metlakahtle three hundred miles away. Mr. Cooke, my co-worker, has a large school fourteen miles from...
Albert Bay and he tells me he could find eight or ten pupils to the industrial school.

It is almost impossible to educate one of our Indian children except he can be kept at a boarding school similar to the one proposed.

The habits of the Indians are so migratory, and the attendance of the chief so irregular that the results from our village school are in almost every instance nil.

Specifications of Proposed Industrial School to be erected at Alert Bay, British Columbia.

Description.

The building to be frame of two stories high, standing on cedar posts, 60 feet long and 40 feet wide, having a porch at front entrance.

Foundation.

Sink cedar posts of not less than one foot in diameter three feet into the ground upon which when evenly cut off at not less than two feet above the surface of the ground in the highest place, set the sills of the building. Posts to be set six feet apart from centres.

Sills.

Five longitudinal sills and two transverse sills to be placed on the top of the posts and spiked thereto. The sills to 12 in X 10 in, the centre sills to be dovetailed into the transverse sills and tremailed thereto. The corners to be half checked and tremailed.

Joists.

Upon the sills place the joist 2" X 10" two inches
X ten inches to be securely spiked to sills and place two feet apart from centres. The upper joists to be 2 X 14 supported by the partitions, those in the school room to be supported by a centre beam of 6 in. X 8 with two posts 6" X 6", to be placed two feet apart from centres, and securely spiked to studding and centre supports, and to rest on a piece of 1 1/4 X 4 in. let into the side studding.

The tie joists on the top of wall plates to be 2 1/2 X 6 in and to be placed two feet apart from centres and securely spiked to wall plates and centre partitions, and to extend one foot on each side the wall plates for the rafters to rest on. The upper floor joists to be securely braced the whole length of the building in at least two places.

Flooring.

The ground floor to be laid with 1 1/2 flooring 4 in. wide tongued and grooved and blind nailed. Spruce lumber to be preferred. The chamber floor to be 1 1/4 in. spruce lumber tongued and grooved and blind nailed. All the flooring to be good and sound and free from knots.

Walls.

To be made of 2 X 6 scantling doubled at the doors and window joints, with wall or roofing plates of two thicknesses, well braced throughout, the scantling to
Rafters.

The rafters to be (2" X 8") two by eight inches, scantling to be notched into a plate securely nailed into the upper tie beams, the rafters to be put two feet apart centres on the top of each of the upper tie beams or joists. A purline plate of 4 X 4 in with supporting posts not more than six feet apart to be securely spiked to rafters, and posts to a plate of (3 X 6) three inches by six inches to be firmly spiked on the upper tie joists. Rafters to be covered with one inch boards put closely together, upon which first class split shingles are to be laid 4 1/2 inches to the weather, the apex of the roof to have weather boards 12 wide, also a plain cornice to be fixed to roof.

Stairs.

Stairs as shown in drawing, treads to be 1 1/2 thick, risers 1 inch thick, to be well and strongly framed and let into stringers, to be 4 feet wide, treads to be nosed, iron rods to be used as a hand rail to be screwed on either side of staircase, strong railing and balusters to be fixed on the top of landing.

Doors.

The front door to be 2 in thick solid with diagonal boards double, the door to be a double door each half to measure 2 feet by 6 ft 8 in to be hung with heavy iron hinges, "not butts" and to have a plain finish around it. The other doors to be 2 ft 8 in by 6 ft 8 in, 1 1/2 thick, hung with heavy 3 1/2 inch butts. The lock of all inside doors to be good American locks with white furniture.

I have the honor to inform you that a fire occurred in the Alert Bay Industrial School on the early morning of 17th last. The damage is confined to the inside walls of the kitchen adjoining the range, where the fire is supposed to have started, and the stringer supporting the stairs is charred, but not sufficiently so to need any renewal. I have the honor to again direct your attention to my letter of 23rd November last No 670/5, with reference to an application for new beds and tools for the Alert Bay Industrial School. In your letter of December 27th No 730, G.5 you state that your office has been advised by letter of 21st December No II6947/5 that this matter would have to stand over until the supplementary estimates. Since then I have heard nothing of the matter.

On Saturday afternoon last in company with Mr Inspector Green I visited the Industrial School with a view of knowing the exact condition of the equipment of the school. We thoroughly examined all the beds and found them in a most deplorable condition. Most of the iron bedsteads originally supplied by the Department as part of the equipment of the school are broken to pieces. The wire mattresses on these beds are completely worn out. Fifteen of these could be repaired by purchasing new springs to put on the old frames. I would respectfully request that 25 new iron beds complete with wire mattresses and wool over mattresses be supplied to the school, in addition to repairing the other mattresses.

In the laundry we found that the copper boiler for heating the water for washing and for boiling the clothes, is worn out and the brickwork and chimney in a dangerous condition.

There should be also a terra cotta drain pipe supplied to carry away the waste water in place of the wooden box in which it is at present conveyed which keeps rotting away and choking very often.

In the attic there is a very rough room used as a dormitory, which is absolutely unfit for the purpose but which
could by a moderate expenditure for material be made fit for 20 beds. At present the room which is 18 feet x 60 feet is partially lined with rough lumber, and the cracks covered with strips of paper which has burst along the seams, and there are two small windows for ventilation one at each end. This room is dark and unwholesome at present, but if there were three windows (mullion style) put in at each end, and one dormer window in the east side, and the room lathed and plastered, this would make a splendid dormitory.

There should also be a fire escape ladder put in at the north end, as at present it is a fire trap.

This School is a credit to the Department in every other way, but the per capita allowance, is not sufficient in view of the increased cost of supplies, to pay for these very necessary repairs.

At the time of our visit there were only 19 boys in residence, and these had only been there a few days. Mr Green examined them in reading and spelling while I was there, in which they acquitted themselves well.

I would urge upon the Department the immediate need of these repairs to the Industrial School. The boys are quite able, under the management of the Trades Instructor, Mr G. Green, to do all the work, if the Department would find the material.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

I beg to report that I arrived at Alert Bay on the evening of Saturday, September 14, 1907, and inspected the Industrial school on the 16 making a measured sketch for future reference.

The school building is a balloon frame built on mud sills laid on the gravel bottom and is in fairly good condition, excepting a few of the posts which are now showing signs of decay and will in a short time require taking out and renewing.

The main building is an oblong square 40 x 60 with gable to front and contains on ground floor, dining-room, sitting-room, office, pantry and bathroom and lavatory. The first floor contains six rooms for staff, with storerooms and one large dormitory. The attic contains one large dormitory lighted from the ends only.

In addition to the main building there is an extension containing sheds and store room immediately in rear of kitchen, also connecting with building at angles is school-room and workshop extension. This portion of building is one story in height only. In addition there are several small out buildings and an elevated wooden tank for water supply which is taken from a small well near the buildings.

The framework supporting the water tank is showing signs of decay and will require repairs to prevent settlement. The wooden drain conveying sewage to water front is rotten and should be taken up and replaced with a tile or cement drain. The old wooden gutter pipes are rotting and should be taken down and new galvanized iron
eavestroughs and down pipes put up instead.

The workshop should be increased in size as there is not room enough to build or repair, and this with house carpentry appears to be the mechanical training which is required in this district.

A recreation room is also necessary and this could be provided at little expense if the room at present used as a work-shop is extended by 10 or 12 feet and used for a recreation room and a new work-shop built at a greater distance from the classroom.

Fruit can be readily grown in this locality and I am of the opinion that schools such as this should train the children in the care and cultivation of fruit trees and vines as this should prove a profitable undertaking for the graduates of schools in this district.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Re...Vitaly necessary repairs at Girls' Home and Boys' School.

Sir:

In pursuance to a request made by your Indian Agent, Mr. W.M. Halliday, for an itemised list of the repairs necessary at the Alert Bay Residential Schools, I have the honour to submit herewith what we consider to be most necessary to enable us to carry on our work until such time as the Department completes the construction of the new school. I might say that our Field Secretary, Dr. T.B.R. Westgate, was at the school when this survey was made, and I am asking him to write you in connection therewith.

Girls' Home.

Roofs. That on the lean-to over back entrance needs re-shingling, with new flashing put in. New flashing is needed all round the main furnace chimney, as water leaks through into the Vice-Principal's bedroom. All gutters should be overhauled, and new stand and down pipes must be installed. These should be at least 3" in diameter, in order to adequately carry off the large amount of rain that falls through the winter. Nearly all the down pipes in use at present are rotten.

Outside doors. Of the six doors of this type, three need replacing, those leading into each stairs, the furnace room, and the double door leading to the gardens. The other three need overhauling, new thresholds, and new bolts. At present the two big double doors on this building both have to be kept shut with ropes, whilst one is kept boarded up all the time, there being no other way of keeping it closed. This is unsafe from the fire risk point of view.

Inside doors. Practically nearly all doors require new thresholds, four require locks.

Windows, in nearly all cases need weather strips, as a great deal of heat is lost through the draftiness from the windows. Seven new wire screen windows are required. These are absolutely necessary in this school on account of the moral question involved.

Transoms. Six require new guide irons, and supports.

Radiators. Four new steam cocks required.

Play-room, a small room, 17' x 10', should be V-jointed 5 feet above the skirting board. This room is in a disgraceful state of disrepair and is the only play room for 36 girls.

Furnace room. Two new windows are required, and the concrete work on window thresholds needs building up before the windows can be set in.

Furnace. Although the Dept. has ordered the inspection of the boiler and we have applied for such inspection, no-one has yet been to look the boiler over. The entire furnace requires asbestos casing, which should go on at once, as the fire can be seen through the side of the furnace walls.

Front steps of building are in dangerous state and should be relined and strengthened.
Kwawkewlth Agency,
Alert Bay, B.C.

In drawing the plans for the new school building might I respectfully suggest to the architect to take into consideration that our winters here have excessively heavy rains and the roofs should be of a firm steep pitch in order to prevent the shingles or other roofing becoming saturated and causing leaks. It would, also, be as well to have as few valleys in the building in order to prevent leaking. The salt air is very hard on all flashing with the exception of lead flashing, and there is always a tendency to leak in the valleys.

1. ALERT BAY

New school at Alert Bay to amalgamate the two existing institutions and have a capacity of accommodating not less than 200 pupils, along with suitable provision for giving instruction in High School subjects. In addition to the main school building which should have a Principal's residence annexed to the site, the following buildings, animals, etc., will be necessary:

(a) Farmer's residence.
(b) Stock barn with open shed shelter, and six grade Jerseys and one team of horses.
(c) Wood shed (Necessary on account of the heavy rain fall on the Coast).
(d) Lumber shed.
(e) Poultry house to accommodate 200 birds, and 200 White Leghorns.
(f) Pigsty to accommodate 20 pigs and 1 boar and 5 sows.
(g) Tool house (unless built in 1928 for class room).

With regard to (b) the following extract from the report made by Inspector Frank of the Health of Animals Branch, Ottawa, to the Chief Inspector of that Branch in Vancouver, B.C. on Aug. 22nd, 1927, relative to the requirements necessary to maintain a "supervised herd" in good standing at this school, should be noted:

"I have suggested that, (1) the Industrial School Reserve, which is situated on the western end of Cormorant Island, should be fenced across the entire eastern boundary, and so prevent other animals on the Island having access to their grounds. (2) A sufficiently large modern cow barn be built to accommodate between twenty and thirty head, with open shed shelter for the young stock. (There is an added reason why such a structure should have cement floors, gutters, mangers, etc., and a two or three foot side wall of the same material, that reason being the great number of rats which infest the Island."

The fencing referred to above will be 200 rods long. It should be 10 x 10 gauge and would cost about $300. Four gates 12 x 12 gauge would cost about $50.

Necessity for above:

(a) While the Girls' Home is comparatively new and in good repair, the Boys' School is old, leaky, drafty, and rots on timbers which in places have almost completely rotted away.

(b) Neither building is capable of accommodating the number of children awaiting admission.

(c) The cost of maintaining and administering two separate institutions is greater than would be required for one.

(d) The distance from Alert Bay to any centre where instruction in High School subjects may be secured is so great as to place such instruction beyond obtainment by many who desire to have it.

It is suggested:

(a) That the new building should be erected on an elevation about 250 yds. below the existing institutions.
(b) That the new building should be known as the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, and have accommodation for 200 pupils.

(c) That a separate class room be provided for importing instruction in High School subjects, unless the existing Girls' Home be set apart for this purpose and operated in conjunction with the Provincial Government of B.C.

(d) That one set of out-buildings including a stock barn, a poultry house, piggery, a wood shed, and an implement shed should be provided for the new institution.

(e) That provision be made in the estimates for 1926 for supplying the school with six good milking cows - preferably Jerseys as the school has now one Jersey bull, two fair Jersey cows and one calf, some Saanen or Taggenberg goats on account of their immunity to tuberculosis. Estimated cost $600. A team of horses and harness should also be provided. Estimated cost $250.

N.B. Provision should also be made for clearing more land. The land set apart for the use of the school comprises 410 acres. Only about 20 acres of this including the sites occupied by all buildings is cleared or under cultivation. The uncleared area is covered with coniferous timber and will cost about $250 per acre to clear ready for the plough, and about $150 per acre for light clearing leaving the stumps in the ground to rot.

An additional thirty acres should be cleared ready for the plough, at the earliest date possible. Modern machinery will be required for this and provision should be made for a tractor and stump puller similar to that supplied to the Sioux Lookout School, (Fordson Tractor estimated cost $2,128.75 - see my letter Sept. 28th, 1926), or of a stronger make. Estimated cost $2,000.

The machinery required, according to the list compiled by the Acting Principal is as follows:

"Tractor, either the 2 Ton Caterpillar (see enclosed letter), or the 10-20 McCormick Deering. Either must be equipped with belt pulley and preferably take off drive. Price of the McCormick is $1100. Stump puller, attachments, freight, etc., $700.

Tractor Saw complete for use with tractor to cost $66. Plow, tractor 2 bottom type, P&O, "Little Genius" type by McCormick Deering is the best. It will cost $120.

Harrow, 4 section, 20 tooth type, to cost $32.50.

Scruffler, McCormick Deering, 5 tooth, to cost $16.50.

Wagon, one horse type, steel axled to cost $105.

Disc harrow, McPd. #12-16, to cost $67.

Engine and Pump for school supply. Must be at least 10 H.P. engine, and pump capable of filling tank at rate of at least 750 gals. per hour. I cannot get prices on these things locally and would need an expert to figure exact requirements."

Rough estimate of total cost $2000.00.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith the original of the Boiler Inspector's Report on the heating equipment at the Girls' Home. This inspection was requested by the Dept. some months ago, but as the inspector only comes up once or twice a year, it was necessarily deferred.

It will be noted on the report that there are quite a number of things requiring attention in connection with this furnace, the largest item being that of a new front, the present one being cracked. It is more than likely that this crack was caused by the flood waters which came last Xmas, and rose above the fire box of the furnace, putting it out of action for nearly three weeks.

Might I ask the views of the Department in connection with the urgent necessity of some of these repairs, especially the overhauling of the radiators, many of which have to be kept shut off owing to lack of steam cocks, leaks, etc. We are now in the midst of the bad weather of the year, and the building is cold. Sir:-

With reference to your letter of Oct. 25th, giving authority for the installing of fire gongs on the floors of the Boys and Girls School, and also of the installation of a fire escape considered to be the most satisfactory to myself and the principal, I am forwarding you Vouchers No. 97 and 98, for $1.66 and $87.79, in favor of the Alert Bay Saw Mills, and the Brettell Distributing Company Limited, Vancouver, B.C.

These gongs have now been installed in the school and on a test have worked very satisfactorily. They have two methods of working. There is a switch in the bedroom of the principal which by being connected will ring the alarm at any time, and the other is a small glass hanging below the gong with a little weight attached to it so that when the glass is broken the alarm becomes automatic.

With regard to the fire escape for the Girls School, I went into this matter very carefully with the principal, and your suggestion about the sliding pole with a landing on each floor was not considered to be advisable in this building for two reasons. In the first place it would require a well hole to be cut on the first floor which would weaken the building considerably, and would be more or less of a menace for children falling through the hole even with a good railing around it, and the other objection was that as a number of the girls are small it was feared that they would not be able to successfully negotiate the sliding pole and might fall and break an arm or leg, which would create a poor impression in the minds of the older Indians. After careful consideration it was decided to put a metal shoot similar to what is used on the play-grounds of the ordinary public schools, leading from the sleeping porch to the ground. The installation of this is
not quite complete yet, but the principle on which it works is that inside of the building there is a small windlass and a pliable wire cable leading from the windlass to a pulley attached on an iron hook outside of the building, and a small counterpoise weight also attached so that it would not come down with a great jerk. In case an alarm is sounded the door on the opening of this will be opened and the outer end of the shoot will be in position and all the children can go out in a very few minutes. The expense is going to be comparatively small in connection with it, and a voucher will be sent from the General Repair Shop for the shoot and fittings later on.

Dear Mr. Halliday:

I beg to enclose herewith vouchers for lubricator and repairs to pump, carried out prior to holidays per authority of yours of the 21st of May of this year.

At that time you had secured authority for us to install a force feed lubricator on our Petter's Engine, and your letter stated that bills would be paid up to $65, f.o.b. Vancouver, and authorising me to purchase said lubricator and install it.

I went to see Mr. F. Wastell, and he advised me that the price quoted me by the B.C. Equipment Co. was a "hold-up", and recommended me to purchase the lubricator alone and have the other parts, including the eccentric, rods, boring, etc., done locally. He stated that he thought the lubricator alone would not come to more than $20 or so. I followed his advice and instructed the Marine Repair Shop to go ahead and install the lubricator. He found that every bearing in the engine was burnt out; that spray nozzle was out of order; that pump for fuel was not working, and that the machine in general was in bad state of disrepair. He built the eccentric and put on the lubricator, but still the machine did not lubricate properly, and much time was spent in adjustments. The job was not finished until some days after I had gone away on my holidays, and when I came back I found the machine and pump house had been burnt up. It was only then that we found out the trouble, the machine had no oil rings in it, and all lubricators in the world would not have stopped burnt out bearings. I am quite satisfied that Jorgenson tried his best to make the engine run properly and also that the time spent on it was entirely necessary, and also that if the engine had been run for as long daily as that at the Sawmill, that it would have been on the scrap heap long before. The lack of the oil rings has cost the Department a lot of money, and the schools a lot too, as the machine was literally loaded with oil all the time, and even then would seldom run more than two or three hours without heating up.

Then the bills came in from the B.C. Equipment Co. for the lubricator, as Mr. Wastell had been forced to purchase it there as they seem to have a monopoly on the Petter Equipment. He at once protested the bill, and a long correspondence ensued. I think that had not the lubricator been destroyed in the fire that Mr. Wastell would have sent it back and purchased another kind.
In view of these circumstances, might I ask please, that you will recommend to the Department, the payment of these bills, as from what I can make out, they were unavoidably though regretfully higher than the amount sanctioned.

I might say that since the Dept., through you, had the engine fixed this last time, that it has run beautifully, and I feel that had the oil rings been put in when the machine was first installed here, that there would never have been any trouble.

With kind regards, Believe me,

Very truly yours,

Earl Anfield
Principal

Sir:-

re Furnace Installation - Proposed New School,
Alert Bay, B.C.

I have the honour to bring to your attention the following suggestions with regard to the proposed new school at Alert Bay.

At the present time there is a great deal of difficulty entailed in the securing of coal supplies for plants using this fuel at Alert Bay. For some reason or other, the mines require a great deal of notice before shipment of coal can be made. In addition to this, there is a considerable hazard in bringing coal in large amounts to the Bay. Should the furnace in the new building be of the coal-burning type, sufficient coal will be required to make it almost essential that this fuel be brought in by scow, owing to prohibitive freight rates on the coast cargo carriers. I have figures to show that coal laid down in less than 50 ton lots at Alert Bay costs more per ton than coal delivered by the railload at Lytton, B.C. The relative figures are $11.50 per ton at Alert Bay and $10.25 at Lytton.

In addition to this question, we have to face the fact that coal brought in to Alert Bay either by scow or freight boat in such quantities as will be required in the new school will mean a tremendous amount of manual labour to bring from either the beach or wharf to the schools. At the Bay we have at present only one horse and one small cart which cannot handle more than 500 lbs. So it will appear that the fuel problem at the proposed new school will be a serious one and one that I feel the Department should take under serious advisement.

I am investigating at present two proposed alternatives to the burning of coal, one being the Oil-o-Matic Burner for installation in standard type furnaces and also a new sawdust burner for standard type furnaces.

With regard to the former, I should say that in Alert
Bay there are four companies with oil stations and fuel oil could be procured at wholesale prices with a minimum of expense in placing same in the school. The great advantage of this type of burner appears to be its cleanliness and ease of operation, coupled with assurance of steady heat. Although I have not at present the figures, I am given to understand that the initial cost is amply repaid by economy of operation.

The sawdust burner is a new idea and is at present in operation in several large hotels and apartment houses in Vancouver. However, they have been faced with the problem of a lack of sawdust for fuel, which condition of course would have to be seriously thought out with reference to Alert Bay. There is, as the Department knows, a sawmill there belonging to the B.C. Fishing & Packing Company, which I understand has just signed a re-lease of the Mission property on which the sawmill stands for a period of 99 years. As at present operating, this sawmill will be compelled to put in a modern standard sawdust burner and I feel that were the Department convinced of the assuredness of fuel supply from this mill, that the sawmill authorities would be glad to get rid of the sawdust and could possibly save themselves a large bill for the erection of a new burner. Of course, it must be taken into account that with the present precarious condition that exists in the fishing industry, the time might come within the course of years when this sawmill would cease to operate.

Of the two alternatives, I feel that the Oil-o-matic system presents the best possibilities and I will forward to your Department full literature and particulars of same as soon as I have procured these.

Trusting that the Department will give to these matters their very earnest consideration, I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a communication from Canon S. Gould, Secretary of the M.S.C.C. to the effect that the Department contemplate making replacement of the present buildings at the Residential Schools, Alert Bay. In this connection, there are some points that I wish to bring to the attention of the Department.

SITE

It has come to my attention that there is some controversy about the location of the new buildings. Some years ago, the Department had cleared ten acres of land for the proposed new school. This site was chosen by our Dr. Westgate, working in conjunction with your Indian Agent, Halliday and a Mr. Myles Morley who, I understand, was appointed by your Department for this purpose. These three gentlemen were unanimous in their opinion with regard to the moving of the location of the school from the present site which is on the beach to a more elevated position, the site chosen being some 250 feet above sea level. Acting on their recommendation, the Department had cleared the necessary land for construction purposes. It is only recently that your Indian Agent, Halliday, seems to have taken objection to the site originally chosen, his claim being that weather conditions, coupled with increased cost of transportation of supplies would render the operating cost of the new plant greatly in excess of what it would be should the school be built down below. Speaking personally, I am quite prepared to abide by the decision of your Department as to location, but I feel that I should inform you that should the field between the two schools be chosen, it will be necessary to have thorough drainage put in to make this building at all safe. All the land at the bottom of the hill is a gravel bar and I feel that were test piles driven water would be found very close to the surface. Your Department will no doubt be aware that when the girls' home was constructed, it was impossible to find solid foundation land. Might I suggest, in closing this subject, that an architect be appointed to proceed to Alert Bay and make definite choice of location, independent of existing opinions at that place.
ACCOMMODATION: As this will be the only school under the administration of the Indian & Eskimo Commission in the Province of British Columbia; and as the field to be served is very extensive, stretching as it does from Cape Mudge to the Naas River and taking in the Anglican children of the Queen Charlotte Islands, we would strongly recommend that accommodation for at least 175 children be incorporated in the new plant. I am under advisement from your Indian Agent at Masset, Queen Charlotte Islands that he would be prepared to give us at least 30 children; and I am also in receipt of communications from Indians of the Prince Rupert agencies expressing a desire to have their children who are Anglicans transferred from the Coquileetza Residential Institute, Sardis, B.C. So it will be seen that we will have no trouble whatever in filling this school and in keeping it filled.

TYPE OF BUILDING: I have to inform you that I have this day returned from Lytton, B.C., where, at the invitation of the Principal, Rev. A. R. Lett, I, with him and the foreman of construction, made a careful inspection of the new St. George's school. Allow me to congratulate the Department on the splendid building that they are putting up for the education of the children of the Interior Indians. I feel that we could not do better than ask the Department to give us at Alert Bay a replica of this building. There are, however, a few changes that might be incorporated in our building and so save the Department the necessity of having to change the plans or add extras on to the initial contract, and I feel that if these suggestions are given due weight that a building will be erected worthy of the best interests of the Department of Indian Affairs. For convenience, I will deal with the building floor by floor.

GROUND FLOOR

Playrooms: Should the Department build to accommodate the requested number of children, the playroom space in this school will be entirely inadequate. It is well known in Child Welfare Work that segregation of age and type are essential for the best interests of children. One playroom for 100 boys ranging in age from seven to eighteen does not bring an institution of this size in line with modern Child Welfare ideas.

Bathroom & Toilets: These I note are placed on the ground floor. Might I suggest that the three shower baths be reduced to one, thus allowing five tub baths, which will be none too many for the number of children using them. Four toilets are far from sufficient and I would suggest that the number be
increased to at least six, leaving the urinals as per the plans. If possible, I would suggest the removal of both bathrooms and toilets to another part of the building, and turning the space at present occupied by them into a junior play room.

Diningroom - Staff: As there will be no married staff quarters available at Alert Bay outside of the Principal's residence, all staff members will have to use this dining room, which will be very much too small. The plans show a 12' x 18' room, which should be increased in length at least to 24 ft. In this room there should also be a door allowing direct contact with the kitchen, thus preventing the necessity of staff food and dishes being carried from the kitchen through the children's dining room into the staff dining room.

Kitchen: It will be noted in the plans of the St. George's school that there is a 24" steel girder supporting the walls and ceiling. Below this come the pipes, etc. As there is no great weight supported by this girder, would it not be possible to decrease its depth to, say, 12", which would raise the piping out of reach of the children. Might I suggest, please, that toilets be installed in the two closets in the corridor outside the kitchen.

Schoolrooms: These rooms are excellent, with the exception of the one immediately adjacent to the Principal's residence, which has blocked the light on one side. If this could in any way be remedied, it would make the work very much easier both for pupil and teacher. There is need in all school rooms for doubling the blackboard space at present granted.

Sewing Room: As there will be no continuation class at Alert Bay for a year or two and as there will be a great deal of sewing and dressmaking carried on for the large number of new children to be admitted, might I request please that a double door be placed, allowing access from the sewing room to the continuation class room which could be used as a dress making room, allowing the sewing room to be kept for mending, etc.

FIRST FLOOR

Gymnasium-Assembly Hall: We would strongly urge the Department to allow the Assembly Hall to be equipped for a gymnasium, and the windows to be screened as has been done at Lytton. It will be also necessary that radiation should be of the wall pattern, as, should the radiators be placed on the floor as they are at Lytton, children playing basketball or other
games are liable to serious injury. As the window screens will be permanent, might I suggest that windows be constructed to open outwards.

Principal's Office: Might I suggest that a door be placed between the Principal's office and what is the white children's class room at Lytton, as I intend using this room as an office and receiving room for bales for the use of the Matron in Charge and access to and from the Principal's office would be very helpful.

Toilet Accommodation: I notice that there is a room for visiting Indians and that, under the plan of St. George's, such Indians would have to use the only staff bathroom and toilet on this floor. This, I am sure, the Department would not wish to happen and I would suggest that toilet accommodation for the visiting Indians' room be incorporated in a closet built into the room.

FIRST DORMITORY FLOOR.

There is no method shown on the plans for separating the boys and girls on this floor. It is most essential that a double door be placed at the Infirmary entrance, thus allowing boys and girls to enter the Infirmary from their respective sides of the building without meeting in the passage. This partition would necessitate another staff toilet and bathroom on this floor.

TOP FLOOR

Although there are two staff bedrooms on this floor, there are no toilet facilities on the plan and I feel that it is only fair to the staff that such should be installed and that they should not be asked to go downstairs for toilet purposes.

GENERAL

Storage: There is a sad lack of storage space provided in this building. We would bring to the attention of the Department the fact that most of our children are clothed from bales sent by the W.A. and this method requires a very large storage space, as most of the bales arrive at approximately the same time. Might I suggest that two large storage rooms be built off the hall leading from the main building to the Assembly Hall and abutting on this corridor.
Cupboards and Lockers: The plan of the new St. George's school shows no provision for locker space either in the play rooms or dormitories. As the children are away from home and have no place that they can really call their own, might I urge strongly that the Department instal steel individual lockers in the basement playrooms and wooden open type lockers either in the dormitories or corridors adjacent thereto. These lockers would be used for the children's clothing. It will also be most necessary that adequate cupboard and shelf facilities be placed in the sewing rooms and in all storage cupboards.

Should the Department see fit to build the Assembly Hall as a gymnasium, might I ask that the thickness of the floor be double that installed at Lytton. This will be necessary for the installation of gymnasium apparatus.

Water Conservation: The Department is no doubt aware of the excessive rainfall at Alert Bay and I would strongly urge that a large soft-water conservation tank be installed on the laundry roof, large enough and so equipped that it could handle practically all the water from the roof downpipes. As we have to pump all water for the school, such a tank would mean a tremendous saving in operating costs as related to the water supply of the school.

It is most essential that doors be placed allowing entrance to the rear of the building from both boys' and girls' sides.

Principal's Residence: Might I suggest that a window be placed looking out over the playgrounds, similar to that put in Mr. Lett's house at Lytton.

I would recommend and ask that the Principal's residence and the boys' side of the building be placed together and the girls' wing on the other side of the front entrance. With this plan, it will be necessary to place the boiler room and engine house to the rear of the boys' side, with the kitchen and laundry accessible to and to the rear of the girls' side.

I would strongly recommend that some kind of tower be placed on the roof of this building, to take from it the extremely flat looking appearance which the new St. George school has. This might be incorporated in a bell tower.

To ensure adequate water supply for domestic and fire-fighting purposes, it will be necessary for the Department to
enlarge the present reservoir capacity and also to install a larger engine and pump. The well supply of water will be adequate to allow of increased pumping facilities.

I am at present working on the equipment to be required for this new school and will be ready to submit same to the Department in a week's time.

Trusting that the Department will favourably view these suggestions and assuring them of our utmost willingness to co-operate in the erection of a building that will be both useful and pleasing to the eye, I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

BUNTING IRON WORKS
THE value of fuel oil as estimated by the World Powers and their Diplomatic Acts and Treaties to secure the oil rights of home and foreign oil fields must convince the most skeptical that oil as a fuel is of the greatest value, and the success and value of this fuel depends on the oil burner and the proper application and installation of the equipment.

The design, material and workmanship on Simplex Oil Burners is the product of many years of experience in oil burning and combustion engineering; not only on the Pacific Coast, but in handling successfully the heavy Mexican oils in Atlantic and Southern cities as well as the lighter oils of the mid-continent fields.

To the investor who wants a well built, reliable and efficient oil burning equipment for the purpose for which Simplex Oil Burners are built we can give assurance that money can not buy a better built and more efficient oil burning equipment than is here presented.
SIMPLEX OIL BURNERS

The SIMPLEX Improved Turbine Oil Burner is the only mechanical atomizing oil burner which embodies the principles of a carburetor, that has the synchronised regulation of the fuel oil, the atomizing and projecting power of the burner and the regulation of the necessary air for combustion. By the operator of an automobile this feature will be readily appreciated as the true relationship of the proper amount of air that is mixed with the hydrocarbons and the power generated is on a parallel with the efficient combustion of an oil burner. This regulation is controlled either by hand or by attaching the regulating arm to the damper regulator on a low pressure heating boiler.

The feature of the Simplex Improved Turbine Burner is the pneumatic turbine drive of the rotary atomizing oil cup. With this feature it is possible to attain a centrifugal force of sufficient power to break up the fuel oil into a very fine fog which is the first essential function of a successful oil burner. The spent air then passes through the nozzle and is the power to project the atomized oil into the combustion chamber; here the vaporized oil fog comes into intimate contact with oxygen of the air and a highly combustible mixture is attained.

Tests with an Orsat instrument show a combustion gas analysis of over 98% efficiency.

A small motor driven direct connected fan and oil pump unit furnishes the necessary air and oil for the burner. Where there is a multitude of burners to be installed, a large motor, fan and oil pump is used, sizes and capacities varying, as data given on page 3.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, relative to the providing of increased accommodation at the Alert Bay Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have noted your suggestion that a frame building, which could later be used as an engineering shop, be constructed to be used for dormitory purposes until the new residential school is completed, when this building could revert to its intended use as an engineering shop. Sir:

I have to bring before you the urgent need of increased accommodation at this school for more pupils. For the past few years this need has been steadily growing until now I do not know what to do to accommodate those you are trying to get in. I have applications on file that have been waiting for three years to get into school and I do not see how they can be accommodated this fall unless something is done in the way of a temporary dormitory. Even now there is serious overcrowding in both schools here and the Indians are clamouring to get their children in to School. It seems too bad that when the pleas for admittance are so urgent that we cannot find room for them.

Whilst I am aware that the Department contemplate building a new school in the near future, it is certain that we cannot occupy it for nearly a year, and I would like to place before you the suggestion that a frame building, suitable for an engineering shop of the same size and capacity as the building erected by your Department last year, to serve as a schoolroom, be constructed at once and used as a dormitory until the new school is finished when it could revert to its intended use as an engineering shop in connection with the Vocational Training programme of the new plant.

We have sufficient space to handle the teaching of the extra pupilage this would allow us to admit, and we could also take care of the dining room and other facilities required. It is sleeping space that is at a minimum. An alternative could be to utilize the present playroom (the old schoolroom) as a dormitory and use the projected new building as a playroom.

Trusting that this matter will receive your earnest consideration,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir:

Some time ago I wrote the Department asking their consideration to my recommendation for an oil-burning type of furnace system in the proposed new school to be built at this centre. I have since received word from quite disinterested parties speaking credibly of the economy brought about by this type of heating plant.

I believe that if a low pressure hot water heating system were installed in connection with such oil-burning furnace (should the Department favourably consider it) that operating costs of a plant of this nature would be reduced to a minimum, and that this school could be heated as economically as any in the land.

The great advantages of hot-water over steam appear to be as follows: A. The oil burners could be started in the morning and run for two or three hours until the radiators are hot, then they could be shut off and the building would remain heated for many hours with no cost for oil during this time, whereas with steam the oil-burners would have to operate as long as steam was required. B. The climate in this part of Canada is such that steam heat is not essential in a building of this type. C. A hot water plant, especially if operated by oil-burning furnaces can be heated up so much more quickly than could a steam installation, thereby effecting a tremendous saving in fuel costs. D. The safety element where there are so many children with access to steam coils on the radiators.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

*Inspector of Indian Schools of B.C.*
Ottawa, June 15, 1928.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Alert Bay Indian Residential School, enclosed a list of the equipment required for the manual training department. He states that continued progress is being made in this subject but that, owing to the scarcity of tools, more advanced work cannot be attempted. The Department will approve of the purchase of the tools as enumerated in the list forwarded by the Inspector, at a cost of approximately $100.41. For your information, I am enclosing a copy of the list of tools required, and the prices of same, as forwarded by the Inspector. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery at the school of these tools. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained.

After the purchase has been made, please forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.
